llm_translation: As an expert Talmud scholar, I would translate the text as follows: "Such as if he had a sick person from the day before."

hebrew_text: אי הכי מאי טעמא דרבי יהודה דאסר כגון שהיה לו חולה והבריא
human_translation: If so, what is the reason that Rabbi Yehuda prohibited where one had ill and recovered.
llm_translation: If so, what is the reason for Rabbi Yehuda who prohibited, such as when he had a sick person and then he became healthy.

hebrew_text: וכי הא דאמר רב אחא בר אדא אמר רב ואמרי לה אמר רבי יצחק בר אדא אמר רב השוחט לחולה בשבת אסור לבריא המבשל לחולה בשבת מותר לבריא
human_translation: And in accordance with that which Rav Aḥa bar Adda says Rav says, and some say Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Adda says Rav says: one who slaughters to an ill on Shabbat, prohibited for a healthy one who cooks to an ill on Shabbat, permitted for a healthy
llm_translation: And when Rav Ahah bar Adda said in the name of Rav, and some say in the name of Rabbi Yitzchak bar Adda said in the name of Rav: One who slaughters for a sick person on Shabbat, it is forbidden for a healthy person. One who cooks for a sick person on Shabbat, it is permitted for a healthy person.

hebrew_text: מאי טעמא האי ראוי לכוס והאי אינו ראוי לכוס
human_translation: What is the reason This was fit to be chewed and that was not fit to be chewed
llm_translation: What is the reason that this one is fitting for the cup, and this one is not fitting for the cup?

hebrew_text: אמר רב פפא פעמים שהשוחט מותר כגון שהיה לו חולה מבעוד יום מבשל אסור כגון שקצץ לו דלעת
human_translation: Rav Pappa says: times when one slaughters permitted where he had ill while it was still day, cooks prohibited where one cut a gourd for
llm_translation: Rav Papa said: "There are times when slaughtering is permitted, such as when one had a sick person from the day before, cooking is prohibited, such as when he cut a gourd for him."

hebrew_text: אמר רב דימי מנהרדעא הלכתא השוחט לחולה בשבת מותר לבריא באומצא מ"ט כיון דאי אפשר לכזית בשר בלא שחיטה כי קא שחיט אדעתא דחולה קא שחיט המבשל לחולה בשבת אסור לבריא גזירה שמא ירבה בשבילו:
human_translation: Rav Dimi of Neharde’a says the halakha one who slaughters for an ill on Shabbat, permitted for a healthy to raw meat [ be’umtza ]. What is the reason Since it is impossible for an olive-bulk of meat without slaughter when he slaughters he slaughters with the ill in mind. one who cooks for an ill on Shabbat, prohibited for a healthy decree lest he increase on behalf of
llm_translation: Rav Dimi of Nehardea said: The halacha is that one may slaughter for a sick person on Shabbat, and it is permitted for a healthy person in a time of urgent need. What is the reason? Since if it were impossible to have a k'zayit of meat without slaughter, when he is slaughtering, it is with the intention of the sick person that he is slaughtering. One who cooks for a sick person on Shabbat, it is prohibited for a healthy person. It is a decree lest he increase the cooking time for him.

hebrew_text: מתני׳ השוחט במגל יד בצור ובקנה שחיטתו כשרה
human_translation: one who slaughters with a hand sickle, with flint, or with a reed his slaughter is valid.
llm_translation: Mishnah: One who slaughters with a sickle, with a hand, with a rock, or with a reed, his slaughter is valid.

hebrew_text: הכל שוחטין ולעולם שוחטין ובכל שוחטין חוץ ממגל קציר והמגירה והשינים והציפורן מפני שהם חונקין:
human_translation: All slaughter [ hakkol shoḥatin ], and one may always slaughter, and one may slaughter with any except for the harvest sickle, a saw, the teeth and a fingernail, because they strangle
llm_translation: All slaughter, and always slaughter, and in all slaughter except for the sickle, the reaper, the teeth, and the nail, because they strangle.

hebrew_text: גמ׳ השוחט דיעבד אין לכתחלה לא בשלמא במגל יד דלמא אתי למעבד באידך גיסא אלא צור וקנה לכתחלה לא ורמינהי בכל שוחטין בין בצור בין בזכוכית בין בקרומית של קנה
human_translation: One who slaughters after the fact, yes, not ab initio . Granted, with a hand sickle, lest he come to perform with the other, side; but a flint and a reed not ab initio ? And raises a contradiction One may slaughter with any whether with a flint, or with glass or with the stalk of a reed.
llm_translation: Gemara: The one who slaughters, if he did so, it is not ideal. Not with a sickle, for perhaps he will come to do it with another blade, but rather with a rock and a reed. Ideally not, and we raise a contradiction: in all slaughtering, whether with a rock, or with glass, or with a reed's edge.

hebrew_text: לא קשיא כאן בתלוש כאן במחובר דאמר רב כהנא השוחט במחובר לקרקע רבי פוסל ור' חייא מכשיר עד כאן לא קא מכשיר רבי חייא אלא בדיעבד אבל לכתחלה לא
human_translation: not difficult. There, when detached. Here, when attached as Rav Kahana says: one who slaughters with attached to the ground, Rabbi deems not valid and Rabbi Ḥiyya deems valid. Rabbi Ḥiyya deems valid only after the fact; but not ab initio .
llm_translation: Not difficult here in detached here in attached for Rav Kahana said: one who slaughters while attached to the ground, Rabbi deems it invalid, and Rabbi Chiya deems it valid. Until here Rabbi Chiya deems it valid only retroactively, but ideally not.

hebrew_text: במאי אוקימתא כרבי חייא ודיעבד אלא הא דתניא בכל שוחטין בין בתלוש בין במחובר בין שהסכין למעלה וצואר בהמה למטה בין שהסכין למטה וצואר בהמה למעלה מני לא רבי ולא ר' חייא אי ר' חייא דיעבד אין לכתחלה לא אי רבי דיעבד נמי לא
human_translation: In accordance with which did you interpret in accordance with Rabbi Ḥiyya, and after the fact? But that which is taught One may slaughter with any whether with detached or with attached whether the knife is above and the neck of the animal is below or the knife is below and the neck of the animal is above; whose neither Rabbi nor Rabbi Ḥiyya. If Rabbi Ḥiyya, After the fact, yes, not ab initio . If Rabbi Even after the fact, not
llm_translation: With what is the law established like Rabbi Chiya? And it was done, rather this that was taught: "In all cases of slaughtering, whether the animal is detached or attached, whether the knife is positioned above and the animal's neck below, or the knife below and the animal's neck above, who is the authority? Not Rabbi, and not Rabbi Chiya. If it is Rabbi Chiya, it is done, but ideally not. If it is Rabbi, it is done as well, not ideally.

hebrew_text: לעולם רבי חייא ואפילו לכתחלה והאי דקמיפלגי בדיעבד להודיעך כחו דרבי
human_translation: Actually, Rabbi Ḥiyya, and even ab initio . And that disagree after the fact to convey to you the far-reaching nature of Rabbi
llm_translation: Forever Rabbi Chiya, and even initially, and this that they argue in retrospect is to inform you the strength of Rabbi.

hebrew_text: ואלא מתניתין דקתני השוחט דיעבד אין לכתחלה לא מני לא רבי ולא רבי חייא אי רבי חייא אפילו לכתחלה אי רבי דיעבד נמי לא
human_translation: But rather, the mishna which teaches: one who slaughters, after the fact, yes, not ab initio , whose neither Rabbi nor Rabbi Ḥiyya. If Rabbi Ḥiyya, even ab initio . If Rabbi Even after the fact, not
llm_translation: And rather, the Mishnah that teaches: one who slaughters on Yom Tov, it is permissible after the fact, but not ideally so, not according to Rabbi, nor according to Rabbi Chiya. If it is according to Rabbi Chiya, even ideally so; if according to Rabbi, even after the fact, not ideally so.

hebrew_text: לעולם רבי חייא ואפילו לכתחלה ומתניתין דקתני השוחט רבי היא
human_translation: Actually, Rabbi Ḥiyya and even ab initio ; and the mishna which teaches: One who slaughters, is Rabbi
llm_translation: Forever Rabbi Chiya, and even initially, and the Mishnah teaches: "One who slaughters, Rabbi Hiya."

hebrew_text: קשיא דרבי אדרבי לא קשיא כאן במחובר מעיקרו כאן בתלוש ולבסוף חיברו
human_translation: difficult, between Rabbi and of Rabbi not difficult. There, where attached from the outset; here, where detached and ultimately he reattached it.
llm_translation: Difficult is the question of Rabbi to Rabbi; not difficult here when it is connected from its inception, difficult here when it is detached, and in the end, he connected it.

hebrew_text: ומנא תימרא דשני לן בין מחובר מעיקרו לתלוש ולבסוף חיברו דתניא השוחט במוכני שחיטתו כשרה במחובר לקרקע שחיטתו כשרה נעץ סכין בכותל ושחט בה שחיטתו כשרה היה צור יוצא מן הכותל או קנה עולה מאליו ושחט בו שחיטתו פסולה
human_translation: And from where do you say that a difference for us between attached from the outset detached and ultimately he reattached it? As it is taught one who slaughters with a mechanism [ bemukhni ] his slaughter is valid; with attached to the ground, his slaughter is valid; one embedded a knife in a wall and slaughtered with it, his slaughter is valid. was a flint emerging from a wall or a reed arising on its own and he slaughtered with it, his slaughter is not valid.
llm_translation: And from where do we derive that one may slaughter whether it is attached from its inception to detached, and in the end he attached it? As it was taught: One who slaughters with a prepared knife, his slaughter is valid; if it is attached to the ground, his slaughter is valid; if he stuck the knife in the wall and slaughtered with it, his slaughter is valid. If a rock protruded from the wall or he acquired a utensil from it and slaughtered with it, his slaughter is invalid.

hebrew_text: קשיין אהדדי אלא לאו ש"מ שאני בין מחובר מעיקרו לתלוש ולבסוף חברו ש"מ
human_translation: difficult, each other, Rather, not conclude from it a difference between attached from the outset and detached and ultimately he reattached it? learn from it.
llm_translation: Difficult are they to one another. But is it not so? That it is different when it is connected from the beginning to being detached, and in the end it is connected.

hebrew_text: אמר מר השוחט במוכני שחיטתו כשרה והתניא שחיטתו פסולה ל"ק הא בסרנא דפחרא הא בסרנא דמיא
human_translation: The Master said: one who slaughters with a mechanism his slaughter is valid. But isn’t it taught his slaughter is not valid? not difficult. This in a potter’s wheel, That in a waterwheel.
llm_translation: The Master said: One who slaughters with a prepared knife, his slaughter is valid. And it was taught: his slaughter is invalid. What is the difference? Here, in the case of the knife of a butcher, and here, in the case of a similar knife.

hebrew_text: ואיבעית אימא הא והא בסרנא דמיא ולא קשיא הא בכח ראשון הא בכח שני
human_translation: And if you wish, say this and that in a waterwheel, and not difficult. This by primary force, That by secondary force,
llm_translation: And if you wish, say: this and this are comparable in the case of a prince, and it is not difficult: this is in the first power, this is in the second power.

hebrew_text: וכי הא דאמר רב פפא האי מאן דכפתיה לחבריה ואשקיל עליה בידקא דמיא ומית חייב מ"ט גירי דידיה הוא דאהני ביה וה"מ בכח ראשון אבל בכח שני גרמא בעלמא הוא
human_translation: And like that which Rav Pappa says: a certain who bound another and diverted a flow [ bidka ] of water upon him and he died, liable What is the reason? his arrows that were effective in his And this matter by primary force, But by secondary force it is merely an indirect
llm_translation: And when Rav Papa said: "One who covers his friend's eyes and I place upon him a jug of water and he dies, he is liable," what is the reason? Because his arrows are the cause of the harm, and this is effective in his hand. And this applies only to the initial force, but with the secondary force, it is merely a contributing factor.

hebrew_text: יתיב רב אחוריה דרבי חייא ורבי חייא קמיה דרבי ויתיב רבי וקאמר מנין לשחיטה שהוא בתלוש שנאמר (בראשית כב, י) ויקח את המאכלת לשחוט א"ל רב לרבי חייא מאי קאמר א"ל וי"ו דכתיב אאופתא קאמר והא קרא קאמר קרא זריזותיה דאברהם קמ"ל
human_translation: Rav sat behind Rabbi Ḥiyya, and Rabbi Ḥiyya before Rabbi and Rabbi sat and said: From where that slaughter is with detached? as it is stated: and took the knife to slaughter Rav said to Rabbi Ḥiyya: What is he saying? said to He is saying vav that is written on a tree trunk [ a’ufta ]. But didn’t say a verse The verse teaches us the diligence of Abraham,
llm_translation: Rav sat behind Rabbi Chiya, and Rabbi Chiya was sitting in front of Rabbi. Rabbi was sitting and saying, "From where do we derive the requirement for slaughter to be with intent, as it is stated (Genesis 22:10), 'And he took the knife to slaughter'?" Rav said to Rabbi Chiya, "What is he saying?" He said to him, "The 'vav' that is written in 'אאופתא' he is saying. But isn't it written 'קאמר'? He is saying the swiftness of Abraham's actions." This teaches us.

hebrew_text: אמר רבא פשיטא לי תלוש ולבסוף חברו לענין עבודת כוכבים הוי תלוש דאמר מר המשתחוה לבית שלו אסרו ואי ס"ד הוי מחובר (דברים יב, ב) אלהיהם על ההרים ולא ההרים אלהיהם
human_translation: Rava said: obvious to me detached and ultimately one attached it, to the matter of idol worship is a detached as the Master says: One who bows to his house has rendered it forbidden And if it enters your mind is attached “Their gods, upon the high mountains” But the mountains are not their gods,
llm_translation: Rava said: It is obvious to me that if it is detached and in the end it is attached for the matter of idol worship, it is considered detached. For the Master said: One who bows down to his house, it is prohibited. And if you will say, it is considered attached, "their gods upon the mountains" and not "the mountains their gods."

hebrew_text: לענין הכשר זרעים תנאי היא דתנן הכופה קערה על הכותל בשביל שתודח הרי זה בכי יותן בשביל שלא ילקה הכותל אינו בכי יותן
human_translation: to the matter of rendering seeds susceptible is tanna’im , as we learned one who places a bowl on the wall so that will be rinsed that is under when is placed so that the wall will not be damaged, it is not under when is placed
llm_translation: Regarding the matter of valid seeds, it is a dispute of the Tannaim, as we learned: One who places a bowl on the wall so that it will drip, if his intention is for the bowl, it is considered as if he is giving it water; but if his intention is for the wall not to get wet, it is not considered as if he is giving it water.

hebrew_text: הא גופא קשיא אמרת בשביל שתודח הרי זה בכי יותן הא בשביל שיודח הכותל אין זה בכי יותן
human_translation: This itself difficult, you said: so that will be rinsed that is under when is placed so that the wall will be rinsed that is not under when is placed
llm_translation: This itself is difficult. You said that for the purpose of plastering, this is considered a permanent structure; but for the purpose of demolishing, this is not considered a permanent structure.

hebrew_text: והדר תני בשביל שלא ילקה הכותל אינו בכי יותן הא בשביל שיודח הכותל ה"ז בכי יותן
human_translation: And then teaches so that the wall will not be damaged, it is not under when is placed so that the wall will be rinsed, that is under when is placed
llm_translation: And return and teach: for the wall should not be licked, is it not because of the wall being pushed? This is for the wall to be pushed.

hebrew_text: א"ר אלעזר תברא מי ששנה זו לא שנה זו רב פפא אמר כולה חד תנא הוא הא בכותל מערה הא בכותל בנין
human_translation: Rabbi Elazar said: disjointed; who taught this did not teach that Rav Pappa said: The entire is one tanna : This in the wall of a cave, that in the wall of a building,
llm_translation: Rabbi Elazar said: "Tavra changed this, did not change this." Rav Papa said: "It is all one Tanna, here in a wall, it is a cave, here in a wall, it is a building."

hebrew_text: וה"ק הכופה קערה על הכותל בשביל שתודח ה"ז בכי יותן הא בשביל שיודח הכותל אין זה בכי יותן
human_translation: And this is saying: one who places a bowl on the wall so that will be rinsed that is under when is placed so that the wall will be rinsed that is not under when is placed
llm_translation: And the sages taught: One who places a bowl on the wall in order for the oil to drip, this is considered "bki yotan." But if one places it in order for the wall to drip, this is not considered "bki yotan."

hebrew_text: בד"א בכותל מערה אבל בכותל בנין בשביל שלא ילקה הכותל הוא דאינו בכי יותן הא בשביל שיודח הכותל ה"ז בכי יותן
human_translation: In what is this statement said? in the wall of a cave, But in the wall of a building, so that the wall will not be damaged, is when not under when is placed But so that the wall will be rinsed, that is under when is placed
llm_translation: In the case of a wall that is a cave, one may mourn there, but in the case of a wall that is a building, one may not mourn there, because the wall that is not a permanent structure, that is not considered a wall. But in the case of a wall that is a permanent structure, one may not mourn there, for that is considered a wall.

hebrew_text: בעי רבא
human_translation: Rava raises a dilemma:
llm_translation: Rava inquires.

hebrew_text: תלוש ולבסוף חברו לענין שחיטה מאי
human_translation: detached and ultimately one attached it, with regard to slaughter, what
llm_translation: "Detached and ultimately connected regarding the matter of slaughter, what is it?"

hebrew_text: תא שמע היה צור יוצא מן הכותל או שהיה קנה עולה מאליו ושחט בו שחיטתו פסולה
human_translation: Come hear was a flint emerging from a wall or a reed arising on its own and he slaughtered with it, his slaughter is not valid.
llm_translation: Come and hear: If there was a rock protruding from the wall, or if there was a reed growing from it, and one slaughtered upon it, his slaughter is invalid.

hebrew_text: הכא במאי עסקינן בכותל מערה דיקא נמי דקתני דומיא דקנה עולה מאליו ש"מ
human_translation: What are we dealing with here? with the wall of a cave is also precise as teaches similar to, a reed arising on its own, learn from it
llm_translation: Here we are dealing with what are we dealing with in a wall of a cave, and also because it teaches similarly to a reed that grows from its place.

hebrew_text: ת"ש נעץ סכין בכותל ושחט בה שחיטתו כשרה שאני סכין דלא מבטל ליה
human_translation: Come hear one embedded a knife in a wall and slaughtered with it, his slaughter is valid. a knife is different, as he does not subsume it
llm_translation: Come and hear: One who sticks a knife into a wall and slaughters with it, his slaughtering is valid, for a knife is different as it does not become nullified.

hebrew_text: ת"ש במחובר לקרקע שחיטתו כשרה דלמא פרושי קא מפרש לה מאי מחובר לקרקע סכין דלא מבטל ליה
human_translation: Come hear with attached to the ground, his slaughter is valid. Perhaps is explaining what attached to the ground? a knife, as he does not subsume it
llm_translation: Come and hear: In a case where it is attached to the ground, its slaughter is valid. Perhaps he is explaining detached from the ground. What is meant by "attached to the ground"? A knife that does not nullify it.

hebrew_text: אמר מר נעץ סכין בכותל ושחט בה שחיטתו כשרה אמר רב ענן אמר שמואל לא שנו אלא שהסכין למעלה וצואר בהמה למטה אבל סכין למטה וצואר בהמה למעלה חיישינן שמא ידרוס
human_translation: The Master said one embedded a knife in a wall and slaughtered with it, his slaughter is valid. Rav Anan says Shmuel says: taught only the knife is above and animal’s neck is below, knife is below and animal’s neck is above, we are concerned lest he press
llm_translation: The Master said: One may insert a knife into a wall and slaughter with it; his slaughtering is valid. Rav Anan said in the name of Shmuel: They only taught this when the knife is above and the animal's neck is below, but if the knife is below and the animal's neck is above, we are concerned lest it be crushed.

hebrew_text: והא קתני בין שהסכין למטה וצואר בהמה למעלה בין שהסכין למעלה וצואר בהמה למטה
human_translation: But isn’t it taught whether the knife is below and neck of the animal is above or the knife is above and neck of the animal is below?
llm_translation: And this is what was taught: whether the knife is below and the animal's neck is above, or the knife is above and the animal's neck is below.

hebrew_text: אמר רב זביד לצדדין קתני סכין למטה וצואר בהמה למעלה בתלוש סכין למעלה וצואר בהמה למטה במחובר רב פפא אמר בעופא דקליל
human_translation: Rav Zevid said: is taught disjunctively: knife is below and neck of the animal is above, when detached. knife is above and neck of the animal is below, when attached. Rav Pappa said: to a bird, which is light,
llm_translation: Rav Zevid said: "For the sides, the knife is pointed downwards, and the animal's neck upwards; for detached limbs, the knife is pointed upwards, and the animal's neck downwards; for attached limbs, Rav Papa said: 'In the case of a light bird.'"

hebrew_text: אמר רב חסדא א"ר יצחק ואמרי לה במתניתא תנא ה' דברים נאמרו בקרומית של קנה אין שוחטין בה ואין מלין בה ואין מחתכין בה בשר ואין מחצצין בה שינים ואין מקנחים בה
human_translation: Rav Ḥisda says Rabbi Yitzḥak says, and some say it was taught in a baraita : Five matters were said with regard to the stalk of a reed, One may neither slaughter with it, nor circumcise with it nor cut meat with it, nor pick teeth with it, nor wipe with it
llm_translation: Said Rav Chisda, Rabbi Yitzchak said, and some say it was taught in a baraita: Five things were stated regarding the membrane of the windpipe: one does not slaughter with it, one does not circumcise with it, one does not cut meat with it, one does not split teeth with it, and one does not clean with it.

hebrew_text: אין שוחטין בה והתניא בכל שוחטין בין בצור בין בזכוכית בין בקרומית של קנה אמר רב פפא בסימונא דאגמא
human_translation: But isn’t it taught With any one may slaughter whether with a flint, or with glass or with the stalk of a reed? Rav Pappa said: to reed in a marsh,
llm_translation: We do not slaughter in it, and it was taught in a Baraita: In any vessel one may slaughter, whether in rock, glass, or a reed vessel. Rav Pappa said: This is a sign of a pond.

hebrew_text: ואין מחתכין בה בשר רב פפא מחתך בה קרבי דגים דזיגי רבה בר רב הונא מחתך בה עופא דרכיך
human_translation: Nor cut meat with it. Rav Pappa cuts with the innards of fish, which are transparent, Rabba bar Rav Huna cuts with it a bird, which is soft
llm_translation: And one does not cut it with meat. Rav Papa cuts it with the innards of fish. Ze'agei, son of Rava Huna, cuts it with the neck of a bird.

hebrew_text: ואין מקנחין בה תיפוק ליה משום דאמר מר המקנח בדבר שהאור שולטת בו שיניו נושרות אמר רב פפא קינוח פי מכה קאמרינן:
human_translation: Nor wipe with it Derive because the Master said: One who wipes with an object that is flammable, his teeth, fall out. Rav Pappa said we are speaking wiping the opening of a wound.
llm_translation: And one does not anoint it the wound with it the ointment because the Master said: One who anoints with a substance over which light has dominion, his teeth will decay. Rav Papa said: We are speaking of the anointing of the mouth with a wound.

hebrew_text: הכל שוחטין ולעולם שוחטין: הכל שוחטין הכל בשחיטה ואפילו עוף
human_translation: All slaughter [ hakkol shoḥatin ] and one may always slaughter. All slaughter [ hakkol shoḥatin ], all of slaughter, and even a bird.
llm_translation: All slaughter and always slaughter: all slaughter all in slaughter and even bird.

hebrew_text: לעולם שוחטין מאן תנא אמר רבה רבי ישמעאל היא דתניא (דברים יב, כ) כי ירחיב ה' אלהיך את גבולך כאשר דבר לך ואמרת אוכלה בשר וגו' ר' ישמעאל אומר לא בא הכתוב אלא להתיר להם בשר תאוה
human_translation: One may always slaughter, who taught Rabba said: is Rabbi Yishmael, as it is taught “When the Lord your God shall expand your border, as He has promised you, and you shall say: I will eat flesh… Rabbi Yishmael says: The verse comes only to permit meat of desire to
llm_translation: Always slaughter who taught said Rabah Rabbi Yishmael it is as taught (Deuteronomy 12:20) "When the Lord your God enlarges your border as He has promised you, and you say, 'I will eat meat,' etc." Rabbi Yishmael says: The verse only came to permit them the desire for meat.

hebrew_text: שבתחלה נאסר להם בשר תאוה משנכנסו לארץ הותר להם בשר תאוה
human_translation: As, at the outset, meat of desire was forbidden to them, When they entered into Eretz meat of desire was permitted for them,
llm_translation: In the beginning, it was forbidden for them meat of desire. When they entered the land, it was permitted for them meat of desire.

hebrew_text: ועכשיו שגלו יכול יחזרו לאיסורן הראשון לכך שנינו לעולם שוחטין
human_translation: And now that were exiled, might they return to their initial prohibition? Therefore, we learned One may always slaughter
llm_translation: And now that they have been exiled, they may be able to return to their original prohibition. Therefore we learned: forever they slaughter.

hebrew_text: מתקיף לה רב יוסף האי לעולם שוחטין לעולם שוחטין ואוכלין מבעי ליה ועוד מעיקרא מאי טעמא איתסר משום דהוו מקרבי למשכן ולבסוף מאי טעמא אישתרו דהוו מרחקי ממשכן
human_translation: Rav Yosef objects to this. this One may always slaughter, should have One may always slaughter and eat, And furthermore, initially, what is the reason was forbidden? because they were proximate to the Tabernacle And ultimately, what is the reason was permitted? that they were distant from the Tabernacle.
llm_translation: Rav Yosef objects to him: "One should always slaughter, one should always slaughter and eat." He asks a question and furthermore, from the outset, what is the reason? It is prohibited because they were close to the Tabernacle. And in the end, what is the reason? It is permitted because they were far from the Tabernacle.

hebrew_text: וכ"ש השתא דארחיקו להו טפי
human_translation: And, all the more so now, when they are more distant
llm_translation: And all the more so now that they have distanced themselves further.

hebrew_text: אלא אמר רב יוסף רבי עקיבא היא דתניא (דברים יב, כא) כי ירחק ממך המקום אשר יבחר ה' אלהיך לשום שמו שם וזבחת מבקרך ומצאנך ר' עקיבא אומר לא בא הכתוב אלא לאסור להן בשר נחירה שבתחלה הותר להן בשר נחירה משנכנסו לארץ נאסר להן בשר נחירה
human_translation: Rather, Rav Yosef said: is Rabbi Akiva, as it is taught “If the place that the Lord your God shall choose to put His name there be too far from you, then you shall slaughter of your herd and of your flock” Rabbi Akiva says: The verse comes only to prohibit for them meat of stabbing as, initially, meat of stabbing was permitted for them. When they entered into Eretz meat of stabbing was forbidden to them,
llm_translation: Rather, Rav Yosef said, Rabbi Akiva said: as it was taught (Deuteronomy 12:21), "If the place which the Lord your God shall choose to put His name there be too far from you, then you shall slaughter of your herd and of your flock." Rabbi Akiva says: The verse only came to prohibit to them the flesh of a firstling animal. Initially, the flesh of a firstling animal was permitted to them, but once they entered the land, the flesh of a firstling animal became prohibited to them.

hebrew_text: ועכשיו שגלו יכול יחזרו להתירן הראשון לכך שנינו לעולם שוחטין:
human_translation: And now that were exiled, might are restored to their initial permitted Therefore, we learned One always slaughter
llm_translation: And now that they have been exiled, they are able to return to permit them. The first one to this we learned forever slaughter.

hebrew_text: במאי קמיפלגי רבי עקיבא סבר בשר תאוה לא איתסר כלל ר' ישמעאל סבר בשר נחירה לא אישתרי כלל
human_translation: With regard to what do they disagree? Rabbi Akiva holds: meat of desire was not forbidden at all, and Rabbi Yishmael holds: meat of stabbing was not permitted at all.
llm_translation: With what do Rabbi Akiva and Rabbi Yishmael disagree? Rabbi Akiva holds that meat of desire is not prohibited at all, while Rabbi Yishmael holds that meat of a carcass is not permitted at all.

hebrew_text: בשלמא לרבי ישמעאל היינו דכתיב (ויקרא א, ה) ושחט את בן הבקר אלא לרבי עקיבא מאי ושחט קדשים שאני
human_translation: Granted, according to Rabbi Yishmael, that is which is written “And he shall slaughter the young bull” But according to Rabbi Akiva, what “And he shall slaughter”? Sacrificial are different,
llm_translation: Regarding Rabbi Yishmael, that is as it is written (Leviticus 1:5), "And he shall slaughter the son of the herd." But according to Rabbi Akiva, what is the meaning of "he shall slaughter" with regards to holy offerings? It is different.

hebrew_text: בשלמא לרבי ישמעאל היינו דכתיב (במדבר יא, כב) הצאן ובקר ישחט להם אלא לר' עקיבא מאי הצאן ובקר ישחט להם ינחר להם מיבעי ליה נחירה שלהן זו היא שחיטתן
human_translation: Granted, according to Rabbi Yishmael, that is which is written: “Will flocks and herds be slaughtered for them” But according to Rabbi Akiva, what “Will flocks and herds be slaughtered for them”? Be stabbed for them, should have their stabbing is their slaughter.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Bashelema to Rabbi Yishmael hainu d'kativ (Bamidbar 11:22) hatzon u'vakar yishchat lahem ela l'Rabbi Akiva mai hatzon u'vakar yishchat lahem yinchur lahem miba'i leih nechirah shelahen zu hi shechitatan." English translation: "According to Rabbi Yishmael, that is as it is written (Numbers 11:22) 'shall flocks and herds be slaughtered for them,' but according to Rabbi Akiva, what is 'shall flocks and herds be slaughtered for them'? It is necessary for them their slaughtering."

hebrew_text: בשלמא לר' ישמעאל היינו דתנן השוחט ונתנבלה בידו והנוחר והמעקר פטור מלכסות אלא לר' עקיבא אמאי פטור מלכסות
human_translation: Granted, according to Rabbi Yishmael, that is which we learned One who slaughters and it became an unslaughtered carcass by his hand, and one who stabs and one who rips exempt from covering But according to Rabbi Akiva, why is one exempt from covering
llm_translation: Regarding Rabbi Yishmael, that is as we learned in a Mishnah: One who slaughters and the animal becomes a nevelah in his hand, and one who skins and one who removes the fetus are exempt from the tax. But according to Rabbi Akiva, why is one exempt from the tax?

hebrew_text: הואיל ואיתסר איתסר
human_translation: Since was forbidden, it was forbidden,
llm_translation: Since it was prohibited, it was prohibited.

hebrew_text: בשלמא לר' עקיבא דאמר בשר תאוה לא איתסר כלל היינו דכתיב (דברים יב, כב) אך כאשר יאכל את הצבי ואת האיל כן תאכלנו אלא לרבי ישמעאל צבי ואיל גופיה מי הוי שרי
human_translation: Granted, according to Rabbi Akiva, who says meat of desire was not forbidden at all, that is which is written “However, as the gazelle and as the deer is eaten, so shall you eat of it, But according to Rabbi Yishmael, were the gazelle and the deer themselves permitted
llm_translation: In accordance with Rabbi Akiva who said: "The flesh of desire is not forbidden at all," this is what is written (Deuteronomy 12:22): "Only as the gazelle and the deer are eaten, so you may eat it." But according to Rabbi Yishmael, is the gazelle and deer themselves permitted?

hebrew_text: כי אסר רחמנא בהמה דחזיא להקרבה אבל חיה דלא חזיא להקרבה לא אסר רחמנא
human_translation: When the Merciful One rendered forbidden, a domesticated animal that is fit for sacrifice. But the Merciful One did not render forbidden undomesticated animals that are not fit for sacrifice.
llm_translation: For the Merciful One prohibited an animal that is fit for offering, but an animal that is not fit for offering, the Merciful One did not prohibit.

hebrew_text: בעי רבי ירמיה אברי בשר נחירה שהכניסו ישראל עמהן לארץ מהו
human_translation: Rabbi Yirmeya raises a dilemma the limbs of meat of stabbing that the Jewish people took with them into Eretz what is
llm_translation: Rabbi Yirmiyah the son of Beser asked: "Regarding a limb of a living animal that the Israelites brought with them into the land, what is the ruling?"

hebrew_text: אימת אילימא בשבע שכבשו השתא דבר טמא אישתרי להו דכתיב (דברים ו, יא) ובתים מלאים כל טוב ואמר ר' ירמיה בר אבא אמר רב כתלי דחזירי בשר נחירה מבעיא
human_translation: When? If we say with regard to seven which they conquered now, non-kosher items were permitted for them as it is written: and houses full of all good things… and Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba says Rav says: Cuts of pig [ kotlei daḥazirei ] necessary meat stabbing
llm_translation: Talmudic text: When? If you say when they conquered the seven nations, now that a ritually impure thing is permitted to them, as it is written (Deuteronomy 6:11), "and houses full of all good." And Rabbi Yirmiyah bar Abba said in the name of Rav: The walls of the pig require scraping.

hebrew_text: אלא לאחר מכאן ואיבעית אימא לעולם בשבע שכבשו כי אשתרי להו שלל של עובדי כוכבים דידהו לא אישתרי תיקו
human_translation: Rather, thereafter. And if you wish, say Actually, with regard to seven which they conquered when was permitted for them, the spoils of gentiles, their own was not permitted. shall stand
llm_translation: Rather, from here on, and if you wish, say: "Indeed, in seven years they conquered, for they were allowed to take the spoils of the idolaters for themselves, but their own spoils were not allowed." The matter stands unresolved.

hebrew_text: אמר רבה שנית הכל שוחטין ולעולם שוחטין בכל שוחטים מאי משנית ליה
human_translation: Rabba says: You explained All slaughter, and: One may always slaughter. what do you explain One may slaughter with any
llm_translation: Rabba said again: "All slaughter, and always slaughter with all slaughterers. What is the reason for repeating it to him?"

hebrew_text: וכי תימא בין בצור בין בזכוכית בין בקרומית של קנה הא דומיא דהנך קתני אי הנך בשוחטין האי נמי בשוחטין ואי הנך בנשחטין האי נמי בנשחטין
human_translation: And if you would say Whether with a flint, or with glass or with the stalk of a reed, but isn’t taught similar to those If these to those that slaughter, this too to those that slaughter; and if those to those that are slaughtered, this too to those that are slaughtered.
llm_translation: And if you will say, whether with a rock, or with glass, or with a reed pen, is it similar to these that it teaches? If with those that are slaughtered, then also with those that are slaughtered, and if with those that are not slaughtered, then also with those that are not slaughtered.

hebrew_text: אלא אמר רבא הכל שוחטין חדא לאתויי כותי וחדא לאתויי ישראל מומר לעולם שוחטין בין ביום בין בלילה בין בראש הגג בין בראש הספינה בכל שוחטין בין בצור בין בזכוכית בין בקרומית של קנה:
human_translation: Rather, Rava said everyone [ hakkol ] slaughters. One is to include a Samaritan and one is to include a Jewish transgressor. One may always slaughter, both during the day and at night, both on a rooftop and atop a ship, One may slaughter with any Whether with a flint, or with glass or with the stalk of a reed.
llm_translation: Rather, Rava said: "One slaughters one animal to include a Kutite and one to include an apostate Israelite. One always slaughters whether by day or by night, whether on the roof or on the top of a ship, in all cases one slaughters whether with a rock, with glass, or with a reed knife."

hebrew_text: חוץ ממגל קציר והמגירה: אבוה דשמואל פגם ושדר פגם ושדר שלחו ליה כמגירה שנינו
human_translation: Except for the harvest sickle, and the saw. Shmuel’s father notch and send notch and send They sent to him We learned like a saw,
llm_translation: Except for the scroll of Esther and the Megillah: The father of Shmuel had a blemish, and he sent a blemished and sent it to him like a Megillah, as we learned.

hebrew_text: תנו רבנן
human_translation: The Sages taught
llm_translation: The Sages taught:

hebrew_text: סכין שיש בה פגימות הרבה תידון כמגירה ושאין בה אלא פגימה אחת אוגרת פסולה מסוכסכת כשרה היכי דמיא אוגרת היכי דמיא מסוכסכת א"ר אליעזר אוגרת משתי רוחות מסוכסכת מרוח אחת
human_translation: a knife in which there are several notches is considered like a saw; and in which there is only one notch, catches, unfit, entangles [ mesukhsekhet ], fit. What are the circumstances catches, what are the circumstances entangles? Rabbi Eliezer said: catches on two sides, entangles on one side.
llm_translation: A knife that has many blemishes in it shall be judged as a drawer, and if it has only one blemish, it is invalid. If it is rusted, it is valid. What is the comparison to a drawer? What is the comparison to being rusted? Rabbi Eliezer said: If it is rusted from two sides, it is valid; if it is rusted from one side, it is invalid.

hebrew_text: מאי שנא משתי רוחות דמורשא קמא מחליש ומורשא בתרא בזע מרוח אחת נמי חורפא דסכינא מחליש מורשא בזע דקאים ארישא דסכינא סוף סוף כי אזלא מחלשא כי אתא בזע כגון שהוליך ולא הביא
human_translation: What is different on two sides, where the first edge [ moresha ] compromises and the latter edge rips on one side too, the sharp of the knife compromises the edge rips that stands at the top of the knife, Ultimately, when goes it compromises when it comes it rips where he drew the knife backward and did not draw it forward.
llm_translation: What is the difference between the two winds? The first Morasha weakens, and the latter Morasha strengthens. In the case of one wind, it also sharpens the blade of the knife, weakening the former Morasha and strengthening the latter Morasha. Ultimately, when it goes away, it weakens, and when it comes, it strengthens, such as when one carries but does not bring.

hebrew_text: אמר רבא ג' מדות בסכין אוגרת לא ישחוט ואם שחט שחיטתו פסולה מסוכסכת לא ישחוט בה לכתחלה ואם שחט שחיטתו כשרה עולה ויורד בסכין שוחט בה לכתחלה
human_translation: Rava says: three types in a knife. catches, one may not slaughter and if he slaughtered, his slaughter is not valid. entangles, one may not slaughter with it ab initio ; and if he slaughtered his slaughter is valid rises and falls in knife one may slaughter with it ab initio .
llm_translation: Rava said: Three qualities in a knife prevent it from slaughtering. And if one slaughters, his slaughter is invalid. A knife with nicks should not be used for slaughtering initially. And if one slaughters, his slaughter is valid. It ascends and descends with the knife; one should slaughter with it initially.

hebrew_text: א"ל רב הונא בריה דרב נחמיה לרב אשי אמרת לן משמיה דרבא מסוכסכת פסולה והא (אמר רבא) מסוכסכת כשרה לא קשיא כאן שהוליך והביא כאן שהוליך ולא הביא
human_translation: Rav Huna, son of Rav Neḥemya, said to Rav Ashi: You said to us in the name of Rava entangles, not valid. But doesn’t Rava say: entangles, valid? not difficult. Here, where he drew the knife back and forth. There, where he drew the knife backward and did not draw it forward.
llm_translation: Rav Huna, son of Rav Nachman, said to Rav Ashi: "You said in the name of Rava: A woven Sukkah is invalid." But didn't Rava say: "A woven Sukkah is valid"? There is no contradiction - here (in one case) he erected and brought (the materials), and here (in the other case) he only erected without bringing (the materials).

hebrew_text: אמר ליה רב אחא בריה דרב אויא לרב אשי דמיא לסאסאה מאי אמר ליה מאן יהיב לן מבשריה ואכלינן
human_translation: Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Avya, said to Rav Ashi: similar to an awn [ sasa ], what said to him: Who will give us from the meat of and we will eat
llm_translation: Rav Acha, son of Rav Avya, said to Rav Ashi: "Is it similar to a sa'asah?" He said to him: "Who will give us from his flesh, and we will eat?"

hebrew_text: אמר רב חסדא מנין לבדיקת סכין מן התורה שנאמר (שמואל א יד, לד) ושחטתם בזה ואכלתם
human_translation: Rav Ḥisda says: From where that examination of a knife by Torah law? as it is stated “And slaughter with this and eat”
llm_translation: Rav Chisda said: From where do we derive the obligation of inspecting a knife from the Torah? As it is stated (1 Samuel 14:34), "And you shall slaughter with this, and you shall eat."

hebrew_text: פשיטא כיון דכי נקב טריפה בעיא בדיקה לחכם קאמרינן והאמר רבי יוחנן לא אמרו להראות סכין לחכם אלא מפני כבודו של חכם מדרבנן וקרא אסמכתא בעלמא הוא
human_translation: obvious Since were one to create a perforation tereifa , requires examination We are saying to scholar But doesn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say said to show knife to scholar only due to deference to scholar? by rabbinic law, and the verse is a mere support
llm_translation: It is obvious, since when a treifah is punctured, examination is required. To a sage we say, and Rabbi Yochanan said: They did not say to show a knife to a sage except out of respect for the sage, as it is a Rabbinic decree, and the verse is merely a support.

hebrew_text: במערבא בדקי לה בשימשא בנהרדעא בדקו לה במיא רב ששת בדק לה בריש לישניה רב אחא בר יעקב בדק לה בחוט השערה
human_translation: In the West, they examine in the sun In Neharde’a they examine with water. Rav Sheshet would examine it with the tip of his tongue. Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov would examine it with a strand of hair.
llm_translation: In the West, they examined it in Shimsa; in Nehardea, they examined it in water. Rav Sheshet examined it at the head of its sleep; Rav Acha bar Yaakov examined it with a hair thread.

hebrew_text: בסורא אמרי בישרא אכלה בישרא לבדקה אמר רב פפא צריכא בדיקה אבישרא ואטופרא (ואתלתא רוחתא)
human_translation: In Sura they say: consumes the flesh; let the flesh examine Rav Pappa said: requires examination on the flesh, and on the fingernail, and on the three sides
llm_translation: In Sura they say: In Yisra, she ate in Yisra, she should be checked. Rav Pappa said: Checking is necessary in Yisra and Atufra (and the third).

hebrew_text: אמר ליה רבינא לרב אשי אמר לן רב סמא בריה דרב משרשיא משמך דאמרת ליה משמיה דרבא צריכא בדיקה אבישרא ואטופרא ואתלתא רוחתא אמר ליה אבישרא ואטופרא אמרי ואתלתא רוחתא לא אמרי איכא דאמרי אבישרא ואטופרא ואתלתא רוחתא אמרי משמיה דרבא לא אמרי
human_translation: Ravina said to Rav Ashi: Rav Sama, son of Rav Mesharshiyya, said to us in your name that you said to him in the name of Rava: requires examination on the flesh, and on the fingernail, and on the three sides. said to On the flesh and on the fingernail I said, and on the three sides I did not say. There are who say On the flesh and on the fingernail and on the three sides I said, in the name of Rava I did not say.
llm_translation: Ravina said to Rav Ashi, "Rav Sama, son of Rav Mesharshia from Mashkach, told us in the name of Rava: 'Investigation is necessary for Avishra, Atufra, and Atalta Ruchata.'" He said to him, "Avishra and Atufra they said, but Atalta Ruchata they did not say." Some say they said Avishra, Atufra, and Atalta Ruchata in the name of Rava, while others say they did not say.

hebrew_text: רבינא ורב אחא בריה דרבא הוו יתבי קמיה דרב אשי אייתו סכין לקמיה דרב אשי לבדקה אמר ליה לרב אחא בריה דרבא בידקא בדקה אטופרא ואבישרא ואתלתא רוחתא אמר ליה יישר וכן אמר רב כהנא
human_translation: Ravina and Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, were sitting before Rav Ashi. brought a knife before Rav Ashi to examine it. said to Rav Aḥa, son of Rava: Examine it. He examined it on the fingernail, and on the flesh, and on the three sides. said to him: Well done, and Rav Kahana likewise said
llm_translation: Ravina and Rav Acha, son of Rava, were sitting before Rav Ashi. They brought a knife before Rav Ashi to inspect it. He said to Rav Acha, son of Rava, "Inspect it." He inspected it and found it to be sharp, well-polished, and of good quality. He said to him, "Well done," and so said Rav Kahana.

hebrew_text: רב יימר אמר אטופרא ואבישרא צריכא אתלתא רוחתא לא צריכא מי לא א"ר זירא אמר שמואל ליבן סכין ושחט בה שחיטתו כשרה שחידודה קודם לליבונה וקשיא לן האיכא צדדין ואמרינן בית השחיטה מרווח רווח הכא נמי בית השחיטה מרווח רווח
human_translation: Rav Yeimar said: on the fingernail and on the flesh is necessary, on the three sides is not necessary. Doesn’t Rabbi Zeira say Shmuel says: one heated a knife until white hot and slaughtered with it, his slaughter is valid, as its sharp preceded its white heat; and difficult for us: But aren’t there sides And we say: The area of the slaughter separates Here too, the area of slaughter separates
llm_translation: Rav Yeimar said: Atufra and Avishra are necessary, the third wind is not necessary. Who did not say? R' Zeira said in the name of Shmuel: "Whiten a knife and slaughter with it, its slaughter is valid, its sharpening precedes its whitening." And we have a difficulty: here there are sides, and we say, "The slaughterhouse is spacious." Here too, the slaughterhouse is spacious.

hebrew_text: אמר רב הונא בר רב קטינא אמר רבי שמעון בן לקיש שלש פגימות הן פגימת עצם בפסח פגימת אוזן בבכור פגימת מום בקדשים
human_translation: Rav Huna bar Rav Ketina says Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says there are three deficiencies The deficiency of a bone in the Paschal offering, the deficiency of an ear in a firstborn the deficiency a blemish in sacrificial
llm_translation: Rav Huna son of Rav Katina said, Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: There are three disqualifications - a bone disqualification in the Passover offering, an ear disqualification in the firstborn animal, and a blemish disqualification in consecrated items.

hebrew_text: ורב חסדא אמר אף פגימת סכין ואידך בחולין לא קא מיירי
human_translation: And Rav Ḥisda says: the deficiency of a knife as well. And the other he is not speaking with regard to non-sacred
llm_translation: And Rav Ḥisda said: Even the blemish of a knife, and the other opinion is not discussing non-sacred items.

hebrew_text: וכולן פגימתן כדי פגימת המזבח
human_translation: And all of the measure of their deficiency equivalent to deficiency the altar
llm_translation: And all of them, their blemish is like the blemish of the altar.

hebrew_text: וכמה פגימת המזבח כדי שתחגור בה צפורן
human_translation: And how much the deficiency the altar sufficient for a fingernail to be impeded on it.
llm_translation: And how much defect of the altar is necessary for it to be girded with a band.

hebrew_text: מיתיבי כמה פגימת המזבח ר' שמעון בן יוחאי אומר טפח ר"א בן יעקב אומר כזית לא קשיא הא בסידא הא באבנא
human_translation: raises an objection How much the deficiency the altar Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai says: handbreadth. Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says: olive-bulk. not difficult. This in the limestone that in the stone
llm_translation: The question was raised: How much defect in the altar is considered significant? Rabbi Shimon ben Yochai says: a handbreadth. Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov says: an olive's bulk. There is no contradiction: one refers to lime, the other to stone.

hebrew_text: אמר רב הונא האי טבחא דלא סר סכינא קמי חכם משמתינן ליה ורבא אמר מעברינן ליה ומכרזינן אבשריה דטרפה היא
human_translation: Rav Huna says: This slaughterer who did not present [ sar ] the knife before scholar, we ostracize him. And Rava says: We remove him and we proclaim about meat that he that it is tereifa .
llm_translation: Rav Huna said: This butcher who did not remove the knife before the wise one, we wait for him. And Rava said: We pass him over and announce that his meat is treif.

hebrew_text: ולא פליגי כאן בשנמצאת סכינו יפה כאן בשלא נמצאת סכינו יפה רבינא אמר היכא דלא נמצאת סכינו יפה ממסמס ליה בפרתא דאפי' לעובד כוכבים נמי לא מזדבן
human_translation: And they do not disagree. Here, in where his knife was discovered intact, There, in where his knife was discovered not intact, Ravina said: where his knife was discovered not intact, one spreads excrement on that even to a gentile it not be sold.
llm_translation: The text reads as follows: "They do not argue here when his knife is found beautiful here when his knife is not found beautiful. Ravina said: Where his knife is not found beautiful, he may smear it with cow dung, for even to a non-Jew he may not sell it."

hebrew_text: ההוא טבחא דלא סר סכינו קמיה דרבא בר חיננא שמתיה ועבריה ואכריז אבשריה דטרפה היא אקלעו מר זוטרא ורב אשי לגביה אמר להו ליעיינו רבה במלתיה דתלו ביה טפלי
human_translation: a certain slaughterer who did not present his knife before Rava bar Ḥinnana. ostracized him, and removed him and proclaimed about meat that he that it is tereifa . Mar Zutra and Rav Ashi happened before said to them: Let the Sages examine the matter of as small children are dependent upon him.
llm_translation: That butcher whose knife did not move before Rava bar Ḥananah, he died, and his limbs were broken, and his meat was declared treif. Mar Zutra and Rav Ashi encountered him. He said to them, "Let Rabba examine his case, for he is skilled in the matter of hanging dependent pieces."

hebrew_text: בדקה רב אשי לסכיניה ונמצאת יפה ואכשריה אמר ליה מר זוטרא ולא ליחוש מר לסבא א"ל שליחותיה קא עבדינן
human_translation: Rav Ashi examined his knife and it was discovered intact, and he deemed fit Mar Zutra said to And shouldn’t the Master be concerned for the elder, said to We are carrying out his agency,
llm_translation: Rav Ashi examined his knife and found it to be beautiful and valid. Mar Zutra said to him, "And should the Master not be concerned about the elderly man?" He replied, "We are fulfilling his mission."

hebrew_text: אמר רבה בר הונא שן תלושה וצפורן תלושה מותר לשחוט בה לכתחלה והא אנן תנן חוץ ממגל קציר והמגירה והשינים והצפורן מפני שהן חונקין
human_translation: Rabba bar Huna says: With a detached tooth and a detached fingernail, it is permitted to slaughter ab initio . But didn’t we learn Except for the harvest sickle, and the saw, and the teeth, and the fingernail, because they strangle?
llm_translation: Rabbah bar Huna said: A loose tooth and a loose nail, it is permitted to slaughter with them initially. But did we not learn: Except for a sickle, a reaping hook, teeth, and nails, because they choke?

hebrew_text: שן אשן לא קשיא הא בחדא הא בתרתי צפורן אצפורן לא קשיא הא בתלושה הא במחוברת:
human_translation: a tooth and a tooth not difficult: This with one That with two a fingernail and a fingernail not difficult: This with a detached That with an attached
llm_translation: Tooth, tooth, not difficult. This one in one, this one in two. A nail, a nail, not difficult. This one detached, this one attached.

hebrew_text: מתני׳ השוחט במגל קציר בדרך הליכתה ב"ש פוסלין וב"ה מכשירין ואם החליקו שיניה הרי היא כסכין:
human_translation: one who slaughters with a harvest sickle, in a forward direction, Beit Shammai deem not valid and Beit Hillel deem valid. And if they smoothed its serrations is like a knife
llm_translation: Mishnah: One who slaughters with a sickle during the harvest on the path of its walking - Beit Shammai disqualify, and Beit Hillel validate. And if its teeth became smooth, it is like a knife.

hebrew_text: גמ׳ א"ר חייא בר אבא א"ר יוחנן אף כשהכשירו ב"ה לא הכשירו אלא לטהרה מידי נבילה אבל באכילה אסורה א"ר אשי דיקא נמי דקתני ב"ש פוסלין וב"ה מכשירין ולא קתני ב"ש אוסרין וב"ה מתירין וליטעמיך ליתני ב"ש מטמאין וב"ה מטהרין אלא פוסלין ומכשירין ואוסרין ומתירין חדא מילתא היא:
human_translation: Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Even when Beit Hillel deemed valid, they deemed valid only to purify it from an unslaughtered carcass; but its consumption is prohibited. Rav Ashi said: is also precise, as teaches: Beit Shammai deem not valid and Beit Hillel deem valid, and he does not teach: Beit Shammai prohibit and Beit Hillel permit But according to your reasoning, let teach: Beit Shammai deem ritually impure and Beit Hillel deem ritually pure. Rather, deem not valid and deem valid and prohibit and permit are one matter,
llm_translation: Gemara: Rabbi Chiya bar Abba said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan, even when Beit Hillel declared it permissible, they only declared it permissible for the purpose of purification from the impurity of a carcass, but for consumption it is forbidden. Rabbi Ashi said: This is also evident, as Beit Shammai teaches that it disqualifies, and Beit Hillel declares it fit, and it does not teach that Beit Shammai prohibits while Beit Hillel permits. Rather, let Beit Shammai teach that it renders impure, and Beit Hillel declares it pure. Instead, it disqualifies and renders fit, and prohibits and permits. This is one matter.

hebrew_text: מתני׳ השוחט מתוך הטבעת ושייר בה מלא החוט על פני כולה שחיטתו כשרה ר' יוסי בר' יהודה אומר מלא חוט על פני רובה:
human_translation: one who slaughters from within the ring and left a thread breadth over the surface of its entirety his slaughter is valid. Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says: a thread breadth over the majority of the surface of
llm_translation: Mishnah: One who slaughters from within the ring and leaves in it the full length of the thread, his slaughter is valid. Rabbi Yosei, the son of Rabbi Yehuda, says: The full length of the thread over its majority.

hebrew_text: גמ׳ רב ושמואל דאמרי תרוייהו הלכה כר' יוסי בר' יהודה ואף ר' יוסי בר' יהודה לא אמר אלא בטבעת הגדולה הואיל ומקפת את כל הקנה אבל בשאר טבעות לא
human_translation: Rav and Shmuel who both say: halakha in accordance with Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda. And even Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says only with regard to the large ring, since it encircles the entire windpipe, but with regard to the rest of the rings, not
llm_translation: Gemara: Rav and Shmuel both say: the halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Yosi, the son of Rabbi Yehuda. And even Rabbi Yosi, the son of Rabbi Yehuda, only said this regarding the large ring, since it encircles the entire reed. But not with other rings.

hebrew_text: ובשאר טבעות לא והתניא רבי יוסי ברבי יהודה אומר
human_translation: And with regard to the rest of the rings, not but isn’t it taught Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says:
llm_translation: And in other rings not, and it was taught: Rabbi Yosi, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says:

hebrew_text: השוחט בשאר טבעות אע"פ שאין מקיפות את כל הקנה הואיל ומקיפות את רוב הקנה שחיטתו כשרה ומוגרמת פסולה העיד רבי חנינא בן אנטיגנוס על מוגרמת שהיא כשרה
human_translation: one who slaughters within the rest of the rings, even though they do not encircle the entire windpipe, since they encircle the majority of the windpipe his slaughter is valid. And is diverted not valid. Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus testified about is diverted that valid.
llm_translation: The one who slaughters in the remaining rings, even though they do not encompass the entire windpipe, since they encompass the majority of the windpipe, his slaughtering is valid. And if it is caused to be invalid, Rabbi Chanina ben Antigonus testified concerning that which is caused to be invalid, that it is valid.

hebrew_text: אמר רב יוסף רבי יוסי בר יהודה תרתי קאמר רב ושמואל סברי כוותיה בחדא ופליגי עליה בחדא
human_translation: Rav Yosef said: Rabbi Yosei bar Yehuda is saying two Rav and Shmuel hold in accordance with his with regard to one and disagree with him with regard to one
llm_translation: Rav Yosef said: Rabbi Yosi, son of Yehuda, said: Rav and Shmuel both hold the same opinion on one matter and disagree on another.

hebrew_text: והא לא אמר קאמרי הכי קאמר הלכה כמותו בטבעת הגדולה ואין הלכה כמותו בשאר טבעות
human_translation: But didn’t say: said only this saying: halakha in accordance with with regard to the large ring, and halakha not in accordance with his with regard to other rings
llm_translation: And isn't it said, they are saying like this, it is said: the halakha is like him in the large ring, and the halakha is not like him in the other rings.

hebrew_text: כי סליק רבי זירא אכל מוגרמת דרב ושמואל אמרי ליה לאו מאתריה דרב ושמואל את אמר להו מאן אמרה יוסף בר חייא יוסף בר חייא מכולי עלמא גמיר
human_translation: When Rabbi Zeira ascended he ate diverted which Rav and Shmuel said to Aren’t you from the place where Rav and Shmuel said to them: Who said Yosef bar Ḥiyya, Yosef bar Ḥiyya learns from everyone,
llm_translation: When Rabbi Zeira ascended, he ate from the dish of Rav and Shmuel. They said to him, "Is it not from the place of Rav and Shmuel that you are eating?" He said to them, "Who said it? Yosef bar Ḥiyya." Yosef bar Ḥiyya learned from everyone.

hebrew_text: שמע רב יוסף איקפד אמר אנא מכולי עלמא גמירנא אנא מרב יהודה גמירנא דאפי' ספיקי דגברי גריס דאמר רב יהודה אמר ר' ירמיה בר אבא ספק משמיה דרב ספק משמיה דשמואל שלשה מתירין את הבכור במקום שאין מומחה
human_translation: Rav Yosef heard was angry. He said: I learn from everyone? I learn from Rav Yehuda, that he cites even uncertainties to the men As Rav Yehuda says Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba says, uncertain in the name of Rav uncertain in the name of Shmuel: three permits firstborn in a place where there is no expert
llm_translation: Listen, Rav Yosef was concerned, saying, "I, from everyone, we have learned. I, from Rav Yehudah, we have learned, that even doubtful cases of men who are experts, as Rav Yehudah said in the name of R. Yirmiyah bar Abba, there are three who permit the firstborn in a place where there is no expert."

hebrew_text: ור' זירא לית ליה נותנין עליו חומרי המקום שיצא משם וחומרי המקום שהלך לשם
human_translation: And does Rabbi Zeira not accept impose upon him the stringencies of the place from which he emerged and the stringencies of the place to which he went?
llm_translation: And Rabbi Zeira does not have the opinion that one places upon it the stringencies of the place from which it departed and the stringencies of the place to which it went.

hebrew_text: אמר אביי הני מילי מבבל לבבל ומארץ ישראל לארץ ישראל אי נמי מארץ ישראל לבבל אבל מבבל לארץ ישראל כיון דאנן כייפינן להו עבדינן כוותייהו
human_translation: Abaye said: That statement from Babylonia to Babylonia, or from Eretz Yisrael to Eretz Yisrael, alternatively, from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia. But from Babylonia to Eretz Yisrael, Since we, are subordinate to them we act in accordance with their
llm_translation: Abaye said: These matters apply from Babylon to Babylon, and from the Land of Israel to the Land of Israel. Alternatively, from the Land of Israel to Babylon, but from Babylon to the Land of Israel, since we are subordinate to them, we act in accordance with their practices.

hebrew_text: רב אשי אמר אפילו תימא מבבל לארץ ישראל הני מילי היכא דדעתו לחזור ר' זירא אין דעתו לחזור הוה
human_translation: Rav Ashi said: Even you say from Babylonia to Eretz Yisrael, that statement where his intent is to return. Rabbi Zeira was not whose intent was to return.
llm_translation: Rav Ashi said: Even if one were to say "from Babylon to the Land of Israel," these words apply where one's intention is to return. Rabbi Zeira had no intention to return.

hebrew_text: אמר ליה אביי לרב יוסף והא רבנן דאתו ממחוזא אמרי אמר רבי זירא משמיה דרב נחמן מוגרמת כשרה א"ל נהרא נהרא ופשטיה
human_translation: Abaye said to Rav Yosef: But didn’t the Sages who came from Meḥoza say Rabbi Zeira says in the name of Rav Naḥman: is diverted valid? said to him: Each river and its course,
llm_translation: Abbaye said to Rav Yosef, "But the rabbis who came from Mehoza said in the name of Rabbi Zeira in the name of Rav Nachman: 'A gored fish is kosher.'" He said to him, "River, river, and its fins."

hebrew_text: רבי שמעון בן לקיש אכשר בחודא דכובעא קרי עליה רבי יוחנן גיסא גיסא אמר רב פפי משמיה דרבא פגע בחיטי טרפה
human_translation: Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish deemed valid at the tip of the thyroid cartilage Rabbi Yoḥanan proclaimed about greatly exaggerated Rav Pappi said in the name of Rava: encountered the arytenoid cartilage a tereifa ,
llm_translation: Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish, when he was sitting in the village of Kub'a, read upon it (the following verse): "Rabbi Yochanan, my brother-in-law, said in the name of Rav Papa in the name of Rava: He encountered a grain that was invalid."

hebrew_text: איבעיא להו פגע ונגע בהן דכתיב (מלכים א ב, כה) ויפגע בו וימת או דלמא פגע ולא נגע כדכתיב (בראשית לב, ב) ויפגעו בו מלאכי אלהים
human_translation: A dilemma was raised before encountered and touched it, as it is written: “And he encountered him and he died” or perhaps encountered but did not touch, like that which is written: “And the angels of God encountered him”
llm_translation: The question was asked to them: "He struck and he touched them," as it is written (1 Kings 1:25), "and he struck him and he died." Or perhaps, "he struck but did not touch," as it is written (Genesis 32:2), "and the angels of God met him."

hebrew_text: איתמר אמר רב פפא משמיה דרבא שייר בחיטי כשרה אמר רב אמימר בר מר ינוקא הוה קאימנא קמיה דר' חייא בריה דרב אויא ואמר לי שייר בחיטי כשרה א"ל רבינא לרב אשי אמר לי רב שמן מסוברא איקלע מר זוטרא לאתרין ודרש שייר בחיטי כשרה מר בר רב אשי אמר פגע בחיטי כשרה שייר בחיטי טרפה
human_translation: It was stated Rav Pappa said in the name of Rava: one left of the arytenoid cartilage, valid. Rav Ameimar bar Mar Yenuka said: I was standing before Rabbi Ḥiyya, son of Rav Avya, and he said to me: one left of the arytenoid cartilage, valid. Ravina said to Rav Ashi: Rav Shemen of Suvara said to me Mar Zutra happened to our place and taught: one left of the arytenoid cartilage, valid. Mar bar Rav Ashi said: one encountered the arytenoid cartilage, valid. one left of the arytenoid cartilage, a tereifa .
llm_translation: It was stated: Rav Papa said in the name of Rava, "Leaving in wheat is valid." Rav Amimar son of Mar Yenuka was standing before Rabbi Chiya, son of Rav Avya, and he said to me, "Leaving in wheat is valid." Ravina said to Rav Ashi, "Rav Shemen Mesubra encountered Mar Zutra in two places and expounded, 'Leaving in wheat is valid.'" Mar, son of Rav Ashi, said, "If it touched valid wheat, it is valid; if it touched invalid wheat, it is invalid."

hebrew_text: והלכתא משיפוי כובע ולמטה כשרה והיינו דשייר בחיטי
human_translation: And the halakha from the incline of the thyroid cartilage and below valid, and that is in that one who left of the arytenoid cartilage
llm_translation: And the halakha is in accordance with the opinion of Kovea, and below is valid. This is what remains in wheat.

hebrew_text: רב נחמן אכשר משיפוי כובע ולמטה אמר ליה רב חנן בר רב קטינא לרב נחמן כמאן לא כרבנן ולא כרבי יוסי ברבי יהודה
human_translation: Rav Naḥman deemed valid from the incline of the thyroid cartilage and below. Rav Ḥanan bar Rav Ketina said to Rav Naḥman: In accordance with whose neither in accordance with the Rabbis nor in accordance with Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda,
llm_translation: Rav Nachman permitted the removal of a hat on Shabbat, and below he said to him, Rav Hanan son of Rav Katinah said to Rav Nachman, "According to whom is this not like the opinion of the Sages nor like the opinion of Rabbi Yosei son of Rabbi Yehuda?"

hebrew_text: אמר ליה אנא לא חילק ידענא ולא בילק ידענא אנא שמעתא ידענא דא"ר חייא בר אבא א"ר יוחנן ואמרי לה א"ר אבא בר זבדא א"ר חנינא ואמרי לה א"ר יעקב בר אידי א"ר יהושע בן לוי משיפוי כובע ולמטה כשרה
human_translation: said to him: Neither do I know Ḥillek nor do I know Billek, I know the halakha , as Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says Rabbi Yoḥanan says, and some say Rabbi Abba bar Zavda says Rabbi Ḥanina says, and some say Rabbi Ya’akov bar Idi says Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says: From the incline of the thyroid cartilage and below, valid.
llm_translation: He said to him, "I do not know 'Chilak' and I do not know 'Bilak,' but I know 'Shemata.' I know that Rabbi Chiya bar Abba said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan, and some say in the name of Rabbi Abba bar Zavda in the name of Chanina, and some say in the name of Yaakov bar Idi in the name of Yehoshua ben Levi: 'From the lip of the cup is valid, and below is kosher.'"

hebrew_text: ואריב"ל מוגרמת דרבנן כשרה לרבי יוסי בר' יהודה
human_translation: And Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says: diverted of the Rabbis valid to Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda,
llm_translation: And Rib"l Mogarmet, according to the Rabbis, is valid for Rabbi Yosi son of Rabbi Yehuda.

llm_translation: And Rabbi Yosi, son of Rabbi Yehuda, is valid for Rabbi Chanina ben Antigonus.

llm_translation: It is obvious. What is the reasoning? Rabbi Yehoshua ben Antigonus is our teacher, as it is implied.

hebrew_text: ואימא ה"נ א"כ העיד עליה מיבעי ליה והלכתא כר' חנינא בן אנטיגנוס דקאי רב נחמן כוותיה

llm_translation: And say: Thus, if so, if he testified about her, what does he need? And the halakha is according to Rabbi Hanina ben Antigonus, as Rav Nahman stands in his place.

hebrew_text: אמר רב הונא אמר רב אסי מחלוקת בששחט שני שליש והגרים שליש דרבנן סברי כולה שחיטה בעינן בטבעת גדולה ורבי יוסי ברבי יהודה סבר רובו ככולו
human_translation: Rav Huna said Rav Asi says: dispute in where one cut two-thirds and diverted one-third, as the Rabbis hold we require the entire slaughter within the large ring, and Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, holds: its majority is like its entirety.
llm_translation: Rav Huna said in the name of Rav Assi: The dispute is regarding slaughtering two-thirds and the proselytes one-third. The Rabbis hold that the entire slaughtering requires a large ring, and Rabbi Yosei, the son of Rabbi Yehuda, holds that the majority is like the whole.

hebrew_text: אבל הגרים שליש ושחט שני שליש דברי הכל פסולה דכי נפקא חיותא בעינן רובא בשחיטה וליכא

hebrew_text: א"ל רב חסדא אדרבה לימא מר איפכא מחלוקת כשהגרים שליש ושחט שני שליש דרבי יוסי ברבי יהודה סבר מידי דהוה אחצי קנה פגום
human_translation: Rav Ḥisda said to On the contrary, let the Master say the opposite. dispute in when one diverted one-third and cut two-thirds as Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, holds just as it is where half the windpipe is deficient.
llm_translation: Rav Ḥisda said to him: On the contrary, let the Master say the opposite: the dispute is when the converts set aside one-third and slaughter two-thirds. Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, holds that anything that is a blemish in the windpipe is considered as if it were half the length of the esophagus.

hebrew_text: ורבנן התם מקום שחיטה הכא לאו מקום שחיטה
human_translation: And the Rabbis there, the place of slaughter, Here, not the place of slaughter.
llm_translation: And the Rabbis there said: the place of slaughter. Here, it is not the place of slaughter.

llm_translation: But if he slaughtered two-thirds and the converts one-third, the words of all are valid, for we learned in a Mishnah: The majority of one is like himself.

llm_translation: Another version says: Rav Huna said in the name of Rav Assi, the dispute regarding gerim who cut one-third and then slaughter two-thirds, Rabbi Yosi bar Rabbi Yehuda holds that anything that causes a blemish in the trachea is considered as if it were cut, and the Rabbis there (in the Mishnah) were discussing the place of slaughter, whereas here it is not the place of slaughter.

human_translation: Rav Ḥisda objects to this: Who will say to us that there the majority of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, did not teach it? llm_translation: Challenges him Rav Ḥisda: Who should say to us that that majority there is not Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, who teaches us? Perhaps Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, teaches us.
