human_translation: Rav Kahana and Rav Asi said to Rav: equivalent slaughter of animal for an animal, and of bird for a bird? Or perhaps of an animal even for a bird,
llm_translation: They said to him, Rav Kahana and Rav Asi to Rav: "For the slaughter of an animal for an animal, and a bird for a bird, or perhaps even an animal for a bird."

hebrew_text: אמר להו לא הוה בדיחנא ביה בחביבי דאישייליה
human_translation: said to them: I not intimate with my beloved that I ask him
llm_translation: He said to them: "I was not joking with him in the matter of the beloved one that he asked about."

hebrew_text: אתמר אמר רב כדי שחיטת בהמה לבהמה ועוף לעוף ושמואל אמר אפילו בהמה לעוף וכן כי אתא רבין אמר רבי יוחנן אפילו בהמה לעוף
human_translation: It was stated Rav said: equivalent slaughter of animal for an animal, and of bird for a bird. And Shmuel said: of an animal even for a bird. And likewise, when Ravin came Rabbi Yoḥanan said: of an animal even for a bird.
llm_translation: It was stated: Rav said, "For the sake of slaughtering an animal for an animal, and a bird for a bird." And Shmuel said, "Even an animal for a bird." And similarly, when Ravin came, Rabbi Yochanan said, "Even an animal for a bird."

hebrew_text: רבי חנניא אמר כדי שיביא בהמה אחרת וישחוט יביא אפילו מעלמא נתת דבריך לשיעורין
human_translation: Rabbi Ḥananya said: equivalent which one can bring another animal and slaughter one can bring even from anywhere else, you have rendered your statement to circumstances;
llm_translation: Rabbi Chananya said: "In order that he may bring another animal and slaughter it, he should bring even from the hidden things you have given for measurements."

hebrew_text: אמר רב פפא עומדת להטיל איכא בינייהו
human_translation: Rav Pappa said: between standing to cast
llm_translation: Rav Papa said: "It stands to cast, there is a difference between them."

hebrew_text: אמרי במערבא משמיה דרבי יוסי ברבי חנינא כדי שיגביהנה וירביצנה וישחוט דקה לדקה וגסה לגסה
human_translation: They said in the West, in the name of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina: equivalent which he can lift and lay it and slaughter a small to a small And a large to a large
llm_translation: They said in the West in the name of Rabbi Yossi, son of Rabbi Chanina: in order that he may lift it up, lay it down, and slaughter it fine by fine and thick by thick.

hebrew_text: אמר רבא השוחט בסכין רעה אפילו כל היום כולו כשרה
human_translation: Rava said: one who slaughters with a blunt knife, even the entire day, valid
llm_translation: Rava said: One who slaughters with a faulty knife, even the entire day, it is valid.

hebrew_text: בעי רבא שהיות מהו שיצטרפו
human_translation: Rava raises a dilemma: interruptions what is they join
llm_translation: Rava inquired: What is the case in which they should join together?

hebrew_text: ותפשוט לה מדידיה התם בדלא שהה
human_translation: And let resolve from his own There, where there was no interruption,
llm_translation: And she shall remove her garment there, because she did not stay.

hebrew_text: בעי רב הונא בריה דרב נתן שהה במיעוט סימנים מהו תיקו:
human_translation: Rav Huna, son of Rav Natan, raises a dilemma: interrupted minority of the simanim , what is shall stand
llm_translation: Rav Huna, son of Rav Natan, asked: "If one paused in the minority of signs, what is the resolution?"

hebrew_text: ר"ש אומר אם שהה [כדי ביקור]: מאי כדי ביקור אמר רבי יוחנן כדי ביקרו של חכם אם כן נתת דבריך לשיעורין אלא כדי ביקור טבח חכם:
human_translation: Rabbi Shimon says: if he interrupted What equivalent an examination? Rabbi Yoḥanan said: equivalent an examination by a Sage If so, you have rendered your statement to circumstances, Rather, equivalent an examination a slaughterer a Sage.
llm_translation: Rabbi Shimon says: If one delayed for the purpose of visiting, what is "for the purpose of visiting"? Rabbi Yochanan said: For the purpose of visiting a sage. If so, you have given your words for teaching! Rather, "for the purpose of visiting a butcher who is a sage."

hebrew_text: מתני׳ שחט את הוושט ופסק את הגרגרת או פסק את הגרגרת ואח"כ שחט את הוושט או שחט אחד מהן והמתין לה עד שמתה או שהחליד את הסכין תחת השני ופסקו רבי ישבב אומר נבלה ר"ע אומר טרפה
human_translation: one cut the gullet and he severed the windpipe or one severed the windpipe and thereafter cut the gullet, or one cut one of and waited until died, or concealed the knife beneath the second and severed it Rabbi Yeshevav says: an unslaughtered carcass Rabbi Akiva says: a tereifa ,
llm_translation: Mishnah: One slaughtered the esophagus and then cut the windpipe, or cut the windpipe and then slaughtered the esophagus, or slaughtered one of them and waited for it until it died, or he dulled the knife beneath the second cut, Rabbi Yishmael says it is a nevelah, Rabbi Akiva says it is a treifah.

hebrew_text: כלל אמר רבי ישבב משום רבי יהושע כל שנפסלה בשחיטתה נבלה כל ששחיטתה כראוי ודבר אחר גרם לה ליפסל טרפה והודה לו רבי עקיבא:
human_translation: Rabbi Yeshevav stated a principle in the name of Rabbi Yehoshua: Any that was rendered unfit during its slaughter is an unslaughtered carcass; any whose slaughter was properly and another matter caused it to become unfit is a tereifa . And Rabbi Akiva conceded to his
llm_translation: Principle: Rabbi Yeshivav said in the name of Rabbi Yehoshua, anything that became disqualified in its slaughter is considered a nevelah. Anything whose slaughter was done properly, and something else caused it to become disqualified, it is considered a treifah. And Rabbi Akiva agreed with him.

hebrew_text: גמ׳ שחט את הוושט וכו' והודה לו רבי עקיבא ורמינהי אלו טרפות בבהמה
human_translation: one cut the gullet…and Rabbi Akiva conceded to his And raises a contradiction These tereifot in an animal:
llm_translation: Gemara: Shachat et hawasht, etc. Ve'hodah lo Rabbi Akiva u'raminah: Elu treifot bebehema.

hebrew_text: נקובת הוושט ופסוקת הגרגרת
human_translation: a perforated gullet, or a severed windpipe.
llm_translation: The perforated and the severed.

hebrew_text: אמר רבא לא קשיא כאן ששחט ולבסוף פסק כאן שפסק ולבסוף שחט שחט ולבסוף פסק נפסלת בשחיטה היא פסק ולבסוף שחט כי דבר אחר גרם לה ליפסל דמיא
human_translation: Rava said: not difficult. Here, where one cut and ultimately severed There, where he severed and ultimately cut cut and ultimately severed was rendered unfit during its slaughter; he severed and ultimately cut as another matter caused to become unfit;
llm_translation: Rava said: It is not difficult here, where he slaughtered and ultimately he ceased, here where he ceased and ultimately he slaughtered, he slaughtered and ultimately he ceased, it is invalidated by the slaughter; it ceased and ultimately he slaughtered, for another matter caused it to be invalidated, it is similar to slaughter.

hebrew_text: איתיביה רב אחא בר הונא לרבא שחט את הוושט ופסק את הגרגרת פסק את הגרגרת ואחר כך שחט את הוושט נבלה
human_translation: Rav Aḥa bar Huna raised an objection to Rava cut the gullet and severed the windpipe, severed the windpipe and cut the gullet thereafter, an unslaughtered carcass.
llm_translation: Rav Acha bar Huna raised an objection to Rava: If one slaughtered the esophagus and then cut the windpipe, or cut the windpipe and then slaughtered the esophagus, the animal is considered a nevelah.

hebrew_text: אימא וכבר שחט את הוושט מעיקרא
human_translation: Say and had already cut the gullet at the outset.
llm_translation: Say, and already he slaughtered the vashet from the outset.

hebrew_text: אמר ליה שתי תשובות בדבר חדא דהיינו קמייתא ועוד הא תנן ואח"כ
human_translation: said to him: two refutations of the statement, One that is the first And furthermore, didn’t we learn thereafter,
llm_translation: He said to him, two answers in one matter, that is the first, and furthermore, as we learned, and afterwards.

hebrew_text: אלא אמר רבא אלו אסורות קתני ויש מהן נבלות ויש מהן טרפות
human_translation: Rather, Rava said: teaches These forbidden; and there are of them unslaughtered carcasses, and there are of them tereifot .
llm_translation: Rather, Rava said: "These are the forbidden ones," as it is taught, and some of them are carcasses, and some of them are torn.

hebrew_text: וליחשוב נמי דחזקיה דאמר חזקיה עשאה גיסטרא נבלה וליחשוב נמי דרבי אלעזר דאמר רבי אלעזר נטלה ירך וחלל שלה נבלה
human_translation: let consider of Ḥizkiyya as well, as Ḥizkiyya says: one rendered a shard an unslaughtered carcass And let consider of Rabbi Elazar as well, as Rabbi Elazar said: the thigh, was removed and its recess an unslaughtered carcass.
llm_translation: And let us also consider the opinion of Hezekiah, for Hezekiah said: He made it a carcass. And let us also consider the opinion of Rabbi Elazar, for Rabbi Elazar said: He took its thigh and its cavity became a carcass.

hebrew_text: כי קתני נבלה דלא מטמאה מחיים אבל נבלה דמטמאה מחיים לא קתני
human_translation: When teaches an unslaughtered carcass, does not impart impurity while alive. But does not teach an unslaughtered carcass imparts impurity while alive,
llm_translation: For it taught: A carcass that does not convey impurity from being alive, but a carcass that does convey impurity from being alive, it did not teach.

hebrew_text: רבי שמעון בן לקיש אמר כאן ששחט במקום חתך כאן ששחט שלא במקום חתך שחט במקום חתך נפסלה בשחיטה היא שלא במקום חתך כי דבר אחר גרם לה ליפסל דמיא
human_translation: Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: Here, where one cut in place cut There, where he cut not in place cut one cut in place cut was rendered unfit during its slaughter not in place cut like another matter caused to become unfit.
llm_translation: Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: Here, where he slaughtered in the place of cutting, here, where he slaughtered not in the place of cutting, he slaughtered in the place of cutting, it is disqualified in the slaughter that was not in the place of cutting, for another matter caused it to be disqualified, it is similar.

hebrew_text: ומי אמר רבי שמעון בן לקיש הכי והאמר רבי שמעון בן לקיש שחט את הקנה ואח"כ ניקבה הריאה כשרה אלמא כמאן דמנחא בדיקולא דמיא הכא נמי כמאן דמנחא בדיקולא דמיא
human_translation: And did Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish say this, But doesn’t Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish say: cut the windpipe and the lung was perforated thereafter fit Apparently, is like that is placed in a basket; Here too, like that is placed in a basket
llm_translation: And did Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish say so? But didn't Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish say: If one slaughtered the trachea and then pierced the lung, it is valid. This implies that it is like one who places a vessel over a flame, here too it is like one who places a vessel over a flame.

hebrew_text: אלא אמר רבי חייא בר אבא אמר רבי יוחנן לא קשיא כאן קודם חזרה כאן לאחר חזרה ומשנה לא זזה ממקומה
human_translation: Rather, Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: not difficult. There before retraction Here, after retraction And a mishna does not move from its place.
llm_translation: Rather, Rabbi Chiya bar Abba said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: It is not difficult. Here, before it turned back, here, after it turned back, and the Mishnah does not move from its place.

hebrew_text: גופא אמר רבי שמעון בן לקיש שחט את הקנה ואח"כ ניקבה הריאה כשרה אמר רבא לא אמר רבי שמעון בן לקיש אלא בריאה הואיל וחיי ריאה תלויה בקנה אבל בבני מעיים לא
human_translation: the itself Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says: cut the windpipe and the lung was perforated thereafter fit Rava said: Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish states only with regard to a lung, since the function of the lung is dependent upon the windpipe. But with regard to innards no,
llm_translation: The text: "Gufa, Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: If one slaughtered the trachea and then perforated the lung, it is valid. Rava said: Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish did not say this, rather, it is only valid when the life of the lung is dependent on the trachea, but not when it is dependent on the intestines."

hebrew_text: מתקיף לה רבי זירא מאחר שנולדו בה סימני טרפה התרת מה לי בריאה מה לי בבני מעיים

llm_translation: And then Rabbi Zeira inquired: Rabbi Zeira asked, "If the intestines were perforated from one sign to another, what is the law regarding whether the first sign combines with the second sign for the purification of a carcass or not?"

human_translation: Does the first siman join with the second siman to purify the animal from an unslaughtered carcass or not?
llm_translation: Who combines the first sign with the second sign for purification from any carcass or not.

hebrew_text: א"ל רב אחא בר רב לרבינא דלמא לעולם לא הדר ביה ור' זירא לדבריו דרבא קאמר וליה לא סבירא ליה

llm_translation: Rav Acha son of Rav said to Ravina: Perhaps he did not actually retract, and Rabbi Zeira according to Rava's words is saying, "And to him he does not agree."

hebrew_text: אמר רב אחא בר יעקב שמע מינה מדר' שמעון בן לקיש מזמנין ישראל על בני מעיים ואין מזמנין עובדי כוכבים על בני מעיים
human_translation: Rav Aḥa bar Yaakov said: Learn from of Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish one may invite Jews innards but one may not invite gentiles innards
llm_translation: Rav Acha bar Yaakov said: Learn from what Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: Israelites are invited to the sons of Ma'ayim, but idolaters are not invited to the sons of Ma'ayim.

hebrew_text: מאי טעמא ישראל דבשחיטה תליא מילתא כיון דאיכא שחיטה מעלייתא אישתרי להו עובדי כוכבים דבנחירה סגי להו ובמיתה תליא מילתא הני כאבר מן החי דמו
human_translation: What is the reason? Jews the matter is dependent upon slaughter. Once there is full-fledged slaughter are permitted to them gentiles, for whom stabbing is sufficient the matter is dependent upon death. these considered like a limb from a living
llm_translation: What is the reason that Israelites, regarding slaughter, the matter is dependent? Since there is slaughter, it is permitted for them, idolaters in Nakhireh, it suffices for them, and regarding death, the matter is dependent. These are like a limb from a living creature.

hebrew_text: אמר רב פפא הוה יתיבנא קמיה דרב אחא בר יעקב ובעי דאימא ליה מי איכא מידי דלישראל שרי ולעובד כוכבים אסור ולא אמרי ליה דאמינא הא טעמא קאמר
human_translation: Rav Pappa said: I was sitting before Rav Aḥa bar Yaakov and I sought to say to him Is there anything that is permitted for a Jew but prohibited for a gentile? But I did not say to him, as I said Didn’t he say a reason
llm_translation: Rav Papa said: I was sitting before Rav Acha bar Yaakov, and I wanted to say to him, "Is there anything that is permitted for a Jew but forbidden for a non-Jew?" And they did not say to me, for I thought that this is what he meant.

hebrew_text: תניא דלא כרב אחא בר יעקב הרוצה לאכול מבהמה קודם שתצא נפשה חותך כזית בשר מבית השחיטה ומולחו יפה יפה ומדיחו יפה יפה וממתין לה עד שתצא נפשה ואוכלו אחד עובד כוכבים ואחד ישראל מותרין בו
human_translation: It is taught not in accordance with Rav Aḥa bar Yaakov: One who seeks to eat from an animal before its soul departs may cut an olive-bulk of meat from the area of the slaughter, and salt it very well, and rinse it very well and wait until the soul departs, and eat it. permitted both a gentile and a Jew to it.
llm_translation: It was taught: Not like Rav Acha bar Yaakov. One who desires to eat from an animal before its soul departs, he cuts a olive-sized piece of meat from the area of slaughter, salts it well, rinses it well, and waits until its soul departs, and then one may eat it. Both a non-Jew and a Jew are permitted in this case.

hebrew_text: מסייע ליה לרב אידי בר אבין דאמר רב אידי בר אבין אמר ר' יצחק בר אשיאן הרוצה שיבריא חותך כזית בשר מבית שחיטתה של בהמה ומולחו יפה יפה ומדיחו יפה יפה וממתין לה עד שתצא נפשה אחד עובד כוכבים ואחד ישראל מותרין בו:
human_translation: supports Rav Idi bar Avin, as Rav Idi bar Avin says Rav Yitzḥak bar Ashyan says: One who seeks to recuperate cut an olive-bulk of meat from the area of slaughter, of an animal, and salt it very well, and rinse it very well, and wait until the soul departs, permitted both a gentile and a Jew to it.
llm_translation: Assisting him, Rav Idi bar Avin, for Rav Idi bar Avin said, Rabbi Yitzchak bar Ashian said: One who desires that it should heal, cuts off an olive-sized piece of meat from the area of the animal's slaughter, salts it well, rinses it well, and waits until its life departs. Both a non-Jew and a Jew are permitted in this.

hebrew_text: מתני׳ השוחט בהמה חיה ועוף ולא יצא מהן דם כשרים ונאכלין בידים מסואבות לפי שלא הוכשרו בדם ר' שמעון אומר הוכשרו בשחיטה:
human_translation: one who slaughters a domesticated animal, an undomesticated animal, or a bird, and blood did not emerge from them permitted and they may be eaten with ritually impure [ mesoavot ] hands, because they were not rendered susceptible with blood, Rabbi Shimon says: They were rendered susceptible by means of slaughter
llm_translation: Mishnah: One who slaughters a domestic animal, wild animal, or bird, and their blood did not emerge, they are kosher and may be eaten with unwashed hands, because they were not rendered fit through the blood. Rabbi Shimon says: They were rendered fit through the slaughter.

hebrew_text: גמ׳ טעמא דלא יצא מהן דם הא יצא מהן דם אין נאכלים בידים מסואבות אמאי ידים שניות הן ואין שני עושה שלישי בחולין
human_translation: reason that blood did not emerge from but blood emerged from them they not be eaten with ritually impure hands. Why hands are second-degree and second-degree cannot impart third-degree non-sacred
llm_translation: Gemara: The reason for the ruling that the blood of sacrifices does not exempt the meat from being eaten with bread is because the blood has already exited the animal. Why, then, are they not eaten with unwashed hands? Because unwashed hands are considered secondary, and two do not make a third in mundane matters.

hebrew_text: וממאי דבחולין עסקינן דקתני חיה דאילו קדשים חיה בקדשים מי איכא ותו אי בקדשים כי לא יצא מהן דם כשרה הוא עצמו לדם הוא צריך

Furthermore, if in holy matters, when its blood has not exited from it, it is considered fit for consumption, it itself requires blood.

llm_translation: And furthermore, with regards to consecrated items, when blood emerges from them, what about non-kosher blood? And Rabbi Chiya bar Abba said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: From where do we derive that the blood of consecrated items that is not kosher? As it is stated (Deuteronomy 12:16), "You shall pour it out on the ground like water" - blood that is poured out like water is kosher, blood that is not poured out like water is not kosher.

hebrew_text: ותו אי בקדשים כי לא יצא מהם דם לא מתכשרי ליתכשרי בחיבת הקדש דקיי"ל חיבת הקדש מכשרתן

human_translation: As we learned On that day, Rabbi Akiva taught: “And every earthenware vessel it shall be impure, it is not stated: is impure [ tameh ]; rather, “it shall be impure [ yitma ]” to transmit impurity to other This teaches about a loaf second-degree that it renders non-sacred third-degree
llm_translation: As we learned in it, on that day, Rabbi Akiva expounded: "And all earthenware vessels, etc." (Leviticus 11:33) - impure, impure was not stated, rather impure to make others impure. This teaches about a loaf of second tithe that renders a third one as common.

human_translation: Rabbi Elazar said Rabbi Hoshaya said Here we are dealing with non-sacred that were prepared on the purity of sacrificial And not in accordance with Rabbi Yehoshua, as it is taught Rabbi Eliezer says: One who eats food first-degree first-degree second-degree second-degree third-degree third-degree
llm_translation: Said Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Hoshea: Here in Hullin, we are dealing with cases that were done in the manner of the holy, and not like Rabbi Yehoshua. For it was taught: Rabbi Eliezer says, "One who eats, eats first; one who drinks, drinks first; one who eats second, eats second; one who drinks second, drinks second; one who eats third, eats third; one who drinks third, drinks third."

llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: One who slaughters an animal and sprinkles its blood on the hyssop, Rabbi says it is valid, Rabbi Chiya says it is invalid.

hebrew_text: א"ר אושעיא מאחר שרבי אומר הוכשר ור' חייא אומר תולין אנו על מי נסמוך באו ונסמוך על דברי ר"ש שהיה ר"ש אומר שחיטה מכשרת ולא דם
human_translation: Rabbi Oshaya said: Since Rabbi says rendered susceptible and Rabbi Ḥiyya says one places in abeyance, on whom shall we rely? Come and let us rely on the statement of Rabbi Shimon, as Rabbi Shimon would say: slaughter renders susceptible, and not blood.
llm_translation: Rabbi Oshaya said: After Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi said, "It is valid," and Rabbi Chiya said, "We are suspended," upon whom shall we rely? Let us come and rely on the words of Rabbi Shimon, for Rabbi Shimon used to say that slaughter is effective, but not the blood.

hebrew_text: אמר רב פפא הכל מודים היכא דאיתיה לדם מתחלה ועד סוף כולי עלמא לא פליגי דמכשיר כי פליגי בנתקנח הדם בין סימן לסימן רבי סבר ישנה לשחיטה מתחלה ועד סוף והאי דם שחיטה הוא
human_translation: Rav Pappa said Everyone, agrees where there is blood from beginning to end, everyone, agrees that renders susceptible When they disagree where the blood is wiped between siman and siman . Rabbi holds slaughter is from beginning to end and this blood is blood of slaughter.
llm_translation: Rav Pappa said: Everyone agrees that where the blood came from the beginning to the end, everyone does not disagree that it is valid. When they disagree is when the blood was collected in a vessel from one mark to another. Rabbi holds that it is fit for slaughter from the beginning to the end, and this blood is considered slaughter.

hebrew_text: רבי חייא סבר אינה לשחיטה אלא בסוף והאי דם מכה הוא ומאי תולין תולין הדבר עד גמר שחיטה אי איתיה לדם בסוף שחיטה מכשיר ואי לא לא מכשיר
human_translation: Rabbi Ḥiyya holds slaughter is only the conclusion and this is blood of a wound, And what one places in abeyance? one places in abeyance until conclusion of slaughter. If there is blood at the conclusion of the slaughter renders susceptible and if not, does not render susceptible
llm_translation: Rabbi Chiya holds: It is not considered for slaughter except at the end, and this act of bloodletting is considered a wound. And what is the meaning of "hanging"? It means hanging the matter until the completion of the slaughter. If it the blood comes at the end of the slaughter, it is valid; and if not, it is not valid.

hebrew_text: ומאי באו ונסמוך על דברי ר"ש לר"ש לא מכשיר לרבי חייא מכשיר
human_translation: And what Come and let us rely on the statement of Rabbi Shimon? to Rabbi Shimon does not render susceptible to Rabbi Ḥiyya renders susceptible
llm_translation: And what is the meaning of "And they came and relied on the words of Rabbi Shimon"? According to Rabbi Shimon, it is not valid; according to Rabbi Chiya, it is valid.

hebrew_text: בנתקנח מיהו אשוו להדדי מר לא מכשיר ומר לא מכשיר הוה ליה רבי חד ואין דבריו של אחד במקום שנים
human_translation: where is wiped in any event, correspond to each other: Sage does not render susceptible and Sage does not render susceptible Rabbi is one and the statement of one has no in a place two
llm_translation: When they are both fixed, one master does not validate the other, and the other does not validate the master. Rabbi had one opinion, and the words of one do not stand in the place of two.

hebrew_text: רב אשי אמר תולין לעולם משמע ונתקנח לר' חייא ספוקי מספקא ליה אי ישנה לשחיטה מתחלה ועד סוף או אינה לשחיטה אלא בסוף ומאי תולין לא אוכלין ולא שורפין
human_translation: Rav Ashi said One places in abeyance, indicates forever. And wiped Rabbi Ḥiyya is uncertain whether slaughter is from beginning to end or whether slaughter is only conclusion And what one places in abeyance? one may neither eat nor may one burn
llm_translation: Rav Ashi said: "We always hang the animal by its tail, and we ask Rabbi Chiya: Is it doubtful for him whether it is fit for slaughter from the beginning to the end, or is it fit for slaughter only at the end? And what is the hanging? Neither eating nor burning."

hebrew_text: ומאי באו ונסמוך על דברי ר"ש לר"ש לא מכשיר לרבי חייא ספיקא לענין שריפה מיהו שוו להדדי מר לא שרפיה ומר לא שרפיה
human_translation: And what Come and let us rely on the statement of Rabbi Shimon? to Rabbi Shimon does not render susceptible to Rabbi Ḥiyya, uncertainty to the matter of burning, in any event, correspond to each other: Sage, does not burn and Sage, does not burn
llm_translation: And what does it come to connect to the words of Rabbi Shimon? According to Rabbi Shimon, it is not valid; according to Rabbi Chiya, it is a doubt regarding the matter of burning, however, they are equal to each other - one Master did not burn it, and the other Master did not burn it.

hebrew_text: הוה ליה רבי חד ואין דבריו של אחד במקום שנים והכי קאמר כגון זאת תולין לא אוכלין ולא שורפין
human_translation: Rabbi is one and the statement of one has no in a place two And this is saying: such as this, one places in abeyance; one may neither eat nor burn
llm_translation: There was to him Rabbi one and his words of one in place of two, and thus he said: "Such as this, hanging not eating and not burning."

hebrew_text: בעי ר"ש בן לקיש צריד של מנחות מונין בו ראשון ושני או אין מונין בו ראשון ושני כי מהניא חבת הקדש לאפסולי גופיה למימנא ביה ראשון ושני לא או דלמא לא שנא
human_translation: Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish raises a dilemma: portion of meal offerings, one count first-degree and second-degree or not count first-degree and second-degree When regard for sanctity is effective to disqualify itself, but to count first-degree and second-degree not Or perhaps is no difference
llm_translation: Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish asked: Is the leftover of meal-offerings counted as the first and second offerings, or is it not counted as the first and second? For is the sanctity of the holy items beneficial to disqualify themselves, to count it as the first and second, or not? Or perhaps it is not different.

hebrew_text: א"ר אלעזר ת"ש (ויקרא יא, לד) מכל האוכל אשר יאכל וגו' אוכל הבא במים הוכשר אוכל שאינו בא במים לא הוכשר
human_translation: Rabbi Elazar said: Come hear “Of all food that may be eaten, Food that comes into water is rendered susceptible food that does not come into water is not rendered susceptible
llm_translation: Rabbi Elazar said: Come and hear (Leviticus 11:34) "Of all food which may be eaten, etc." - Food that comes into contact with water is rendered fit for consumption, while food that does not come into contact with water is not rendered fit for consumption.

hebrew_text: אטו רבי שמעון בן לקיש לית ליה אוכל הבא במים רבי שמעון בן לקיש הכי קמיבעיא ליה חבת הקדש כאוכל הבא במים דמי או לא
human_translation: Is that to say Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish does not have food that comes into water This is the dilemma Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish is raising: regard for sanctity like food that comes into water, or no,
llm_translation: So, does Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish not have the case of "ochel haba b'mayim" (food that comes into contact with water)? Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish thus raises the question: Is the sanctified offering like "ochel haba b'mayim" or not?

hebrew_text: רבי אלעזר נמי מיתורי קראי קאמר מכדי כתיב (ויקרא יא, לח) וכי יותן מים על זרע מכל האוכל אשר יאכל למה לי
human_translation: Rabbi Elazar, too is stating from the extraneous of the verses. Since it is written: “But when water is placed upon the seed, why do I “Of all food which may be eaten,
llm_translation: Rabbi Elazar also from Mitorai said: From where do we derive this? As it is written (Leviticus 11:38): "And if water be put upon seed, and any part of their carcass fall thereon, it shall be unclean unto you."

hebrew_text: לאו למעוטי חיבת הקדש לא חד בטומאת מת וחד בטומאת שרץ
human_translation: not to exclude regard for sanctity? No, One impurity corpse, and one impurity a creeping animal.
llm_translation: Not to exclude the obligation of the holy, not one regarding the impurity of a corpse and one regarding the impurity of a creeping thing.

hebrew_text: וצריכי דאי אשמעינן טומאת מת התם הוא דבעי הכשר משום דלא מטמא בכעדשה אבל שרץ דמטמא בכעדשה אימא לא ליבעי הכשר
human_translation: And are necessary, as had taught us impurity a corpse, it is there requires rendered susceptible due to that a lentil-bulk does not render impure. But a creeping animal, as renders impure a lentil-bulk, say does not require rendered susceptible
llm_translation: And it is necessary, for if we were to hear about the impurity of a corpse, there it is required to permit it because it does not impart impurity through a barrier. But a creeping creature, which imparts impurity through a barrier, one might say that it does not require permission.

hebrew_text: ואי אשמעינן שרץ משום דלא מטמא טומאת שבעה אבל מת דמטמא טומאת שבעה אימא לא ליבעי הכשר צריכא
human_translation: And had taught us a creeping animal, due to that does not render impure impurity seven But a corpse, which renders impure impurity seven say does not require rendered susceptible it is necessary
llm_translation: And if we were to say that a sheretz does not transmit impurity of seven days because it does not transmit impurity of seven days, but a corpse, which does transmit impurity of seven days, if you say it does not require the water of the red heifer, it is necessary.

hebrew_text: מתיב רב יוסף רבי שמעון אומר הוכשרו בשחיטה הוכשרו ואפילו למימני בהו ראשון ושני
human_translation: Rav Yosef raises an objection Rabbi Shimon says: They were rendered susceptible by means of slaughter they were rendered susceptible and even to count first-degree and second-degree
llm_translation: Challenged Rav Yosef: Rabbi Shimon says, "If they were deemed fit for slaughter, they are fit, even to count them as the first and second."

hebrew_text: אמאי והא לאו אוכל הבא במים הוא א"ל אביי עשאוהו כהכשר מים מדרבנן
human_translation: Why but not food that comes into water? Abaye said to accorded like of susceptibility rendered water, by rabbinic law.
llm_translation: Why? Isn't it that it is not considered food that comes in contact with water? Abaye said to him: He made it like water that is fit according to rabbinic law.

hebrew_text: אמר רבי זירא ת"ש הבוצר לגת שמאי אומר הוכשר הלל אומר לא הוכשר ושתיק ליה הלל לשמאי אמאי והא לאו אוכל הבא במים הוא אמר ליה אביי עשאוהו כהכשר מים מדרבנן
human_translation: Rabbi Zeira said: Come hear one who harvests to the winepress, Shammai says: rendered susceptible Hillel says: not rendered susceptible and ultimately, Hillel was silent to Shammai, Why but are not food that comes into water? Abaye said to accorded like of susceptibility rendered water, by rabbinic law,
llm_translation: Rabbi Zeira said: Come and hear! The one who harvests grapes for the winepress. Shamai says: It is fit. Hillel says: It is not fit. And Hillel remained silent to Shamai. Hillel said to Shamai: Why? But is it not that it is not considered food that comes into contact with water? Abaye said to him: He made it like fit water, according to rabbinic law.

hebrew_text: א"ל רב יוסף אמינא לך אנא הוכשרו בשחיטה ואת אמרת לי עשאוהו כהכשר מים ואמר לך רבי זירא ואמרת ליה עשאוהו כהכשר מים לר"ש בן לקיש נמי עשאוהו כהכשר מים
human_translation: Rav Yosef said to I said to you They were rendered susceptible by means of slaughter and you said to me: accorded like of susceptibility rendered water. And Rabbi Zeira said to you and you said to him: accorded like of susceptibility rendered water. also Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish accorded like of susceptibility rendered water,
llm_translation: Rav Yosef said to him: I say to you, I was trained in ritual slaughter, and you told me to do it like the training of water. And you said to Rabbi Zeira: And you told him to do it like the training of water. To Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish too, you told him to do it like the training of water.

hebrew_text: אמר ליה אטו ר' שמעון בן לקיש לתלות קמיבעיא ליה כי קא מיבעיא ליה לשרוף
human_translation: said to Is that to say Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish was raising a dilemma placing in abeyance, When raises the dilemma to burn
llm_translation: He said to him: "Is it so, Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish, that you are inquiring to hang when you should be inquiring to burn?"

hebrew_text: מכלל דחיבת הקדש דאורייתא מנא לן אילימא מדכתיב (ויקרא ז, יט) והבשר אשר יגע בכל טמא האי בשר דאתכשר במאי
human_translation: by inference that regard for sanctity by Torah law, From where do we If we say from which is written: “And the flesh that touches any impure This flesh that was rendered susceptible by what means
llm_translation: From the principle that the obligation of sanctity is from the Torah, how do we derive it? If you say, from what is written (Leviticus 7:19), "And the flesh that touches any unclean thing shall not be eaten," this flesh that becomes permissible, with what?

hebrew_text: אילימא דאתכשר בדם והאמר רבי חייא בר אבא א"ר יוחנן מנין לדם קדשים שאינו מכשיר שנאמר לא תאכלנו על הארץ תשפכנו כמים דם הנשפך כמים מכשיר שאינו נשפך כמים אינו מכשיר
human_translation: If we say that it was rendered susceptible by means of blood But doesn’t Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba say Rabbi Yoḥanan says: From where with regard to blood of sacrificial that it does not render susceptible as it is stated: “You shall not eat it; you shall pour it upon the earth like water” Blood which is poured like water renders susceptible which is not poured like water does not render susceptible
llm_translation: The text reads as follows: "Shall we say that it is valid with blood? But didn't Rabbi Chiya bar Abba say in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: From where do we derive that the blood of holy offerings does not render them valid? As it is stated: 'You shall not eat it on the ground; you shall pour it out like water' (Deuteronomy 12:16). Blood that is poured out like water renders the offering valid, but blood that is not poured out like water does not render the offering valid."

hebrew_text: אלא דאיתכשר במשקי בית מטבחיא והא א"ר יוסי ברבי חנינא משקי בית מטבחיא לא דיין שהן דכן אלא שאין מכשירין וכי תימא תרגמא אדם והא משקי קאמר  אלא לאו דאתכשר בחבת הקדש
human_translation: Rather, that was rendered susceptible by means of the liquids of the abattoir. But didn’t Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, say: the liquids of the abattoir, not only are they ritually pure, but they do not render susceptible And if you would say explain to blood, but doesn’t he say: Liquids, Rather, not that was rendered susceptible via regard for sanctity?
llm_translation: Rather, it is valid in the liquids of the kitchen. But didn't Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Chanina, say: The liquids of the kitchen are not valid, for they are thus, but they do not render valid. And if you might say that a person translated it, but he was speaking about liquids. Rather, it is not valid in the sanctified vessel.

hebrew_text: ודלמא כדרב יהודה אמר שמואל דאמר רב יהודה אמר שמואל כגון שהיתה לו פרה של זבחי שלמים והעבירה בנחל שחטה ועדיין משקה טופח עליה
human_translation: And perhaps in accordance with Rav Yehuda Shmuel says, as Rav Yehuda says Shmuel says: where one had a cow a peace offering, and he conveyed it through the river slaughtered while liquid was still upon it damp.
llm_translation: Perhaps like Rav Yehudah said Shmuel for Rav Yehudah said Shmuel such as that he had a cow of peace offerings and he passed it through a river and still he waters it with a bucket on it.

hebrew_text: אלא מסיפא והבשר לרבות עצים ולבונה עצים ולבונה בני אכילה נינהו אלא חבת הקדש מכשרא להו ומשויא להו אוכל הכא נמי חבת הקדש מכשרתה
human_translation: Rather from the latter And the flesh, to include wood and frankincense, wood and frankincense edible Rather, regard for sanctity renders susceptible and renders their food. Here too, regard for sanctity renders susceptible
llm_translation: Rather, from the latter clause "and the flesh" includes wood and frankincense. Wood and frankincense are considered food. Rather, the sanctified portion validates and renders them fit for consumption. Just as there, the sanctified portion validates it, so too here, the sanctified portion validates it.

hebrew_text: מאי כי מהניא חבת הקדש לפסולא דגופיה אבל למימנא ביה ראשון ושני לא או דלמא לא שנא תיקו:
human_translation: What When regard for sanctity is effective to disqualify itself, but to count first-degree and second-degree not or perhaps is no difference shall stand
llm_translation: "What is the case when the sanctity of the offering is beneficial for its disqualification, but to count it as the first or second does not apply, or perhaps it is not different? This remains undecided."

hebrew_text: מתני׳ השוחט את המסוכנת רשב"ג אומר עד שתפרכס ביד וברגל ר"א אומר דיה אם זינקה אמר ר"ש השוחט בלילה ולמחר השכים ומצא כתלים מלאים דם כשרה שזינקה וכמדת ר"א וחכ"א עד שתפרכס או ביד או ברגל או עד שתכשכש בזנבה
human_translation: one who slaughters that is in danger Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: only where it convulses with its foreleg and with its hind leg. Rabbi Eliezer says: It is sufficient if spurted Rabbi Shimon says: one who slaughters at night and the next day he awoke and found walls full of blood, valid, that spurted, and in accordance with the rule of Rabbi Eliezer. And the Rabbis say: only where it convulses with its foreleg or with its hind leg, or where it wags its tail.
llm_translation: Mishnah: One who slaughters a dangerously ill animal. Rabbi Shimon ben Gamliel says: until it convulses in its hand and foot. Rabbi Eliezer says: if it writhes. Rabbi Shimon says: one who slaughters at night and the next morning finds its intestines full of blood, it is valid, as it writhed. And according to the measure of Rabbi Eliezer and the sages, until it convulses in its hand or foot, or until its tail flaps.

hebrew_text: אחד בהמה דקה ואחד בהמה גסה בהמה דקה שפשטה ידה ולא החזירה פסולה שאינה אלא הוצאת נפש בלבד במה דברים אמורים שהיתה בחזקת מסוכנת אבל אם היתה בחזקת בריאה אפי' אין בה אחד מכל הסימנים הללו כשרה:
human_translation: both a small animal, and a large animal, a small animal that extended its foreleg and did not restore is not valid, as is only removal soul In what is this statement said? where the presumptive status was in danger But if its presumptive status was healthy, even if there were none of these indicators, valid.
llm_translation: One animal light and one animal heavy, animal light that its hand stretched out and did not return it disqualified for it is only considered a matter of endangering life alone. In what circumstances are these words said? That it was in a presumed state of danger, but if it was in a presumed state of health even if it does not have one of all these signs, it is valid.

hebrew_text: גמ׳ מסוכנת ממאי דשריא וממאי תיסק אדעתין דאסירא דכתיב (ויקרא יא, ב) זאת החיה אשר תאכלו חיה אכול ושאינה חיה לא תאכל והא מסוכנת אינה חיה
human_translation: From where that in danger is permitted And from where would it enter your mind that it is prohibited? as it is written: “These are the living beings [ haḥayya ] that you may eat Eat live [ ḥayya ], but do not eat that is not live. And this in danger is not live.
llm_translation: Gemara: From what source is a bat considered permissible to eat, and from what source is a flying squirrel considered forbidden? We can deduce from the verse that prohibits eating a living creature, as it is written (Leviticus 11:2), "This is the living creature that you may eat." A living creature you may eat, but one that is not a living creature you may not eat, and a bat is not a living creature.

hebrew_text: מדאמר רחמנא (דברים יד, כא) נבלה לא תאכל מכלל דמסוכנת שריא דאי ס"ד מסוכנת אסירא השתא מחיים אסירא לאחר מיתה מיבעי
human_translation: from the fact that the Merciful One states that you shall not eat an unslaughtered animal carcass, by inference in danger is permitted. As, if it enters your mind in danger is prohibited, now prohibited while alive, necessary after death?
llm_translation: As the Merciful One said (Deuteronomy 14:21), "You shall not eat a carcass," is it not inferred that a carcass is permitted? For if you think that it is prohibited, now that it is prohibited during life, it should be prohibited after death, what is needed?

hebrew_text: ודלמא היינו נבלה היינו מסוכנת לא ס"ד דכתיב (ויקרא יא, לט) וכי ימות מן הבהמה אשר היא לכם לאכלה הנוגע בנבלתה לאחר מיתה הוא דקרייה רחמנא נבלה מחיים לא אקרי נבלה
human_translation: And perhaps an unslaughtered carcass is that of in danger It would not enter your mind as it is written: “And if any animal of which you may eat dies, one who touches its carcass it is after death that the Merciful One calls a carcass; while alive, is not called a carcass.
llm_translation: And perhaps this is a carcass, this is dangerous, not so we say, as it is written (Leviticus 11:39), "And if an animal that you may eat dies, anyone who touches its carcass shall be impure until evening." It is after its death that it is called a carcass by the Merciful One, not while alive; I will not call it a carcass while alive.

hebrew_text: ודלמא לעולם אימא לך היינו נבלה היינו מסוכנת מחיים בעשה לאחר מיתה בלאו
human_translation: And perhaps, actually I will say to you: an unslaughtered carcass is that of in danger while alive, in a positive after death, in a prohibition:
llm_translation: And perhaps indeed I will say to you, this is a carcass, this is a dangerous thing, alive through an action after death through a negative commandment.

hebrew_text: אלא מדאמר רחמנא (שמות כב, ל) טרפה לא תאכל מכלל דמסוכנת שריא דאי ס"ד מסוכנת אסירא השתא מסוכנת דלא מחסרא אסירא טרפה מיבעיא
human_translation: Rather, from the fact that the Merciful One states you shall not eat that an animal with a wound that will cause it to die within twelve months [ tereifa ], by inference in danger is permitted. As, if it enters your mind in danger is prohibited, now in danger that is not lacking is prohibited, necessary a tereifa ,
llm_translation: Rather, from when the Merciful One said (Exodus 22:30), "You shall not eat anything torn by beasts in the field," is it to be inferred that it is permitted to eat something that is in danger? For if you think that something in danger is prohibited, now something that is not lacking is in danger, is it necessary to ask whether it is torn?

hebrew_text: ודלמא היינו טרפה היינו מסוכנת ולעבור עליו בעשה ולא תעשה א"כ נבלה דכתב רחמנא ל"ל ומה מחיים קאי עלה בלאו ועשה לאחר מיתה מיבעיא
human_translation: And perhaps a tereifa is in danger to in violation a positive and a prohibition: If so, why do I that the Merciful One writes an unslaughtered carcass? If while alive one stands in a prohibition and a positive is necessary after death?
llm_translation: And perhaps this is a case of treifah, this is a case of danger, and to transgress upon it with a positive commandment and a negative commandment, if so, a carcass, for the Merciful One wrote "to teach us." And what is the status of a living creature regarding a negative commandment and a positive commandment after death, this is the question.

hebrew_text: ודלמא היינו נבלה היינו טרפה היינו מסוכנת ולעבור עליו בשני לאוין ועשה
human_translation: And perhaps an unslaughtered carcass is a tereifa is that of in danger and the result will be that he will violate two prohibitions and a positive
llm_translation: And perhaps this is a case of a nevelah, this is a case of a tereifah, this is a case of a mesukanet, and to transgress upon it with two prohibitions and perform.

hebrew_text: אלא מהכא (ויקרא ז, כד) וחלב נבלה וחלב טרפה יעשה לכל מלאכה ואכל לא תאכלוהו ואמר מר למאי הלכתא אמרה התורה יבא איסור נבלה ויחול על איסור חלב יבא איסור טרפה ויחול על איסור חלב
human_translation: Rather, from here: “And the fat of a carcass and the fat of a tereifa may be used for any purpose; but you shall not eat it” And the Master says: to what halakha The Torah states: Let the prohibition against an unslaughtered carcass come and take effect upon the prohibition against fat, Let the prohibition against a tereifa come and take effect upon the prohibition against fat,
llm_translation: Rather, from here (Leviticus 7:24) "And the fat of a carcass and the fat of a torn animal may be used for any work, but you shall not eat it." And the Master said, for what halakha? The Torah said, let the prohibition of a carcass come and be combined with the prohibition of fat, let the prohibition of a torn animal come and be combined with the prohibition of fat.

hebrew_text: ואי סלקא דעתך טרפה היינו מסוכנת לכתוב רחמנא חלב נבלה יעשה לכל מלאכה וחלב טרפה לא תאכלוהו ואנא אמינא ומה מחיים אתי איסור טרפה חייל אאיסור חלב לאחר מיתה מיבעיא
human_translation: And if it enters your mind a tereifa is in danger let the Merciful One write: the fat of a carcass may be used for any purpose, and the fat of a tereifa you shall not eat. and I would say: If while alive the prohibition against a tereifa takes effect upon the prohibition against fat, is necessary after death
llm_translation: And if it enters your mind, "Tereifah" is the same as dangerous, to write, "The Compassionate One shall make milk from a carcass for all work, and the milk of a tereifah you shall not eat," and I say, "But what difference does it make if the prohibition of tereifah comes from a living animal or the prohibition of milk comes after death?"

hebrew_text: אלא מדכתב רחמנא (ויקרא ז, כד) נבלה מכלל דטרפה לאו היינו מסוכנת
human_translation: Rather, from the fact that the Merciful One writes an unslaughtered carcass by inference that tereifa is not the same as in danger
llm_translation: Rather, from where is it written in the Torah (Leviticus 7:24), "nevelah," is it not included in the category of "trefah"? Is this not a dangerous situation?

hebrew_text: מתקיף לה מר בר רב אשי ודלמא לעולם אימא לך היינו טרפה היינו מסוכנת ודקאמרת נבלה דכתב רחמנא ל"ל להך נבלה דלא אתיא מכח מסוכנת והיכי דמי שעשאה גיסטרא התם נמי אי אפשר דלא הוי מסוכנת פורתא מקמי דליפסק לרובא
human_translation: Mar bar Rav Ashi objects to this: And perhaps, actually I will say to you a tereifa is in danger and that which you said: Why do I an unslaughtered carcass that the Merciful One writes, for that unslaughtered carcass that does not come as a result of danger And what are the circumstances where one rendered a shard, There too, impossible that was not somewhat in danger before he cut the majority
llm_translation: Challenges him Master son of Rav Ashi: But perhaps indeed I will say to you, this is a treifah, this is dangerous. And you said, a nevelah that the Merciful One wrote for that nevelah that does not come from the danger. And how is it similar to one who made a gizzard there also it is impossible that it is not dangerous a little before it reaches the majority.

hebrew_text: ואיבעית אימא א"כ לימא חלב נבלה וטרפה חלב חלב למה לי זו היא שאין חלבה חלוק מבשרה ויש לך אחרת שחלבה חלוק מבשרה ואיזו זו מסוכנת
human_translation: And if you wish, say If so let say: The fat of an unslaughtered carcass and a tereifa . Why do I “Fat fat it is this where its fat is not distinct from its meat, but you have another where its fat, is distinct from its meat, And which That is in danger
llm_translation: And if you wish, say: If so, let him say that the fat of a carcass and a torn animal, why do I need its fat? This is because its fat is not distinct from its flesh, and you have another case where its fat is distinct from its flesh, and which is that? It is dangerous.

hebrew_text: ואיבעית אימא מהכא (יחזקאל ד, יד) ואומר אהה ה' אלהים הנה נפשי לא מטומאה ונבלה וטרפה לא אכלתי מנעורי ועד עתה ולא בא בפי בשר פגול
human_translation: And if you wish, say from here: “Then I said: Ah, Lord God, my soul has not become impure; and from my youth until now I have not eaten an unslaughtered carcass or a tereifa , and no piggul flesh came into my mouth”
llm_translation: And if you wish, say from here (Ezekiel 4:14), "Then I said, 'Ah, Lord God! Behold, my soul has not been defiled, and a carcass or torn flesh I have not eaten from my youth until now, nor has abominable flesh entered my mouth.'"

hebrew_text: הנה נפשי לא מטומאה שלא הרהרתי ביום לבא לידי טומאה בלילה ונבלה וטרפה לא אכלתי מנעורי שלא אכלתי בשר כוס כוס מעולם ולא בא בפי בשר פגול שלא אכלתי מבהמה שהורה בה חכם משום רבי נתן אמרו שלא אכלתי מבהמה שלא הורמו מתנותיה
human_translation: “My soul has not become impure” that I did not consider during the day to come to impurity at night. “And from my youth until now I have not eaten an unslaughtered carcass or a tereifa ” that I never ate flesh of Slaughter slaughter “And no piggul flesh came into my mouth” that I never ate from an animal a Sage issued a ruling They said in the name of Rabbi Natan That I never ate from an animal whose gifts were not separated.
llm_translation: Behold, my soul is not defiled, for I did not have any thoughts during the day that would lead to impurity at night, and I did not eat nevelah or terefah. I have not eaten from my youth meat cooked in a pot, and I have never had in my mouth pig's flesh that is disqualified. I have not eaten from an animal that a sage has ruled as unfit, in the name of Rabbi Nathan they said, "I have not eaten from an animal whose tithes have not been separated."

hebrew_text: אי אמרת בשלמא שריא היינו רבותיה דיחזקאל אלא אי אמרת אסירא מאי רבותיה דיחזקאל
human_translation: Granted, if you say it is permitted that is the greatness of Ezekiel, But if you say it is forbidden what the greatness of Ezekiel?
llm_translation: If you say, "Granted, it is fitting," that is the majority of Ezekiel. But if you say, "It is prohibited," what is the majority of Ezekiel?

hebrew_text: ה"ד מסוכנת אמר רב יהודה אמר רב כל שמעמידין אותה ואינה עומדת רב חנינא בר שלמיא משמיה דרב אמר אפילו אוכלת בקעיות רמי בר יחזקאל אמר אפילו אוכלת קורות
human_translation: What are the circumstances in danger Rav Yehuda said Rav said: any which one stands it but it does not stand Rav Ḥanina bar Shelamya in the name of Rav said: even eats pieces of wood, Rami bar Yeḥezkel said: even eats beams.
llm_translation: So it was dangerous, said Rav Yehudah said Rav, anyone who stands it and it does not stand, Rav Chanina bar Shalmiya in the name of Rav said, even if it eats ke'ayot, Rami bar Yechezkel said, even if it eats beams.

hebrew_text: בסורא מתני הכי בפומבדיתא מתני הכי היכי דמיא מסוכנת אמר רב יהודה אמר רב כל שמעמידין אותה ואינה עומדת ואפילו אוכלת בקעיות רמי בר יחזקאל אמר אפילו אוכלת קורות
human_translation: In Sura, they teach that In Pumbedita, they teach this What are the circumstances in danger Rav Yehuda said Rav said: any which one stands it but it does not stand even eats pieces of wood. Rami bar Yeḥezkel said: even and eats beams,
llm_translation: In Sura they taught thus: In Pumbedita they taught thus: How is it similar to a dangerous thing? Rav Yehudah said in the name of Rav: Anything that they stand it up and it does not stand, even if it eats beams. Rami bar Yehezkel said: Even if it eats rafters.

hebrew_text: אשכחינהו שמואל לתלמידי דרב אמר להו מאי אמר רב במסוכנת אמרו ליה הכי אמר רב
human_translation: Shmuel found students of Rav He said to them: What did Rav say with regard to in danger They said to him: This Rav said:
llm_translation: We found them, Samuel said to the disciples of Rav, he said to them, "What did Rav say about a dangerous situation?" They said to him, "This is what Rav said."

hebrew_text: גועה והטילה ריעי וכשכשה באזנה הרי זה פירכוס אמר להו אצטריכא ליה לאבא לאזוזי אוני שאני אומר כל שאינו דברים שהמיתה עושה
human_translation: lows, or excreted excrement, or wiggled its ear that is a convulsion, said to them: Is it necessary to Abba, to move its ears As I say: Any that are not matters that the death engenders
llm_translation: The deceased and her friend cast lots, and when she clapped her hands in her ear, this is a miscarriage. He said to them: Abba requires the removal of the fetus. I say, anything that is not something that causes death.

hebrew_text: מאי נינהו דברים שהמיתה עושה אמר רב ענן לדידי מפרשא לי מיניה דמר שמואל היתה ידה כפופה ופשטתה דבר שהמיתה עושה פשוטה וכפפה דברים שאין המיתה עושה
human_translation: What are matters that the death engenders? Rav Anan said: was explained to me from Master Shmuel foreleg was bent, and straightened it, a matter that the death engenders. straight and bent matters that the death does not engender
llm_translation: What are the words that cause death to be done? Rav Anan said: According to me, I have a tradition from Mar Shmuel that her hand was bent and she spread out a matter that causes death is spread out and bent, matters that death does not cause.

hebrew_text: מאי קמ"ל תנינא בהמה דקה שפשטה ידה ולא החזירה פסולה שאינה אלא הוצאת נפש הא החזירה כשרה
human_translation: What is teaching us We learn a small animal that extended its foreleg and did not restore is not valid, as is nothing other than removal soul But restore valid.
llm_translation: What is the reason that we learned in a Mishnah: An animal that is light, if its hand stretched out and did not retract it, it is invalid, for it is only considered a removal of life. But if it retracted, it is valid.

hebrew_text: אי ממתני' הוה אמינא דוקא דכייפה ופשטה והדר כייפה לה אבל פשוטה וכפפתה לא קמ"ל
human_translation: If from the mishna I would say specifically where bent, and straightens and then bends it, But straight and bent it, not teaches us
llm_translation: If from the beginning, I would say specifically that when she was forced and then consented, and then she was forced again, but if she consented initially and then was forced, it teaches us.

hebrew_text: מיתיבי ר' יוסי אומר היה ר"מ אומר גועה בשעת שחיטה אין זה פירכוס ר"א ברבי יוסי אומר משמו אפילו הטילה ריעי וכשכשה בזנבה אין זה פירכוס קשיא גועה אגועה קשיא ריעי אריעי
human_translation: raises an objection Rabbi Yosei says Rabbi Meir would say: lows during its slaughter, that is not convulsion Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yosei, says in name Even excreted excrement or wagged its tail, that is not convulsion lows difficult, lows excrement is difficult, excrement
llm_translation: The Talmudic text you provided translates into English as follows: It was taught in a Baraita: Rabbi Yosei says, Rabbi Meir says, "If an animal was dying at the time of slaughter, this is not considered a blemish." Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Yosei, says in his own name, "Even if it kicked its companion and wagged its tail, this is not considered a blemish." The question was raised: "Dying" - is it dying? The question was raised: "Companion" - is it a companion?

hebrew_text: גועה אגועה לא קשיא הא דעבי קלה הא דעמי קלה ריעי אריעי נמי לא קשיא כאן בשותתת כאן במתרזת
human_translation: lows lows not difficult. This where voice rich that where voice muted, excrement excrement not difficult. Here, expels in a trickle. There, expels with force.
llm_translation: The deceased, I will die - not difficult; here, where it is light, and here, where it is dark - also not difficult. Here, where she is drinking, and here, where she is sipping.

hebrew_text: אמר רב חסדא פירכוס שאמרו בסוף שחיטה מאי בסוף שחיטה באמצע שחיטה לאפוקי תחלת שחיטה דלא
human_translation: Rav Ḥisda said: the convulsion that said at the conclusion of slaughter. What At the conclusion of slaughter? in the midst of the slaughter. to exclude the beginning of slaughter, which not
llm_translation: Rav Chisda said: "Regarding the Pharisees who said at the end of the slaughter, what is 'at the end of the slaughter'? It is to exclude the beginning of the slaughter."

hebrew_text: אמר רב חסדא מנא אמינא לה דתנן בהמה דקה שפשטה ידה ולא החזירה פסולה אימת אילימא בסוף שחיטה כל היכי תיחי ותיזיל אלא לאו באמצע שחיטה
human_translation: Rav Ḥisda said: From where do I say as we learned: a small animal that extended its foreleg and did not restore is not valid, When If we say at the conclusion of slaughter, must continue living so extended Rather, is it not in the middle of slaughter?
llm_translation: Rav Chisda said: From where do I know this? As we learned in a Mishnah: An animal that has a thin membrane covering its hand and it removed it but did not return it, it is invalid. When is this so? If you say at the end of the slaughter, how can it live and walk? Rather, is it not in the middle of the slaughter.

hebrew_text: א"ל רבא לעולם בסוף שחיטה שאני אומר כל שאינה עושה כן בסוף שחיטה בידוע שנשמתה נטולה הימנה קודם לכן
human_translation: Rava said to Actually, the conclusion of slaughter, as I say any that does not do so at the conclusion of slaughter, it is known that its soul was taken from it before that
llm_translation: Rava said: Always at the end of slaughter, I say, anyone who does not do so at the end of slaughter, it is known that her soul has departed from her before that.

hebrew_text: ר"נ בר יצחק אמר פירכוס שאמרו בתחלת שחיטה
human_translation: Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: The convulsion that said at the beginning of slaughter.
llm_translation: Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak said: Pirchos, as they said at the beginning of the slaughter.

hebrew_text: אמר ר"נ בר יצחק מנא אמינא לה דתנן אמר ר"ש השוחט בלילה ולמחר מצא כתלים מלאים דם כשרה שזינקה וכמדת ר"א ואמר שמואל כותלי בית שחיטה שנינו אי אמרת בשלמא בתחלת שחיטה שפיר אלא אי אמרת בסוף שחיטה ליחוש דלמא בתחלת שחיטה זינקה
human_translation: Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: From where do I say as we learned Rabbi Shimon says: one who slaughters at night and the next day and found walls full of blood, valid, that spurted, and in accordance with the rule of Rabbi Eliezer. And Shmuel said the walls of the place of the slaughter, we learned. Granted, if you say at the beginning of slaughter well. But if you say at the conclusion of slaughter, let us be concerned perhaps spurted at the beginning of slaughter,
llm_translation: Rav Nahman son of Yitzhak said: From where do I say this? As we learned in a Mishnah: Rabbi Shimon said, one who slaughters at night and the next day finds the intestines full of blood, it is considered valid, for it was absorbed. And according to the measure of Rabbi Eliezer. And Shmuel said: We learned about the walls of the slaughterhouse. If you say at the beginning of the slaughter, it is fine. But if you say at the end of the slaughter, we should be concerned that perhaps at the beginning of the slaughter it was absorbed.

hebrew_text: ודלמא שאני זינוק דעדיף
human_translation: But perhaps spurting is different, as superior
llm_translation: And perhaps it is different, for "zayinuk" is preferable.

hebrew_text: ומי עדיף והתנן ר"א אומר דייה אם זינקה קל מדרבן גמליאל ועדיף מדרבנן
human_translation: And is superior? But didn’t we learn Rabbi Eliezer says it is sufficient if spurted less than of Rabban Gamliel but superior to the Rabbis
llm_translation: And who is superior? And we learned in a Mishnah: Rabbi Eliezer says: "One who is more lenient, if he is more lenient than Rabban Gamliel, is superior to the Rabbis."

hebrew_text: אמר רבינא אמר לי סמא בר חילקאי אקשי בה אבוה דבר אבוברם ואמרי לה אחוה דבר אבוברם ומדרבנן מי עדיף והא תנן וחכמים אומרים עד שתפרכס או ביד או ברגל
human_translation: Ravina said: Samma bar Ḥilkai said to me the father of bar Abuveram, and some say the brother of bar Abuveram, raises a difficulty: And is superior to the Rabbis But didn’t we learn And the Rabbis say: only where it convulses with its foreleg or with its hind leg,
llm_translation: Ravina said, Sama the son of Chilqai said to me, I asked the father of Avubaram, and some say, the brother of Avubaram, which is preferable, and isn't it taught: "And the Sages say, until it is crushed, whether by hand or by foot."

hebrew_text: רבנן אהייא קיימו אילימא אדר"ג כיון שפירכסה מיבעי ליה
human_translation: To which do the Rabbis stand If we say of Rabban Gamliel, should Once convulsed
llm_translation: The sages said: Ahaiya is standing. If you say it is because of the "Adra" of the Garden of Eden, once it is covered, he needs it.

hebrew_text: אלא פשיטא אדר"א ואי עדיף מאי עד
human_translation: Rather, obvious of Rabbi Eliezer. And if superior what only
llm_translation: Rather, it is obvious, as Rabbi Akiva said, "And if it is superior, what is it superior to?"

hebrew_text: רבא אמר פירכוס שאמרו בסוף שחיטה אמר רבא מנא אמינא לה דתניא שור
human_translation: Rava said: The convulsion that said at the conclusion of slaughter. Rava said: From where do I say as it is taught “a bull
llm_translation: Rava said: "Pirkus," as they said at the end of the slaughter. Rava said: "From where do I say this? As it was taught: 'An ox.'"

hebrew_text: (ויקרא כב, כז) או כשב פרט לכלאים או עז פרט לנדמה כי יולד פרט ליוצא דופן שבעת ימים פרט למחוסר זמן תחת אמו פרט ליתום
human_translation: or a sheep” to the exclusion of diverse kinds, “or a goat” to the exclusion of that resembles “When it is born”; to the exclusion of born by caesarean section. seven days”; to the exclusion of whose time has not yet “Under its mother”; to the exclusion of an orphan.
llm_translation: "And a sheep or a goat - excluding hybrids; or a goat - excluding a condemned one; 'when a woman gives birth' - excluding a breech birth; 'for seven days' - excluding a case of lacking time; 'under her mother' - excluding an orphan."

hebrew_text: האי יתום ה"ד אילימא דילידתיה אמיה והדר מתה לעולם תיחי ותיזיל אלא דמתה והדר ילידתיה מכי יולד נפקא
human_translation: What are the circumstances this orphan? If we say that its mother gave birth to it and then died, continue living forever? Rather, where died and then gave birth to it. is derived from “When it is born,”
llm_translation: This orphan, here is where? If you say that his mother gave birth and then died, he should live and go out into the world. Rather, if she died and then gave birth, it is evident.

hebrew_text: אלא פשיטא זה פירש למיתה וזה פירש לחיים אי אמרת בשלמא בעינן חיותא בסוף לידה היינו דאיצטריך קרא למעוטי אלא אי אמרת לא בעינן חיותא בסוף לידה למה ליה מכי יולד נפקא
human_translation: Rather, obvious this withdrew for death and that withdrew for life. Granted, if you say we require life at the conclusion of birth, that is why a verse was necessary to exclude But if you say we do not require life at the conclusion of the birth, why is be derived from “When it is born.”
llm_translation: Rather, it is obvious: this one separated for death, and this one separated for life. If you say, "Well and good, we require the living at the end of childbirth, that is why a verse is necessary to exclude," but if you say, "We do not require the living at the end of childbirth, why does he need it? When he is born, he goes out."

hebrew_text: אמר רבא הלכתא כי הא מתניתא בהמה דקה שפשטה ידה ולא החזירה פסולה
human_translation: Rava says the halakha is in accordance with this baraita : a small animal that extended its foreleg and did not restore it is not valid.
llm_translation: Rava said: The halakha is in accordance with this Mishnah: A small animal that extended its hand and did not retract it is invalid.

hebrew_text: במה דברים אמורים ביד אבל ברגל בין פשטה ולא כפפה בין כפפה ולא פשטה כשרה בד"א בדקה אבל בגסה בין ביד בין ברגל בין פשטה ולא כפפה בין כפפה ולא פשטה כשרה ועוף אפילו לא רפרף אלא גפו ולא כשכש אלא זנבו הרי זה פירכוס
human_translation: In what is this statement said? with regard to the foreleg. But with regard to the hind leg, whether extended it and did not restore or bent it but did not extend it, is valid. In what is this statement, said? with regard to a small But with regard to a large whether foreleg or its hind leg, whether extended it and did not restore or bent it but did not extend it, is valid. And a bird, even fluttered [ rifref ] only its wing or wagged only its tail, that is a convulsion
llm_translation: In what matters are these words said? In the case of an animal that died by hand, but not by foot, whether it was skinned but not flayed, or flayed but not skinned, it is valid. This applies only to a small animal, but in the case of a large animal, whether by hand or by foot, whether it was skinned but not flayed, or flayed but not skinned, it is valid. And regarding a bird, even if it is not whole, as long as its body is intact and not crushed, but its tail is intact and not severed, it is considered a peirakus.

hebrew_text: מאי קמ"ל כולהו תננהי בהמה דקה שפשטה ידה ולא החזירה פסולה שאינה אלא הוצאת נפש יד אין רגל לא דקה אין גסה לא עוף איצטריכא ליה דלא תנן:
human_translation: What is teaching us all of we learned a small animal that extended its foreleg and did not restore is not valid, as is only removal soul a foreleg yes, a hind leg, no, a small yes, a large no, was necessary for a bird, as we did not learn
llm_translation: What is the reason that the Mishnah teaches all small domestic animals that its hand has spread out and not returned are invalid? Because it is only considered as the removal of a soul by hand, not by foot, not small, not large, not a bird. It is necessary to teach this.

hebrew_text: מתני׳ השוחט לעובד כוכבי' שחיטתו כשרה ור"א פוסל אמר ר"א אפילו שחטה לאכול לעובד כוכבים מחצר כבד שלה פסולה שסתם מחשבת עובד כוכבים לעבודת כוכבים
human_translation: who slaughters for a gentile, his slaughter is valid, and Rabbi Eliezer deems it not valid. Rabbi Eliezer says: Even if slaughtered to feed the gentile from its diaphragm [ meḥatzar kaved ], not valid, as the unspecified intent of a gentile is for idol worship,
llm_translation: Mishnah: One who slaughters for a worshipper of stars, his slaughter is valid. And Rabbi Eliezer disqualifies it. Rabbi Eliezer said: Even if he slaughtered to eat for a worshipper of stars, its liver is disqualified, for the general intention of a worshipper of stars is for idolatry.

hebrew_text: א"ר יוסי ק"ו הדברים ומה במקום שהמחשבה פוסלת במוקדשין אין הכל הולך אלא אחר העובד מקום שאין מחשבה פוסלת בחולין אינו דין שלא יהא הכל הולך אלא אחר השוחט:
human_translation: Rabbi Yosei says: matter an a fortiori If in a place where intent invalidates in sacrificial everything follows only performing the service in a place where intent does not invalidate in non-sacred is it not right that everything should follow only the one who slaughters
llm_translation: Rabbi Yosei said: The matter is equal. Just as in a place where intent invalidates offerings, everyone follows after the one who performs the act, so too in a place where intent does not invalidate ordinary animals, it is not proper for everyone to follow after the one who slaughters.

hebrew_text: גמ׳ הני תנאי אית להו דר' אליעזר ברבי יוסי דתניא אמר ר' אליעזר ברבי יוסי שמעתי שהבעלים מפגלין
human_translation: These tanna’im hold Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Yosei, as it is taught Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Yosei, says: I heard that the owners, render piggul
llm_translation: Gemara: These teachings belong to Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Yosi, as it was taught: Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Yosi, said, "I have heard that ba'alim render offerings disqualified."

hebrew_text: מיהו ת"ק סבר אי שמעיניה דחשיב אין אי לא לא סתם מחשבת עובד כוכבים לעבודת כוכבים לא אמרינן ור"א סבר אע"ג דלא שמעיניה דחשיב סתם מחשבת עובד כוכבים לעבודת כוכבים אמרינן ואתא רבי יוסי למימר אע"ג דשמעיניה דחשיב זה מחשב וזה עובד לא אמרינן
human_translation: But the first tanna holds if we heard that he intends yes, if not not we do not say unspecified intent of a gentile is for idol worship. Rabbi Eliezer holds: Although we did not hear that he intends we say unspecified intent of a gentile is for idol worship. And Rabbi Yosei comes to say even though we heard that he intends this has intent and that performing we do not say
llm_translation: Who is the Tanna Kamma? He holds: If his intention is discernible, it is considered idolatrous; if not, it is not considered idolatrous. We do not say that a general thought of a non-Jew is regarding idol worship is considered idolatrous. And Rabbi Eliezer holds: Even though his intention is not discernible, if it is a general thought of a non-Jew regarding idol worship, we say it is considered idolatrous. And Rabbi Yosei came to say: Even though his intention is discernible, this one is a thought and this one is an idolater, we do not say it is considered idolatrous.

hebrew_text: איכא דאמרי בדשמעיניה דחשיב פליגי ת"ק סבר כי אמרינן זה מחשב וזה עובד הני מילי בפנים אבל בחוץ לא חוץ מפנים
human_translation: There are who say with regard to where we heard that he intends disagree. The first tanna holds when we say this has intent and that performing this statement inside But outside not outside from inside
llm_translation: There are those who say in their names of Hashem, they argue with the Tanna Kamma. The Tanna Kamma holds that when we say "this one intends and this one performs," these matters are applicable only indoors, but not outdoors, except for indoors.

hebrew_text: לא ילפינן ואתא רבי אליעזר למימר ילפינן חוץ מפנים ואתא רבי יוסי למימר אפילו בפנים נמי זה מחשב וזה עובד לא אמרינן
human_translation: we do not derive And Rabbi Eliezer comes to say we derive outside from inside And Rabbi Yosei comes to say even inside this has intent and that performing we do not say
llm_translation: We do not teach, and Rabbi Eliezer came to say we teach, except outside. And Rabbi Yosei came to say even inside, this one calculates and this one performs, we do not say.

hebrew_text: אתמר השוחט את הבהמה לזרוק דמה לעבודת כוכבים ולהקטיר חלבה לעבודת כוכבים רבי יוחנן אמר פסולה ר"ש בן לקיש אמר מותרת
human_translation: It was stated one who slaughtered an animal to sprinkle its blood for idol worship, or to burn its fat for idol worship. Rabbi Yoḥanan says: not valid, Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says: permitted.
llm_translation: It was stated: One who slaughters an animal to sprinkle its blood for idol worship, and to burn its fat for idol worship. Rabbi Yochanan said: It is invalid. Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: It is permissible.

hebrew_text: רבי יוחנן אמר פסולה מחשבין מעבודה לעבודה וילפינן חוץ מפנים
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan says: not valid one transfers intent from rite to rite. And we derive outside from inside
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan said: "An invalid animal is calculated from one service to another, and we may sprinkle its blood outside the Temple courtyard due to the prohibition of 'inside'."

hebrew_text: ריש לקיש אמר מותרת אין מחשבין מעבודה לעבודה ולא גמרינן חוץ מפנים
human_translation: Reish Lakish says: permitted. one does not transfer intent from rite to rite. And we do not derive outside from inside
llm_translation: Reish Lakish said: "Permitted, not calculate from service to service, and we do not finish except from inside."

hebrew_text: ואזדו לטעמייהו דאתמר שחטה לשמה לזרוק דמה שלא לשמה רבי יוחנן אמר פסולה ר"ש בן לקיש אמר כשרה
human_translation: And follow their reasoning, as it was stated: slaughtered for its own sake, to sprinkle its blood not for its own sake Rabbi Yoḥanan says unfit, Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says fit.
llm_translation: And they went according to their reasons that were stated: slaughtering for the sake of throwing its blood, not for the sake of throwing its blood. Rabbi Yochanan said: invalid. Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: valid.

hebrew_text: רבי יוחנן אמר פסולה מחשבין מעבודה לעבודה וגמרינן ממחשבת פיגול ר"ש בן לקיש אמר כשרה אין מחשבין מעבודה לעבודה ולא גמרינן ממחשבת פיגול
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan says unfit. one transfers intent from rite to rite, and we derive from intent for piggul , Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says fit one does not transfer intent from rite to rite, and we do not derive from intent for piggul .
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan said: "A disqualified offering, we calculate from one service to another, and we conclude its disqualification from the thought of Pigul." Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: "A valid offering, we do not calculate from one service to another, and we do not conclude its disqualification from the thought of Pigul."

hebrew_text: וצריכא דאי איתמר בהא בהא קאמר ר"ש בן לקיש משום דחוץ מפנים לא ילפינן אבל פנים מפנים אימא מודי ליה לרבי יוחנן
human_translation: And necessary As, if were stated with regard to that in that Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish states due to that we do not derive outside from inside But inside from inside say concedes to Rabbi Yoḥanan
llm_translation: And it is necessary, for if it was stated regarding this and that, R. Shimon ben Lakish said: Because outside we do not learn, but inside we say, let Rabbi Yochanan agree.

hebrew_text: ואי אתמר בהך בההיא קאמר רבי יוחנן אבל בהא אימא מודי ליה לר"ש בן לקיש צריכא
human_translation: And if was stated with regard to this in this Rabbi Yoḥanan said But in that say that concedes to Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish necessary
llm_translation: And if it was said in that case, in that situation, Rabbi Yochanan said, but in this case, say that Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish agrees.

hebrew_text: מתיב רב ששת א"ר יוסי ק"ו הדברים ומה במקום שמחשבה פוסלת במוקדשין אין הכל הולך אלא אחר העובד מקום שאין מחשבה פוסלת בחולין אינו דין שלא יהא הכל הולך אלא אחר השוחט
human_translation: Rav Sheshet raises an objection Rabbi Yosei says: matter an a fortiori If in a place where intent invalidates in sacrificial everything follows only performing the service in a place where intent does not invalidate in non-sacred is it not right that everything should follow only the one who slaughters
llm_translation: A question was raised: Rav Sheshet said, Rabbi Yosei raises a contradiction: "And what about a case where intent invalidates in consecrated items, does everything depend only on the one who performs the action? In a place where intent does not invalidate in non-consecrated items, is it not the law that everything should depend only on the one who slaughters?"

hebrew_text: מאי אין מחשבה פוסלת בחולין אילימא דלא פסלה כלל אלא זביחה דעבודת כוכבים דמיתסרא היכי משכחת לה
human_translation: What Intent does not invalidate in non-sacred If we say that does not invalidate at all, but how can you find slaughter for idol worship where is forbidden?
llm_translation: What is the meaning of "thought does not disqualify in mundane matters"? If you say it does not disqualify at all, but only the slaughter of idolatrous worship, how do you find it?

hebrew_text: אלא פשיטא מעבודה לעבודה וה"ק ומה במקום שמחשבה פוסלת במוקדשין מעבודה לעבודה אין הכל הולך אלא אחר העובד מקום שאין מחשבה פוסלת בחולין מעבודה לעבודה אלא באותה עבודה אינו דין שלא יהא הכל הולך אלא אחר השוחט
human_translation: Rather, obvious from rite to rite, and this is saying: If in a place where intent invalidates, in sacrificial from rite to rite, everything follows only performing place where intent does not invalidate, in non-sacred from rite to rite only within the same rite, is it not right that everything should follow only the one who slaughters
llm_translation: Rather, it is obvious from one service to another, and it was asked: "And in a place where intention disqualifies in consecrated items, from one service to another, does everything go only after the one performing the service? In a place where intention does not disqualify in mundane items, from one service to another, it is not the case that everything goes only after the one who slaughters."

hebrew_text: פנים קשיא לר"ש בן לקיש חוץ קשיא לרבי יוחנן
human_translation: inside difficult for Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish, outside difficult for Rabbi Yoḥanan,
llm_translation: Faces difficult to Reish Lakish, outside difficult to Rabbi Yochanan.

hebrew_text: בשלמא פנים לר"ש בן לקיש לא קשיא הא מקמי דשמעה מרבי יוחנן הא לבתר דשמעה מרבי יוחנן אלא חוץ קשיא לרבי יוחנן
human_translation: Granted, inside not difficult for Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish, this he heard from Rabbi Yoḥanan, that after he heard from Rabbi Yoḥanan. But outside is difficult for Rabbi Yoḥanan.
llm_translation: In accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish, it is not difficult. This is prior to hearing from Rabbi Yochanan, but after hearing from Rabbi Yochanan, it is difficult. Rather, the difficulty is for Rabbi Yochanan.

hebrew_text: הוא מותיב לה והוא מפרק לה בארבע עבודות וה"ק ומה במקום שמחשבה פוסלת במוקדשין בארבע עבודות אין הכל הולך אלא אחר העובד
human_translation: raises the objection, and he resolves it. of the four rites And this is saying: If in a place where intent invalidates in sacrificial during four rites, everything follows only performing the service
llm_translation: He poses to her and he resolves for her with four works and it is stated: "And just as in a place where intention disqualifies in consecrated items, with four works, everything goes only after the one performing the work."

hebrew_text: מקום שאין מחשבה פוסלת בחולין אלא בשתי עבודות אינו דין שלא יהא הכל הולך אלא אחר השוחט
human_translation: in a place where intent invalidates in non-sacred during only two rites, is it not right that everything should follow only the one who slaughters
llm_translation: Place where no thought disqualifies in mundane except in two works not law that not should be all going except after the slaughter.

hebrew_text: תניא כוותיה דרבי יוחנן השוחט את הבהמה לזרוק דמה לעבודת כוכבים ולהקטיר חלבה לעבודת כוכבים הרי אלו זבחי מתים שחטה ואח"כ חישב עליה זה היה מעשה בקיסרי ולא אמרו בה לא איסור ולא היתר
human_translation: It is taught in accordance with of Rabbi Yoḥanan: one who slaughters an animal to sprinkle its blood for idol worship to burn its fat for idol worship, these is offerings to the dead, If one slaughtered and thereafter intended in its that was incident in Caesarea, and did not say with regard to neither prohibition nor permission.
llm_translation: It was taught in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: One who slaughters an animal in order to sprinkle its blood for idol worship, and to burn its fat for idol worship, these are sacrifices to the dead. If one slaughtered it and then had intent for it, this was the case with the Caesareans, and they did not say about it either prohibition or permission.

hebrew_text: אמר רב חסדא לא אמרו בה איסור משום כבודן דרבנן לא היתר משום כבודו דרבי אליעזר
human_translation: Rav Ḥisda says they did not say prohibition, due to the honor of the Rabbis Nor permission, due to the honor of Rabbi Eliezer,
llm_translation: Rav Chisda said: They did not say regarding it prohibition due to the honor of the Rabbis, nor permission due to the honor of Rabbi Eliezer.

hebrew_text: ממאי דלמא עד כאן לא קאמרי רבנן התם אלא דלא שמענא דחשיב אבל הכא דשמענא דחשיב הוכיח סופו על תחלתו
human_translation: From where Perhaps the Rabbis say only there because we did not hear that intends But here where we hear that he intends his ultimate proves his original
llm_translation: From what source do the Rabbis perhaps not say this until here? There in that case it is only because I did not hear it that it is considered significant, but here, since I heard it that it is considered significant, he proved its end from its beginning.

hebrew_text: אי נמי ע"כ לא קאמר ר"א התם אלא גבי עובד כוכבים דסתם מחשבת עובד כוכבים לעבודת כוכבים אבל ישראל הוכיח סופו על תחלתו לא אמרינן
human_translation: Alternatively, Rabbi Eliezer states there only with regard to a gentile, as the unspecified intent of a gentile is directed to idol worship. But a Jew, we do not say his ultimate proves his original
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Alternatively, indeed not so said Rabbi Eliezer there, but regarding a Gentile whose intention is for idol worship, but an Israelite who established the end at the beginning, we do not say.

hebrew_text: אלא אמר רב שיזבי לא אמרו בה היתר משום כבודו דרשב"ג הי רשב"ג
human_translation: Rather, Rav Sheizevi said did not state permission with regard to due to the honor of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, Which Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel
llm_translation: Rather, Rav Sheizbi said: They did not say about it the halacha that it is permitted because of the honor of Rabban Gamliel. This is what Rabban Gamliel said.

hebrew_text: אילימא רשב"ג דגיטין דתנן הבריא שאמר כתבו גט לאשתי רצה לשחק בה
human_translation: If we say Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel with regard to bills of divorce, As we learned a healthy who says: Write a bill of divorce for my wife, sought to mock her
llm_translation: Let's say it is Rabbi Shimon ben Gamliel regarding the case of a healthy person who said, "Write a bill of divorce for my wife," but he intended to jest with her.

hebrew_text: ומעשה בבריא שאמר כתבו גט לאשתי ועלה לגג ונפל ומת אמר רשב"ג אם מעצמו נפל ה"ז גט ואם הרוח דחתו אינו גט
