llm_translation: Rav Assi said: There are eight uncertainties - Chova, Chuga, Suga, and Harnuga, Tushalmi and Marda, Kochilna, and Bar Nafcha. What are their uncertainties? Pure birds, their crop is peeled, and they are impure. If their crop is not peeled, and these crops are peeled with a knife.

hebrew_text: והא ההיא בר אווזא דהוה בי מר שמואל דלא הוה קא מקלף קורקבניה ואותביה בשימשא וכיון דרפי איקליף התם כי רפי איקליף בידא הכא אע"ג דרפי לא מקליף אלא בסכינא
human_translation: But a certain duck in the house of Mar Shmuel whose gizzard could not be peeled, and they set in the sun, and once it softened it could be peeled? There, when it softened it could be peeled by hand. Here, even when it softened it could be peeled only with a knife.
llm_translation: And the story of the duck that was in the house of Mar Samuel, who was peeling its gizzard and placing it in fat. And once it softened, he peeled it there. When it softened, he peeled it with his hand. Here, even though it softened, he does not peel it except with a knife.

hebrew_text: אמר אביי תרנגולא דאגמא חד משמונה ספיקות הוא והיינו מרדו אמר רב פפא תרנגולא דאגמא אסירא תרנגולתא דאגמא שריא וסימניך עמוני ולא עמונית דרש מרימר תרנגולתא דאגמא אסירא חזיוה דדרסה ואכלה והיינו גירותא
human_translation: Abaye says: The swamp rooster is one of the eight uncertain and this is mardu , Rav Pappa says: The swamp rooster is forbidden, but the swamphen is permitted. And your mnemonic an Ammonite man but not an Ammonite woman. Mareimar taught: The swamphen is forbidden, saw that it claws and eats And this is giruta ,
llm_translation: Abbaye said: "A rooster of the marsh is one of eight doubts, and that is what Mardu said." Rav Pappa said: "A rooster of the marsh is forbidden, a hen of the marsh is permitted, and your sign is 'Ammonite' and not 'Ammonitess'." R. Yirmiyah expounded: "A hen of the marsh is forbidden - see if it trampled and ate, and that is the conclusion."

hebrew_text: אמר רב שבור אנדרפטא שרי פירוז אנדרפטא אסור וסימניך פירוז רשיעא אמר רב הונא בוניא שרי פרוא אסיר וסימניך פרואה אמגושא
human_translation: Rav says: shavor anderafta is permitted, piruz anderafta is forbidden. And your mnemonic Piruz the Evil. Rav Huna says: bunya is permitted. parva is forbidden. And your mnemonic Parva’a the Sorcerer.
llm_translation: Rav Shabur said: Andarfta is permitted, Piruz Andarfta is forbidden, and your sign is Piruz Rashi'a. Rav Huna said: Bunya is permitted, Pru'a is forbidden, and your sign is Prua'a Amgusha.

hebrew_text: אמר רב פפא מרדו זגיד ואכיל שרי סגיד ואכיל אסור וסימניך (שמות לד, יד) לא תשתחוה לאל אחר אמר שמואל שתיא חמרא אסירא וסימניך שתויי יין פסולין לעבודה ואמר שמואל מזגא חמרא אסירא
human_translation: Rav Pappa says: reclining and eating mardu is permitted, bowing and eating is forbidden. And your mnemonic “You shall bow down to no other god” Shmuel says: wine drinker is forbidden. And your mnemonic Those who drank wine are unfit for service And Shmuel says: wine pourer is forbidden.
llm_translation: Rav Papa said: If one rebels, fish is permitted; if one eats, fish is forbidden. And your mnemonic is, "You shall not bow down to another god" (Exodus 34:14). Shmuel said: Two cups of wine are forbidden, and your mnemonic is, "Those who are drunk with wine are unfit for service" (Leviticus 10:9). And Shmuel said: Mixed wine is forbidden.

hebrew_text: בת מזגא חמרא שריא וסימניך יפה כח הבן מכח האב
human_translation: little wine pourer is permitted. And your mnemonic The power of the son is greater than the power of the father,
llm_translation: Daughter of Migga, wine is permitted, and your signs are beautiful, the strength of the son from the strength of the father.

hebrew_text: אמר רב יהודה שקיטנא אריכי שקי וסומקי שריא וסימניך מורזמא גוצי וסומקי אסירי וסימניך ננוס פסול אריכי שקי וירוקי אסירי וסימניך ירוקין פסולין
human_translation: Rav Yehuda says: shekitena . long-shanked red permitted. And your mnemonic murzema little red forbidden, and your mnemonic a dwarf unfit long-shanked green, forbidden, and your mnemonic green unfit
llm_translation: Rav Yehudah said: "A long fig is valid, a short fig is valid, a red fig is valid, and your sign is a white fig. A cracked fig is invalid, a smoky fig is invalid, and your sign is a withered fig. A green fig is invalid, and your sign is green figs are invalid."

hebrew_text: אמר רב יהודה שלך זה השולה דגים מן הים דוכיפת שהודו כפות תניא נמי הכי דוכיפת שהודו כפות וזהו שהביא שמיר לבית המקדש
human_translation: Rav Yehuda says: shalakh , this is that scoops [ sholeh ] fish out of the sea. dukhifat whose comb bent [ hodo kafut ] This is also taught dukhifat whose comb bent, and this is that brought the shamir to the Temple.
llm_translation: Rav Yehudah said: "This is the Shulah that catches fish from the sea, the Dudkipat, whose fins are split. It was also taught in a Baraita: 'The Dudkipat, whose fins are split.' And this is what brought Shemir to the Temple."

hebrew_text: ר' יוחנן כי הוה חזי שלך אמר (תהלים לו, ז) משפטיך תהום רבה כי הוה חזי נמלה אמר (תהלים לו, ז) צדקתך כהררי אל
human_translation: When Rabbi Yoḥanan would see a shalakh , he say: “Your judgments are like the great deep” When he would see an ant, he say “Your righteousness is like the mighty mountains,”
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan, when he would see a slug, would say (Psalms 36:7), "Your judgments are a great deep." When he would see an ant, he would say (Psalms 36:6), "Your righteousness is like the mighty mountains."

hebrew_text: אמר אמימר לקני ובטני שריין שקנאי ובטנאי מקום שנהגו לאכול אוכלין מקום שנהגו שלא לאכול אין אוכלין אטו במנהגא תליא מילתא אין ולא קשיא הא באתרא דשכיחי פרס ועזניה הא באתרא דלא שכיחי פרס ועזניה
human_translation: Ameimar says: laknei and batnei permitted. sakna’ei and batna’ei place that it is customary to eat one may eat place that it is customary not to eat one may not eat Is that to say that the matter depends on custom? Yes, but not difficult: This a place where the peres and ozniyya are found. That a place where the peres and ozniyya are not found.
llm_translation: Ammar Amimar: To Knei and Betnei, they permit, for Kena'i and Betna'i, in a place where it is customary to eat, they eat; in a place where it is not customary to eat, they do not eat. Is the matter dependent on custom? And it is not difficult: here, in a place where they are common, the Persians and their food; there, in a place where they are not common, the Persians and their food.

hebrew_text: אמר אביי קואי וקקואי אסירי קקואתא שריא במערבא מלקו עילוה וקרו לה תחוותא
human_translation: Abaye says: kevai and kakvai are forbidden, kakvata is permitted. in the West, they flog on its and they call it taḥveta .
llm_translation: Abbaye said: "Koai and Kakoa'i are forbidden, the Koai of the Koaita is permitted in the west, they flogged her on her upper part and called it 'Tachvata'."

hebrew_text: ת"ר (ויקרא יא, יח) תנשמת באות שבעופות אתה אומר באות שבעופות או אינו אלא באות שבשרצים אמרת צא ולמד מי"ג מדות שהתורה נדרשת בהן דבר הלמד מענינו במה הכתוב מדבר בעופות אף כאן בעופות
human_translation: The Sages taught tinshemet , ba’ut among birds. Do you say the ba’ut among birds, or is it only the ba’ut among creeping animals? Say: Go out and learn from the thirteen hermeneutical principles, A matter derived from its context. What are the verses speaking about? about birds. So too here, to birds.
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: "Regarding the sign of the seven species of birds, do you say it is the sign of the seven species of birds, or is it rather the sign of the seven species of creeping things?" You should go and learn from the thirteen principles through which the Torah is expounded. Just as the Scripture is speaking about birds there, so too here it is speaking about birds.

hebrew_text: תניא נמי גבי שרצים כה"ג תנשמת באות שבשרצים אתה אומר באות שבשרצים או אינו אלא באות שבעופות אמרת צא ולמד מי"ג מדות שהתורה נדרשת בהן דבר הלמד מענינו במה הכתוב מדבר בשרצים אף כאן בשרצים
human_translation: It is also taught in this way with regard to creeping animals: tinshemet ba’ut among creeping animals. Do you say ba’ut among creeping animals, or it is only ba’ut among birds? Say: Go out and learn from the thirteen hermeneutical principles, A matter derived from its context. What are the verses speaking about? about creeping animals. So too here, to creeping animals.
llm_translation: It was also taught regarding creeping creatures: Just as the soul is in the letter of creeping creatures, do you say in the letter of creeping creatures, or is it only in the letter of birds? You said, "Go and learn from the thirteen attributes by which the Torah is expounded. A matter that is learned from its context, what is the Scripture speaking about? In the case of creeping creatures." Just as there, in the case of creeping creatures.

hebrew_text: אמר אביי באות שבעופות קיפוף באות שבשרצים קורפדאי אמר רב יהודה קאת זו הקוק רחם זו שרקרק
human_translation: Abaye says: ba’ut among birds kifof . ba’ut among creeping animals kurpedai . Rav Yehuda says: ka’at this is the a kuk . raḥam , this is sherakrak .
llm_translation: Abbaye said: In the letter of the hoopoe, there is a kafuf; in the letter of the vermin, there is a korpdaye. Rav Yehudah said: "Ka'at" refers to the hoopoe, "Racham" refers to the shrike.

hebrew_text: א"ר יוחנן למה נקרא שמו רחם כיון שבא רחם באו רחמים לעולם אמר רב ביבי בר אביי והוא דיתיב אמידי ועביד שרקרק וגמירי דאי יתיב אארעא ושריק אתא משיחא שנאמר (זכריה י, ח) אשרקה להם ואקבצם
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Why is it called the raḥam ? when the raḥam comes mercy [ raḥamim ] comes to the world, Rav Beivai bar Abaye said: And it is when it sits on something and makes a sherakrak is learned that if it sits on the ground and hisses [ veshareik ], the Messiah is coming, as it is stated: “I will hiss [ eshreka ] for them, and gather them”
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan said: Why is his name called Rechem (womb)? Because when Rechem (the womb) came, mercy came into the world. Rav Beivai bar Abaye said, and he was sitting immediately and making a noise, and he learned that if he sits in the dust and makes a noise, the Messiah will come, as it is said (Zechariah 10:8), "I will whistle for them and gather them."

hebrew_text: א"ל רב אדא בר שימי למר בר רב אידאי והא ההוא דיתיב בי כרבא ושרק ואתא גלל אפסקיה למוחיה א"ל ההוא ביידא הוה
human_translation: Rav Adda bar Shimi said to Mar bar Rav Idai: But a certain that sat on a plowed field and hissed, and a stone came and broke its head? said to him: That was a liar
llm_translation: Rav Adda bar Shimei said to Mar bar Rav Idi, "But that one who was sitting in the house of the teacher, and he whistled, and a clod came and struck his head, he said, 'That one was a Jew.'"

hebrew_text: ת"ר עורב זה עורב את כל העורב להביא עורב העמקי למינו להביא עורב הבא בראשי יונים
human_translation: the Sages taught orev , this is the crow. “Every orev ,” to include the valley crow “After its kinds,” to include the crow that comes at the heads of pigeons.
llm_translation: The Sages taught: "Orev" - this is the Orev that mixed with all the other ravens to bring the Orev HaAmaki of its kind, to bring the Orev that came with the heads of doves.

hebrew_text: אמר מר עורב זה עורב אטו קמן קאי אלא אימא עורב זה עורב אוכמא וכן הוא אומר (שיר השירים ה, יא) קווצותיו תלתלים שחורות כעורב העמקי חיוורא וכן הוא אומר (ויקרא יג, כה) ומראהו עמוק מן העור כמראה חמה העמוקה מן הצל
human_translation: The Master said: orev , this is the crow. Is that to say stands before us, Rather, say: orev , this is the black crow, and so states: “His locks are curled, and black as a crow” The valley [ ha’amaki ] white And so states “If the appearance thereof be deeper [ amok ] than the skin” As the appearance of sun, which deeper than the shade,
llm_translation: The Master said: "This raven is a raven, is it not standing before us? Rather, say: This raven is a raven of the city." And so it says (Song of Songs 5:11): "His locks are curled, black as a raven." And it also says (Leviticus 13:25): "And the appearance of it is deeper than the skin, like the appearance of the deep sunken spot."

hebrew_text: ועורב הבא בראשי יונים אמר רב פפא לא תימא דאתי בריש יוני אלא דדמי רישיה לדיונה
human_translation: And the crow that comes at the heads of pigeons, Rav Pappa said: Do not say that it comes at the head of pigeons, rather, head resembles that of a pigeon.
llm_translation: And a raven that came with the heads of doves, Rav Pappa said: Do not say that it came with the head of a dove, but rather its head resembles that of a dove.

hebrew_text: ת"ר הנץ זה הנץ למינהו להביא את בר חיריא מאי בר חיריא אמר אביי שורינקא
human_translation: the Sages taught: the netz , this is the hawk. “After its kinds,” to include bar ḥireya . What is the bar ḥireya ? Abaye said: shurineka .
llm_translation: The Sages taught: "The sunrise, this is the sunrise of its kind." To bring Bar Ḥiryah. What is Bar Ḥiryah? Abaye said: "A calf."

hebrew_text: אמר רב יהודה החסידה זו דיה לבנה למה נקרא שמה חסידה שעושה חסידות עם חברותיה האנפה זו דיה רגזנית למה נקרא שמה אנפה שמנאפת עם חברותיה
human_translation: Rav Yehuda says: the ḥasida , this is the white dayya . And why is it called ḥasida ? Since it performs charity [ ḥasidut ] for its fellows, the anafa , this is the irritable dayya . And why is it called anafa ? Since it quarrels [ mena’efet ] with its fellows.
llm_translation: Said Rav Yehudah: "Why is this bird called 'Chasidah'? Because it acts with kindness towards its companions. Why is this bird called 'Anafah'? Because it commits adultery with its companions."

hebrew_text: אמר רב חנן בר רב חסדא אמר רב חסדא אמר רב חנן בריה דרבא אמר רב עשרים וארבעה עופות טמאין הן א"ל רב חנן בר רב חסדא לרב חסדא דהיכא אי דויקרא עשרים הוו אי דמשנה תורה עשרים וחד הוו וכי תימא דאה דכתיבא בויקרא ולא כתיבא במשנה תורה שדייה עלייהו אכתי עשרין ותרין הוו
human_translation: Rav Ḥanan bar Rav Ḥisda says Rav Ḥisda says Rav Ḥanan, son of Rava, says Rav says: There are twenty-four non-kosher birds. Rav Ḥanan bar Rav Ḥisda said to Rav Ḥisda, From where If of Leviticus there are twenty If of Deuteronomy there are twenty-one And if you would say: Add da’a , which is written in Leviticus but is not written in Deuteronomy, to still there are twenty-two.
llm_translation: Rav Hanan son of Rav Chisda said, Rav Chisda said, Rav Hanan son of Rava's son said, Rav said: "There are twenty-four impure birds." Rav Hanan son of Rav Chisda said to Rav Chisda: Wherever it is called twenty, whether in Leviticus or in the Torah, it is twenty-one. And if you say that the one mentioned in Leviticus is not mentioned in the Torah, leave it, for they are twenty-two.

hebrew_text: אמר ליה הכי אמר אבוה דאמך משמיה דרב (ויקרא יא, יד) למינה למינה למינו (דברים יד, טו) למינהו הרי כאן ארבע אי הכי עשרין ושית הוו אמר אביי דאה וראה אחת היא דאי סלקא דעתך תרתי אינון
human_translation: said to him: This your mother’s father, said in the name of Rav: “after its kinds,” “after its kinds,” “after its kinds,” “after its kinds,” Here, are four If so, there are twenty-six, Abaye said: da’a and ra’a are one As, if it enters your mind that they are two
llm_translation: He said to him, so said the father of your mother in the name of Rav (Leviticus 11:14) "according to its kind, according to its kind, according to its kind" (Deuteronomy 14:15) "according to its kind." Here we have four, if so, there were twenty-six. Abaye said: "This is a proof, and see, there is only one, for if you think there are two of them."

hebrew_text: מכדי משנה תורה לאוסופי הוא דאתא מאי שנא הכא דכתיב דאה ומ"ש הכא דכתיב ראה ולא כתיב דאה אלא ש"מ מין ראה ודאה אחת היא
human_translation: Since Deuteronomy comes to add what is different here, that it is written: “ Da’a ,” what is different here, that it is written: “ Ra’a ,” and da’a is not written? Rather, conclude from ra’a and da’a are one species.
llm_translation: From the fact that the Mishneh Torah states "to gather," what is the difference here that it is written "see," and what is the difference here that it is written "see" and not written "gather"? Rather, we can infer that "see" and "gather" are one and the same.

hebrew_text: ואכתי כ"ה הוו אמר אביי כשם שראה ודאה אחת היא כך איה ודיה אחת היא דאי ס"ד תרתי אינון מכדי משנה תורה לאוסופי הוא דאתא מאי שנא הכא דכתיב למינה אאיה ומ"ש התם דכתיב למינה אדיה אלא ש"מ איה ודיה אחת היא
human_translation: But still, there are twenty-five Abaye said: Just as ra’a and da’a are one so ayya and dayya , are one As, if it enters your mind that they are two Since Deuteronomy comes to add what is different here, that it is written: “After its kinds,” about ayya , and what is different there, that it is written: “After its kinds,” about dayya ? Rather, learn from ayya and dayya are one
llm_translation: And thus, when twenty-five cases were discussed, Abaye said: Just as seeing and certainty are one, so too, searching and certainty are one. For if you think there are two types, since the Mishnah is the end conclusion of the Torah, what is the difference here that it is written "to its kind" למינה for searching, and what is the difference there that it is written "to its kind" למינה for certainty? Rather, you must conclude that searching and certainty are one.

hebrew_text: וכי מאחר שאיה ודיה אחת היא למה ליה למיכתב איה ודיה כדתניא רבי אומר אקרא אני איה דיה למה נאמרה כדי שלא תתן פתחון פה לבעל דין לחלוק שלא תהא אתה קורא איה והוא קורא דיה אתה קורא דיה והוא קורא איה לכך כתב במשנה תורה (דברים יד, יג) והראה ואת האיה והדיה למינה
human_translation: And now that ayya and dayya are one why did to write ayya and dayya As it is taught Rabbi says: I will read ayya Why is dayya stated? so as not to give a claim to a litigant to disagree, it should not occur you call an ayya and he calls a dayya you call a dayya and he calls an ayya Therefore, writes in Deuteronomy: “And the ra’a , and the ayya , and the dayya after its kinds”
llm_translation: And when since it is one, why for him to write one? It is one, why for him to write one? As it was taught: Rabbi says, "I will read 'one,' why was it said 'one'? So that you do not give an opening to the litigant to divide, that you should not read 'one' while he reads 'one,' you read 'one' while he reads 'one.' Therefore it is written in the Torah (Deuteronomy 14:13), 'And he shall show the one and the other according to its kind.'"

hebrew_text: מיתיבי למה נשנו בבהמה מפני השסועה ובעופות מפני הראה מאי לאו מדבהמה דהתם לאוסופי עופות נמי לאוסופי לא התם לאוסופי הכא לפרושי
human_translation: raises an objection Why of animals repeated? due to the shesua And of birds due to the ra’a . What, is it not from that animals there, to add birds also to add No, there, to add, here, to explain.
llm_translation: The Talmudic text: It was asked: Why were cattle specified regarding the issue of deviation, and birds regarding the issue of appearance? What, is it not because there, in the case of cattle, they are not gathered together, so too, in the case of birds, they are not gathered together? There, regarding cattle, it is for tithing purposes; here, regarding birds, it is for separation purposes.

hebrew_text: ופליגא דרבי אבהו דא"ר אבהו ראה זו איה ולמה נקרא שמה ראה שרואה ביותר וכן הוא אומר (איוב כח, ז) נתיב לא ידעו עיט ולא שזפתו עין איה תנא עומדת בבבל ורואה נבלה בארץ ישראל
human_translation: And differs from Rabbi Abbahu, as Rabbi Abbahu says: ra’a is ayya . And why is it called ra’a ? Since it sees [ ro’ah ] most And so states: “That path no bird of prey knows, neither has the eye of the ayya seen it” taught: stand in Babylonia and see a carcass in Eretz Yisrael.
llm_translation: And it is in dispute of Rabbi Abahu, for Rabbi Abahu said: "See this is the vulture, and why is it called by this name? Because it sees exceedingly well." And so it says (Job 28:7): "The path no bird of prey knows, nor has the falcon's eye seen it." Where is she standing? In Babylon, and she sees carrion in the land of Israel.

hebrew_text: מדראה היינו איה מכלל דדאה לאו היינו ראה מכדי משנה תורה לאוסופי הוא דאתא מאי שנא הכא דכתיב דאה ומאי שנא התם דלא כתיב דאה אלא לאו ש"מ דאה וראה ואיה אחת היא
human_translation: Since ra’a is ayya , by inference, that da’a is not the ra’a ; since Deuteronomy comes to add what is different here, that it is written: “ Da’a ,” what is different there, that da’a is not written? Rather, not conclude from da’a and ra’a and ayya are one
llm_translation: From the beginning, this is where "Ayeh" is derived from the general category of "Da'ah." Is it not the case that "Da'ah" is not the same as "Ra'ah"? Since it is derived from the Mishneh Torah, it is for the purpose of adding. What is the difference here that it is written "Da'ah"? And what is the difference there that it is not written "Da'ah," but rather "Lo"? Conclude from here that "Da'ah" and "Ra'ah" are one and the same.

hebrew_text: ומדראה היינו איה מכלל דדיה לאו היינו איה מאי שנא התם דכתיב למינהו אאיה ומ"ש הכא דלא כתיב למינהו אאיה אלא אדיה אלא ש"מ דאה וראה דיה ואיה אחת היא
human_translation: And from ra’a is ayya , by inference, dayya is not ayya . What is different there, that it is written: “After its kinds,” about ayya , and what is different here, that it is not written: “After its kinds,” about ayya but about dayya ? Rather, learn from da’a and ra’a , dayya and ayya are one
llm_translation: "And from its generation, this is it. From the inference that it is not its, this is not it. What is the difference there that it is written 'from it' and what is different here that it is not written 'from it' but 'its'? Rather, from here we learn that 'it' and 'its' are one."

hebrew_text: תניא איסי בן יהודה אומר מאה עופות טמאין יש במזרח וכולן מין איה הן תני אבימי בריה דר' אבהו ז' מאות מיני דגים הן וח' מאות מיני חגבים ולעופות אין מספר עופות כ"ד הוו אלא ולעופות טהורים אין מספר
human_translation: it is taught Isi ben Yehuda says: There are one hundred non-kosher birds in the East, and they are all species of ayya . Avimi, son of Rabbi Abbahu, taught: There are seven hundred types of fish, and eight hundred types of grasshopper, and there are countless birds. birds? there are twenty-four Rather, And there are countless kosher birds.
llm_translation: It was taught: Issi ben Yehuda says, "There are one hundred species of impure birds in the east, and all of them are of the species of 'Ayah.'" Where are they? Avimi, son of R. Abbahu, taught: There are seven hundred species of fish and eight hundred species of locusts, and as for birds, their number is not counted, except for pure birds, whose number is twenty-four.

hebrew_text: תניא רבי אומר גלוי וידוע לפני מי שאמר והיה העולם שבהמה טמאה מרובה מן הטהורות לפיכך מנה הכתוב בטהורה גלוי וידוע לפני מי שאמר והיה העולם שעופות טהורין מרובין על הטמאין לפיכך מנה הכתוב בטמאין
human_translation: It is taught Rabbi says: It is revealed and known before the One Who spoke and the world came into being that non-kosher animals are more numerous than the kosher Therefore, the Torah lists the kosher it is revealed and known before the One Who spoke and the world came into being that kosher birds are more numerous than the non-kosher Therefore, the Torah lists the non-kosher
llm_translation: It was taught: Rabbi says, "It is revealed and known before the One who spoke and the world came into being that there are more impure animals than pure ones. Therefore, the Scripture enumerates the pure ones. It is revealed and known before the One who spoke and the world came into being that there are more pure birds than impure ones. Therefore, the Scripture enumerates the impure ones."

hebrew_text: מאי קמ"ל כדרב הונא אמר רב ואמרי לה אמר רב הונא אמר רב משום ר' מאיר לעולם ישנה אדם לתלמידו דרך קצרה
human_translation: What is teaching us? As Rav Huna says Rav and some say Rav Huna says Rav says in the name of Rabbi Meir: A person should always teach his student in a concise manner,
llm_translation: What is the meaning of "as Rav Huna said, Rav said, and some say it was Rav Huna who said it in the name of Rabbi Meir: A person should always teach his student in a concise manner."

hebrew_text: א"ר יצחק עוף טהור נאכל במסורת נאמן הצייד לומר עוף זה טהור מסר לי רבי א"ר יוחנן והוא שבקי בהן ובשמותיהן
human_translation: Rabbi Yitzḥak says: A kosher bird may be eaten on a tradition the hunter is deemed credible to say: My teacher conveyed to me this bird is kosher. Rabbi Yoḥanan said: And this when is familiar with and with their names.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yitzchak: A pure bird may be eaten with a reliable tradition from the hunter saying, "This bird is pure." Rabbi Yochanan said, "And he is proficient in them and their names."

hebrew_text: בעי ר' זירא רבו חכם או רבו צייד ת"ש דא"ר יוחנן והוא שבקי בהן ובשמותיהן אי אמרת בשלמא רבו צייד שפיר אלא אי אמרת רבו חכם בשלמא שמייהו גמיר להו אלא אינהו מי ידע להו אלא לאו ש"מ רבו צייד ש"מ
human_translation: Rabbi Zeira raises a dilemma: teacher the Sage, or his teacher the hunter, Come hear which Rabbi Yoḥanan said: And this when is familiar with them and with their names. Granted, if you say his teacher the hunter, well. But if you say his teacher the Sage, granted, their names, he has learned them, but does he recognize themselves? Rather, not conclude from it his teacher the hunter? conclude from it
llm_translation: Rabbi Zeira asked: Is it preferable for one's teacher to be a scholar or a hunter? Come and hear what Rabbi Yochanan said: "And he left them and their names." If you say it is better for one's teacher to be a hunter, it is well; but if you say it is better for one's teacher to be a scholar, can they remember their names? Rather, they do not know them. Therefore, conclude from this that it is better for one's teacher to be a hunter.

hebrew_text: ת"ר לוקחין ביצים מן העובדי כוכבים בכל מקום ואין חוששין לא משום נבלות ולא משום טרפות
human_translation: The Sages taught One may buy eggs from the gentiles anywhere, and one not concerned, neither with regard to carcasses, nor with regard to tereifot ,
llm_translation: The Sages taught: One may purchase eggs from idolaters in any place, and there is no concern either for them being carrion or for them being torn.

hebrew_text: ודילמא דעוף טמא נינהו אמר אבוה דשמואל באומר של עוף פלוני טהור ולימא של עוף טהור אי הכי אית ליה לאישתמוטי
human_translation: But perhaps they a non-kosher bird. Shmuel’s father said: to says of such and such bird, kosher. But let him say of a kosher bird. If so, he has deflect
llm_translation: Perhaps the bird is impure, said the father of Shmuel in the name of Abaye: "The offering of such-and-such a bird is pure." And let him say, "The offering of a pure bird." If so, he has room to retract.

hebrew_text: ולבדוק בסימנין דתניא כסימני ביצים כך סמני דגים סימני דגים ס"ד סנפיר וקשקשת אמר רחמנא אלא אימא כך סימני
human_translation: But Let him inspect for signs, as it is taught Like the signs of eggs, so the signs of fish. enter your mind the signs of fish? The Merciful One states “Fins and scales” Rather, say: So the signs of
llm_translation: To examine with signs as it was taught: Just as the signs of eggs, so too the signs of fish. The signs of fish - a thorn and a scale. The Merciful One said, rather say, thus are the signs.

hebrew_text: עוברי דגים
human_translation: fish embryos,
llm_translation: Translating the Talmudic text "עוברי דגים" into English word-for-word: "Transgressors of fish"

hebrew_text: ותניא גבי ביצים אלו הן סימני ביצים כל שכודרת ועגולגולת ראשה אחד כד וראשה אחד חד טהורה ב' ראשיה כדין או ב' ראשיה חדין טמאין חלבון מבחוץ וחלמון מבפנים טהורה חלמון מבחוץ וחלבון מבפנים טמאה חלמון וחלבון מעורבין זה בזה בידוע שהיא ביצת השרץ
human_translation: And it is taught about eggs these are the signs of eggs: Any that narrows and is rounded, one of its ends is rounded and one of its ends is pointed, is kosher. both of its ends are rounded or both of its ends are pointed, non-kosher. albumen on the outside and yolk on the inside, kosher. yolk on the outside and albumen on the inside, non-kosher. yolk and albumen are mixed with each other, it is certainly the egg of a creeping animal.
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita regarding eggs: These are the signs of eggs - any egg that is rounded and has one head, whether its head is like this or its head is like that, it is pure. If it has two heads like this or two heads like that, it is impure. Its white is on the outside and its yolk is on the inside - it is pure. Its yolk is on the outside and its white is on the inside - it is impure. If its yolk and white are mixed together, it is known that it is the egg of a creeping creature.

hebrew_text: לא צריכא דחתוכות וליבדוק בחלמון וחלבון בטרופות בקערה
human_translation: No, necessary cut But let him inspect the yolk and the albumen, with mixed in a bowl,
llm_translation: Not necessary to cut and check in Chalmon and Chalvon in the troughs in a bowl.

hebrew_text: וכה"ג מי זבנינן מינייהו והא תניא אין מוכרין ביצת טרפה לעובד כוכבים אלא א"כ טרופה בקערה לפיכך אין לוקחין מהם ביצים טרופות בקערה
human_translation: But in a case like this, may we buy from them? Isn’t it taught One may sell the egg of a tereifa to a gentile only if it is mixed in a bowl; therefore, one may not buy eggs mixed in a bowl from them,
llm_translation: And so we have learned from them. But isn't it taught: One may not sell a treifah egg to a non-Jew unless it is cracked? Therefore, one should not buy treifah eggs from them if they are cracked.

hebrew_text: אלא אמר ר' זירא סימנין לאו דאורייתא דאי לא תימא הכי הא דאמר רב אסי שמנה ספיקות הן ליבדוק בביצים דידהו אלא ש"מ סימנין לאו דאורייתא
human_translation: Rather, Rabbi Zeira said: signs are not by Torah law. As, if you do not say so, that which Rav Asi says: There are eight uncertain. Let one inspect their eggs Rather, learn from it signs are not by Torah law
llm_translation: Rather, Rabbi Zeira said: Signs are not from the Torah. For if you do not say so, this is what Rav Assi said: There are eight doubts to check in their eggs. Rather, infer from this that signs are not from the Torah.

hebrew_text: אלא למאי הלכתא קתני לה הכי קאמר ב' ראשיה כדין או ב' ראשיה חדין או חלמון מבחוץ וחלבון מבפנים ודאי טמאה רישיה חד חד רישיה חד כד וחלבון מבחוץ וחלמון מבפנים ואמר לך של עוף פלוני וטהור הוא סמוך עליהם בסתמא לא תסמוך עליהם דאיכא דעורבא דדמי לדיונה
human_translation: But with regard to what halakha is teaching This is saying: both of its ends are rounded, or both its ends are pointed, or yolk on the outside and albumen on the inside, certainly non-kosher. one of its ends is pointed one of its ends is rounded, and albumen on the outside and yolk on the inside, and says to you from such and such bird, and is kosher, rely on no specification do not rely on them, since there are crow’s that resemble those of a pigeon.
llm_translation: Rather, for what halakha does it teach thus? This is what it is saying: Whether its two heads are like this or its two heads are like that, or if the ḥalmun is on the outside and the ḥalvon is on the inside, it is certainly impure. If one of its heads is like this and one of its heads is like that, and the ḥalvon is on the outside and the ḥalmun is on the inside, and it tells you that the specific bird is pure, rely on them in general, do not rely on them, for there is a crow that resembles a raven.

hebrew_text: אמר מר חלבון וחלמון מעורבין זה בזה בידוע שהיא ביצת השרץ למאי הלכתא אמר רב עוקבא בר חמא לומר שאם ריקמה וניקבה (בכעדשה מטמא)
human_translation: The Master said: albumen and yolk are mixed with each other, it is certainly the egg of a creeping animal For what halakha Rav Ukva bar Ḥama said: to say that if tissue developed [ rikema ] and it was perforated, it transmits ritual impurity that of a lentil-bulk,
llm_translation: The Master said: "Chelevon and Chalmon are mixed together, it is known that it is the egg of a sheretz." What is the halacha? Rav Ukva bar Chama said: To say that if it was emptied and punctured (in the size of a lentil), it is impure.

hebrew_text: מתקיף לה רבינא ודלמא דנחש היא אלא אמר רבא שאם ריקמה ואכלה לוקה עליה משום שרץ השורץ על הארץ
human_translation: Ravina objects to this: But perhaps it is of a snake, Rather, Rava said: that if tissue developed and one ate it, he is flogged on its account, due to swarming thing that swarms upon the earth
llm_translation: Ravina objects to this: But perhaps it is like the snake! Rather, Rava said: If she made herself empty and ate, she is punished because of the creeping thing that creeps upon the earth.

hebrew_text: אי הכי מאי איריא דטמאה אפילו דטהורה נמי דתניא (ויקרא יא, מא) כל השרץ השורץ על הארץ
human_translation: If so, why specifically of a non-kosher even of a kosher as well. as it is taught “Every swarming thing that swarms upon the earth,”
llm_translation: If so, what is the difference between impure and even pure? As it was taught (Leviticus 11:41), "Every swarming thing that swarms upon the earth."

hebrew_text: לרבות אפרוחים שלא נפתחו עיניהם מדרבנן וקרא אסמכתא בעלמא
human_translation: to include chicks whose eyes have not opened by rabbinic and the verse a mere support
llm_translation: To include chicks that their eyes did not open from Rabbinic decree, and he cited a mere support.

hebrew_text: תנו רבנן גיעולי ביצים מותרות ביצים מוזרות נפש יפה תאכלם נמצא עליה קורט דם זורק את הדם ואוכל את השאר
human_translation: The Sages taught eggs boiled permitted. Unfertilized eggs strong constitution may eat them, a drop [ koret ] of blood is found on it, discards the blood, and eats the rest.
llm_translation: The Sages taught: Regular eggs are permitted, strange eggs, a beautiful soul shall eat them. If a clot is found on them, one should remove the clot, discard the blood, and eat the rest.

hebrew_text: אמר רבי ירמיה והוא שנמצא על קשר שלה תני דוסתאי אבוה דר' אפטוריקי לא שנו אלא שנמצא על חלבון שלה אבל נמצא על חלמון שלה אפי' ביצה אסורה מאי טעמא דשדא תכלא בכולה א"ל רב גביהה מבי כתיל לרב אשי איפכא תני תנא קמיה דאביי ואביי הוא דתרצה ניהליה הכי
human_translation: Rabbi Yirmeya said: And this when is found on its knot, taught Dostai, father of Rabbi Aptoriki: taught only when is found on its albumen, but it is found on its yolk, even the egg is forbidden. What is the reason that the decay has spread through all of it. Rav Geviha from Bei Ketil said to Rav Ashi: A tanna taught the opposite before Abaye, and it is Abaye that corrected it this
llm_translation: Rabbi Yirmiyah said, and it is found on her girdle, Dosetai, the father of Rabbi Aptoriki, taught: They only said if it is found on her milk duct, but if it is found on her womb, even an egg is prohibited. What is the reason? Because she absorbs it all. Rav Gavyah said to Rav Ashi from the house of Katil, reverse it. A Tanna taught before Abaye, and Abaye was pleased with it thus.

hebrew_text: אמר חזקיה מנין לביצת טמאה שהיא אסורה מן התורה שנאמר (ויקרא יא, טז) ואת בת היענה וכי בת יש לה ליענה אלא איזו זו ביצה טמאה ודלמא היינו שמייהו לא סלקא דעתך דכתיב (איכה ד, ג) בת עמי לאכזר כיענים במדבר
human_translation: Ḥizkiyya says: From where that the egg of a non-kosher is prohibited by Torah As it is stated: “And the daughter [ bat ] of the ya’ana ” But does the ya’ana have a daughter Rather, which This is a non-kosher egg. But perhaps this is their name, should not enter your mind, as it is written: “The daughter of my people has become cruel, like the ye’enim in the wilderness”
llm_translation: Said Hezekiah: From where do we derive that a ritually impure egg is prohibited by Torah law? As it is stated (Leviticus 11:16), "And the ostrich." But does an ostrich have a daughter named Ya'ana? Rather, which is this? An impure egg. And perhaps this is their name. Is it not your opinion that it is written (Lamentations 4:3), "The daughter of my people has become cruel, like ostriches in the wilderness"?

hebrew_text: ולא והא כתיב (מיכה א, ח) אעשה מספד כתנים ואבל כבנות יענה כיענה זו שמתאבלת על בניה והא כתיב (ישעיהו יג, כא) ושכנו שם בנות יענה כיענה זו ששוכנת עם בניה
human_translation: And not But isn’t it written: “I will make a wailing like the jackals, and a mourning like the daughters [ benot ] of the ya’ana ” like this ya’ana that mourns for its children. But isn’t it written: “And benot ya’ana shall dwell there” like this ya’ana that dwells with its children.
llm_translation: "And not, but is it not written (Micah 1:8), 'I will make a lament like jackals and mourning like ostriches'? 'Like ostriches' - this refers to one who mourns for her children. And is it not written (Isaiah 13:21), 'And its dwellings shall be filled with howling, and the daughters of ostriches shall dwell there'? 'Daughters of ostriches' - this refers to one who dwells with her children."

hebrew_text: והכתיב (ישעיהו מג, כ) תכבדני חית השדה תנים ובנות יענה ואי סלקא דעתך ביצה ביצה בת מימר שירה היא אלא כתיב היענה וכתיב בת היענה
human_translation: But isn’t it written: “The animals of the field shall honor Me, the jackals and the benot ya’ana ” And if it enters your mind an egg, can an egg sing a song Rather, The ya’ana is written, and the bat ya’ana is written,
llm_translation: And it is written (Isaiah 43:20), "The beast of the field shall honor Me, the jackals and the ostriches." And if you wish to say, "egg by egg, the daughter of the ostrich is a song," it is not so, but it is written "the ostrich" and it is written "the daughter of the ostrich."

hebrew_text: ושאני הכא דפסק ספרא לשתי תיבות ומדפסיק להו ספרא
human_translation: And here is different that the scribe splits into two words: And from that the scribe splits it
llm_translation: And different is the case here, for he divided the book into two sections, and he divided the book for them.

hebrew_text: בתרתי תיבות ש"מ תרי שמות נינהו
human_translation: into two words, conclude from it they are two names,
llm_translation: In the two words "Shem," there are two names.

hebrew_text: אלא מעתה (בראשית יד, ד) את כדר לעומר דפסק להו ספרא בתרי הכי נמי דתרתי שמי נינהו אמרי התם בשתי תיבות פסיק להו בשני שיטין לא פסיק להו אבל הכא אפי' בשני שיטין נמי פסיק להו:
human_translation: If that is so, “Chedorlaomer” which the scribe splits in two also that they are two names? They say There, splits into two words, may not split it into two lines But here, he may split even into two lines,
llm_translation: Rather now (Genesis 14:4) "the measure of the omer," that the book concluded for them two matters, so too, these are two names. They said there in the Bible with two words it concluded for them, with two rows it did not conclude for them. But here, even with two rows, it also concluded for them.

hebrew_text: אבל אמרו חכמים כל עוף [וכו']: תניא רבן גמליאל אומר דורס ואוכל בידוע שהוא טמא יש לו אצבע יתירה וזפק וקרקבנו נקלף בידוע שהוא טהור ר"א בר' צדוק אומר מותחין לו חוט של משיחה אם חולק את רגליו שתים לכאן ושתים לכאן טמא שלש לכאן ואחת לכאן טהור ר"ש בן אלעזר אומר כל עוף הקולט מן האויר טמא
human_translation: But the Sages stated any bird It is taught Rabban Gamliel says: claws and eats is certainly non-kosher. it has an extra digit and a crop, and its gizzard can be peeled, it is certainly kosher. Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Tzadok, says: One stretches a line, If it splits its feet two here and two there, non-kosher. three here and one there, kosher. Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: Any bird that catches out of the air is non-kosher.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: But the sages said: "Every bird etc.." It was taught: Rabban Gamliel says, if it pecks and eats with the knowledge that it is impure, it has an extra finger and a crop, and its gizzard is peeled, with the knowledge that it is pure. Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Tzadok, says: They stretch out a thread of crimson wool for it; if it divides its feet, two here and two there, it is impure; three here and one there, it is pure. Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: Every bird that collects from the air is impure.

hebrew_text: ציפרתא נמי מקלט קלטה אמר אביי קולט ואוכל קאמרי
human_translation: tziparta also catches Abaye said: We say catches and eats
llm_translation: The Talmudic text translates as follows: "Tsiparta also serves as a refuge." Abaye said: They say, "One may take and eat."

hebrew_text: אחרים אומרים שכן עם טמאים טמא עם טהורים טהור
human_translation: Others say: dwells with non-kosher non-kosher; with kosher kosher.
llm_translation: Others say: "So is with the impure, impure; with the pure, pure."

hebrew_text: כמאן כר' אליעזר דתניא ר"א אומר לא לחנם הלך זרזיר אצל עורב אלא מפני שהוא מינו אפי' תימא רבנן שכן ונדמה קאמרינן:
human_translation: In accordance with whose in accordance with Rabbi Eliezer, as it is taught Rabbi Eliezer says: not for naught zarzir went with the crow, but because it is species. You even say the Rabbis, We say dwells and resembles
llm_translation: Like whom is this opinion? Like Rabbi Eliezer, as it was taught: Rabbi Eliezer says, "The sparrow did not go to the raven for nothing, but because it is of its kind." Even if you say it was the Rabbis who said this, it is so, and it appears that we are saying this.

hebrew_text: ובחגבים כל שיש לו כו': מאי רובו אמר רב יהודה אמר רב רוב ארכו ואמרי לה רוב הקיפו אמר רב פפא הלכך בעינן רוב ארכו ובעינן רוב הקיפו
human_translation: And with regard to grasshoppers, any that has What most of its Rav Yehuda said Rav said: Most of its length. And some say Most of its circumference. Rav Pappa said: Therefore, We require most of its length, and we require most of its circumference.
llm_translation: In locusts, anything it has, etc.: What is its majority? Rav Yehudah said Rav said: Its majority is its length. And some say: Its majority is its circumference. Rav Pappa said: Therefore, we require its majority in length and we require its majority in circumference.

hebrew_text: ת"ר אין לו עכשיו ועתיד לגדל לאחר זמן כגון הזחל מותר ר"א בר' יוסי אומר (ויקרא יא, כא) אשר לא כרעים אף על פי שאין לו עכשיו ועתיד לגדל לאחר זמן מאי זחל אמר אביי אסקרין
human_translation: The Sages taught has no now but will grow after a time, e.g., the zaḥal , is permitted. Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yosei, says: which have [ lo ] jointed legs even though it has no now but will grow after a time, What zaḥal ? Abaye said: askarin
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: If it does not have fins now but will grow them later, such as a caterpillar, it is permitted. Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Yosi, says: "Which have not fins" (Leviticus 11:21) - even though it does not have fins now but will grow them later. What is the caterpillar? Abaye said: an ascaris.

hebrew_text: ת"ר (ויקרא יא, כב) את אלה מהם תאכלו את הארבה וגו' ארבה זה גובאי סלעם זה רשון חרגול זה ניפול חגב זה גדיאן מה ת"ל (ויקרא יא, טו) למינו למינהו למינהו למינהו ד' פעמים להביא ציפורת כרמים ויוחנא ירושלמית והערצוביא והרזבנית
human_translation: The Sages taught “These of them you may eat: The arbeh arbeh is govai . solam is rashon . ḥargol is nippul . ḥagav is gadyan . Why the verse state: “After its kinds,” “after its kinds,” “after its kinds,” “after its kinds,” four times? It is to include vineyard bird, and Jerusalem yoḥana , and the artzuveya , and the razbanit ,
llm_translation: The Sages taught: "Of them you may eat: the locust, etc." (Leviticus 11:22). Locust - this is the arbeh; grasshopper - this is the sol'am; cricket - this is the chargol; and locust - this is the chagav. What is the teaching of the verse: "According to its kind, according to its kind, according to its kind, of the four times" (Leviticus 11:15)? To include the vineyard tziporet, the Jerusalem yochana, the aratzovya, and the razvaniya.

hebrew_text: דבי ר' ישמעאל תנא אלו כללי כללות ואלו פרטי פרטות ארבה זה גובאי למינו להביא
human_translation: The school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: These are generalizations, and these are details. arbeh is govai , “after its kinds” to include
llm_translation: The school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: These are general principles and these are specific details. Four this is the rule to bring.

hebrew_text: ציפורת כרמים
human_translation: vineyard bird,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: ציפורת כרמים English translation: Tsiporet Karmim

hebrew_text: אין לי אלא הבא ואין לו גבחת הבא ויש לו גבחת מנין ת"ל (ויקרא יא, כב) סלעם זה ניפול למינהו להביא את האושכף
human_translation: I have only that comes and does not have a smooth forehead From where that comes and has a smooth forehead The verse states: “ Solam ,” this is nippul , “after its kinds” to include the ushkaf ,
llm_translation: I have nothing but the one who comes, and he does not have a gavachat. The one who comes has a gavachat. How do we know? It teaches (Leviticus 11:22), "Their carcass falls upon its kind, to bring the oshef."

hebrew_text: ואין לי אלא הבא ואין לו גבחת הבא ויש לו גבחת הבא ואין לו זנב הבא ויש לו זנב מנין ת"ל חרגול זה רשון למינהו להביא את הכרספת ואת השחלנית
human_translation: And I have only that comes and does not have a smooth forehead, that comes and has a smooth forehead, comes and has no tail, From where that comes and has a tail The verse states: “ Ḥargol ,” this is rashon , “after its kinds” to include the karsefet and the shaḥlanit ,
llm_translation: "And I have only the one that comes, and it does not have a gullet; the one that comes has a gullet, and it does not have a tail; the one that comes has a tail. From where do we derive this? The verse states, 'The locust after its kind, the bald locust after its kind, the cricket after its kind, and the grasshopper after its kind.'"

hebrew_text: ואין לי אלא הבא ואין לו גבחת הבא ויש לו גבחת הבא ואין לו זנב הבא ויש לו זנב הבא ואין ראשו ארוך הבא וראשו ארוך מנין
human_translation: And I have only that comes and does not have a smooth forehead, that comes and has a smooth forehead, that comes and has no tail, that comes and has a tail, that comes and its head is not long, From where that comes and its head is long
llm_translation: "And I have nothing except the one that comes, and it does not have a hump; the one that comes has a hump, and it does not have a tail; the one that comes has a tail; and its head is long. How do we know that its head is long?"

hebrew_text: אמרת הרי אתה דן בנין אב משלשתן לא ראי ארבה כראי חרגול ולא ראי חרגול כראי ארבה ולא ראי שניהם כראי סלעם ולא ראי סלעם כראי שניהם הצד השוה שבהן שיש לו ד' רגלים וארבע כנפים וקרצולים וכנפיו חופין את רובו אף כל שיש לו ארבע רגלים וארבע כנפים וקרצולים וכנפיו חופין את רובו
human_translation: You say: You derive a paradigm from the three of them, The aspect [ re’i ] of arbeh , is not similar to the aspect of ḥargol , and the aspect of ḥargol is not similar to the aspect of arbeh . And the aspect of neither of them is similar to the aspect of solam , and the aspect of solam is similar to neither of their aspects. Their common denominator is that has four legs, and four wings, and jumping legs, and its wings cover most of its So too, any that has four legs, and four wings, and jumping legs, and its wings cover most of its
llm_translation: You said: Behold, you judge the building of a father from three of them; the sight of a locust is not like the sight of a grasshopper, and the sight of a grasshopper is not like the sight of a locust, and the sight of both is not like the sight of a lizard, and the sight of a lizard is not like the sight of both. The common feature in them is that they have four legs, four wings, and antennae, and their wings cover their majority. So too, any creature that has four legs, four wings, and antennae, and its wings cover its majority.

hebrew_text: והלא הצרצור הזה יש לו ארבע רגלים וד' כנפים וקרצולים וכנפיו חופין את רובו יכול יהא מותר ת"ל חגב ששמו חגב
human_translation: But doesn’t this tzartzur have four legs, and four wings, and jumping legs, and its wings cover most of its might it should be permitted. the verse states: “ Ḥagav ,” that its name ḥagav .
llm_translation: And behold, this locust has four legs and four wings and antennae, and its wings cover most of its body. One might have thought it is permitted, therefore the Torah teaches: "Locust," whose name is locust.

hebrew_text: אי שמו חגב יכול אין בו כל הסימנין הללו ת"ל למינהו עד שיהא בו כל הסימנין הללו
human_translation: if its name ḥagav , might it does not have all these signs. the verse states: “After its kinds,” unless it has all these signs.
llm_translation: If his name is grasshopper, one might think it lacks all these signs; therefore, the verse teaches to include all these signs in it.

hebrew_text: פריך רב אחאי מה להנך שכן אין ראשן ארוך וכי תימא כיון דשוו בד' סימנין מייתינן ולא פרכינן אי הכי חרגול נמי דשוו להו לא ליכתוב ותיתי מארבה וסלעם
human_translation: Rav Aḥai refutes What about these in that their heads are not long. And if you would say: Since they share four signs, we include and we do not refute if so, should not even write ḥargol , which shares with and let it be derived from the arbeh and solam .
llm_translation: Rav Ahai posed a question: What about those animals whose front legs are not long? And if you will say, since they have the four signs we bring them as sacrifices, yet we do not ask this question? If so, the locust should also not be written in the list of kosher animals, for it also has the four signs: it comes from the locust and its types.

hebrew_text: אלא איכא למיפרך מה להנך שכן אין להן זנב ה"נ איכא למיפרך מה להנך שכן אין ראשן ארוך
human_translation: Rather, could be refuted What about these, in that they have no tail. So too, can be refuted What about these, in that their heads are not long.
llm_translation: Rather, there is to refute: "What about those that do not have a tail?" So too, there is to refute: "What about those that do not have a long head?"

hebrew_text: אלא אמר רב אחאי סלעם יתירא הוא לא ליכתוב רחמנא סלעם ותיתי מארבה ומחרגול דמאי פרכת מה לארבה דאין לו גבחת הרי חרגול דיש לו גבחת מה לחרגול דיש לו זנב הרי ארבה דאין לו זנב סלעם דכתב רחמנא ל"ל אם אינו ענין לגופו תנהו ענין לראשו ארוך
human_translation: Rather, Rav Aḥai said: solam is redundant. Let the Merciful One not write solam , and let it be derived from arbeh and ḥargol , As what can you refute What from arbeh , which, does not have a smooth forehead; But ḥargol , which has a smooth forehead. What from ḥargol , which, has a tail, But arbeh , which has no tail. why do I solam that the Merciful One wrote? if is not for the matter itself, apply it matter of a long-headed
llm_translation: Rather, Rav Achai said: "It is an extra stone." The Merciful One did not write "stone" but rather "ant" and "grasshopper." Regarding a wall, what about an ant that does not have a neck? Behold, a grasshopper that has a neck. What about a grasshopper that has a tail? Behold, an ant that does not have a tail. The stone that the Merciful One wrote about, if it is not relevant to its body, apply it to its long head.

hebrew_text: במאי קמיפלגי תנא דבי רב ותנא דבי רבי ישמעאל בראשו ארוך קמיפלגי
human_translation: With regard to what do the tanna of the study hall, and the tanna of the school of Rabbi Yishmael disagree? They disagree with regard to whose head is long.
llm_translation: With what do they disagree? One Tanna of the school of Rav and one Tanna of the school of Rabbi Yishmael, the son of Rabbah, disagree.

hebrew_text: תנא דבי רב סבר אשר לו כרעים כלל ארבה סלעם חרגול חגב למינהו פרט כלל ופרט אין בכלל אלא מה שבפרט דמיניה אין דלאו דמיניה לא ומרבי דדמי ליה משני צדדין
human_translation: The tanna of the study hall holds “which have jointed legs” a generalization. arbeh , solam , ḥargol , ḥagav , “after its kinds,” a detail. a generalization and a detail, the generalization includes only that which is in the detail. of the species as are that are not of the species as not And amplifies that are similar to in two aspects,
llm_translation: The Tanna of the school of Rav holds: "That which has hind legs in general, includes the locust, the bald locust, the cricket, and their kinds." "Exclude the general and include the specific; and the specific only includes that which is similar to it. If it is not similar to it, then it is not included." And Rabbi adds: "He learns from two sides."

hebrew_text: תנא דבי ר' ישמעאל סבר אשר לו כרעים כלל ארבה סלעם חרגול חגב פרט למינהו חזר וכלל כלל ופרט וכלל אי אתה דן אלא כעין הפרט ומרבי כל דדמי ליה בחד צד
human_translation: the tanna of the school of Rabbi Yishmael holds “which have jointed legs” a generalization. arbeh , solam , ḥargol , ḥagav detail. “after its kinds” it then generalized a generalization, and a detail, and a generalization, you may deduce only similar to the detail. And amplifies any that is similar to in one aspect,
llm_translation: The Tanna of the school of Rabbi Yishmael holds: "That which has hind legs in general, includes the locust, the bald locust, the cricket, except for its own kind." He then went back and included everything in general, and then specified, and then included again. You can only judge it according to the specific category, and we increase all that is similar to it on one side.

hebrew_text: והא לא דמי כללא קמא לכללא בתרא כללא קמא אשר לו כרעים אמר רחמנא דאית ליה אכול דלית ליה לא תיכול כללא בתרא עד דשוו בארבעה סימנין
human_translation: But The first generalization is not similar to the latter generalization. the first generalization, the Merciful One states: “Which have jointed legs,” eat that has you may not eat that does not have the latter generalization: unless it shares four signs
llm_translation: The text reads as follows: "And is it not similar to the first general principle to the latter general principle? The first general principle, which has legs, the Merciful One said that it may be eaten; if it does not have legs, it may not be eaten at all until it is examined with four signs."

llm_translation: Not this and not this in its father, and not difficult, this in a cow, this in a tree itself.

hebrew_text: דיקא נמי דקתני תולעת שבעיקרי זיתים ושבעיקרי גפנים ש"מ
human_translation: is also precise, as it teaches: Worms that are in the roots of olive trees and in the roots of vines, Learn from it
llm_translation: Precisely also that it teaches: "A worm in the roots of olive trees and in the roots of grapevines." Learn from this.

hebrew_text: בעי רב יוסף פרשה ומתה מהו מקצתה מהו לאויר העולם מהו תיקו
human_translation: Rav Yosef raises a dilemma: emerged but died what is part of it what is into the air of the world what is shall stand
llm_translation: Rav Yosef inquired: "Regarding a Parsha that has died, what is the status of its portion? What about for the atmosphere of the world? What is the resolution?"

hebrew_text: בעי רב אשי לגג תמרה מהו לגג גרעינתה מהו מתמרה לתמרה מהו תיקו
human_translation: Rav Ashi raises a dilemma: onto the roof of date, what is what is onto the roof of pit? from a date a date what is shall stand
llm_translation: Rav Ashi inquired: Regarding the roof of a date-palm tree, what is the law? Regarding its kernel, what is the law? Regarding one date-palm tree to another, what is the law? The matter remains unresolved.

hebrew_text: אמר רב ששת בריה דרב אידי קוקיאני אסירי מאי טעמא מעלמא אתו
human_translation: Rav Sheshet, son of Rav Idi, says: Kukeyanei , forbidden. What is the reason they came from world,
llm_translation: Rav Sheshet, son of Rav Idi, said: "Kukyanians are forbidden. What is the reason? They come from a forbidden place."

hebrew_text: מתקיף לה רב אשי אי מעלמא אתו לישתכחו דרך בית הריעי
human_translation: Rav Ashi objects to this: If they came from world, they should be found in the digestive tract
llm_translation: Rav Ashi objects: If they come from the world, let them forget the way to the house of the shepherd.

hebrew_text: איכא דאמרי אמר רב שישא בריה דרב אידי קוקיאני שרו מאי טעמא מיניה גבלי אמר רב אשי פשיטא דאי מעלמא קא אתו לישתכחו דרך בית הריעי
human_translation: Some state Rav Sheisha, son of Rav Idi, says: Kukeyanei are permitted. What is the reason they originate from Rav Ashi said: obvious, as if they came from world, they should be found in the digestive tract.
llm_translation: There are those who say, Rav Shisha, son of Rav Idi the Cook, permitted something. What is the reason? Because they the Sages separated from him. Rav Ashi said: It is obvious, for if they had come from the world, they would have forgotten the path of the house of the shepherd.

hebrew_text: והלכתא קוקיאני אסירי מ"ט מינם ניים ועיילי ליה באוסייה תולעים דרני דבשרא אסירי דכוורי שריין
human_translation: And the halakha Kukeyanei are forbidden. What is the reason sleeps, and worms enter it through its snout. Worms meat are forbidden; fish are permitted.
llm_translation: The Halakha of the Kukianites: Why are their types of wine sweet, and they bring it with wormwood, which is forbidden, and the types of meat of a weasel are permitted.

hebrew_text: אמר לה רבינא לאימיה אבלע לי ואנא איכול א"ל רב משרשיא בריה דרב אחא לרבינא מאי שנא מהא דתניא (ויקרא יא, יא) ואת נבלתם תשקצו לרבות את הדרנים שבבהמה
human_translation: Ravina said to his mother: Conceal and I will eat Rav Mesharshiyya, son of Rav Aḥa, said to Ravina: What is different from that which is taught “Their carcasses you shall have in detestation” to include worms that are in animals
llm_translation: Ravina said to his mother, "Swallow for me, and I will eat." Rav Mesharshya, son of Rav Acha, said to Ravina, "What is the difference from what is taught: 'And you shall abominate their carcasses' (Leviticus 11:11) to include the tendons of an animal."

hebrew_text: א"ל הכי השתא בהמה בשחיטה הוא דמשתריא והני מדלא קא מהניא להו שחיטה באיסורייהו קיימן אבל דגים באסיפה בעלמא מישתרי והני כי קא גבלן בהיתרא קא גבלן
human_translation: said to him: How can be compared? An animal is rendered permitted by slaughter. And since slaughter is not effective for these they retain their forbidden But fish are rendered permitted by merely gathering And when these originate they originate in a permitted
llm_translation: He said to him: So now, regarding an animal in slaughter, it is where it becomes permitted, and these, since they are not benefiting from the slaughter in their prohibition, they remain. But fish in a gathering, in general, become permitted, and these, when they are confined in their permission, are confined.

hebrew_text: ת"ר (ויקרא יא, מב) הולך על גחון זה נחש כל לרבות השילשול ואת הדומה לשילשול על ארבע זה עקרב כל הולך לרבות את החיפושית ואת הדומה לחיפושית מרבה רגלים זה נדל עד כל לרבות את הדומה ואת הדומה לדומה
human_translation: The Sages taught “goes upon the belly” snake. “whatever” to include earthworm and similar to an earthworm. “upon all fours” scorpion. “whatever goes” to include the beetle and similar to a beetle. “has many feet” centipede. “or whatever” to include similar and similar to those similar to
llm_translation: The Sages taught: "Walking upon the belly" - this includes the snake, to include all types of serpents, and that which resembles a serpent. "Upon four" - this includes the scorpion, to include all types of scorpions, and that which resembles a scorpion. "Having many legs" - this includes the lizard, to include all types of lizards, and that which resembles a lizard.

hebrew_text: תניא ר' יוסי בן דורמסקית אומר לויתן דג טהור הוא שנאמר (איוב מא, ז) גאוה אפיקי מגנים (איוב מא, כב) תחתיו חדודי חרש אפיקי מגנים אלו קשקשים שבו תחתיו חדודי חרש אלו סנפירין שפורח בהן:
human_translation: It is taught Rabbi Yosei ben Durmaskit says: leviathan is a kosher fish, as it is stated: “His armor is his pride” “Sharpest potsherds are under him” “his armor” his scales, “sharpest potsherds are under him” fins with which he swims,
llm_translation: It was taught: Rabbi Yosei ben Darmaskit says, "The Leviathan is a pure fish, as it is stated (Job 41:7), 'Pride is on his back' (Job 41:15), 'Underneath are rows of sharp potsherds' - 'Pride is on his back' refers to the scales on it, 'Underneath are rows of sharp potsherds' refers to the fins that sprout from it."

hebrew_text: הדרן עלך אלו טרפות
llm_translation: We will return to you regarding these treifot.

hebrew_text: מתני׳ בהמה המקשה לילד והוציא העובר את ידו והחזירו מותר באכילה הוציא את ראשו אע"פ שהחזירו הרי זה כילוד
human_translation: an animal was encountering difficulty giving birth and the fetus extended its foreleg and brought it back consumption permitted extended its head even if it brought it back that like a newborn,
llm_translation: Mishnah: An animal that is difficult to give birth and one who removes the fetus by hand, and returns it, it is permitted for consumption. If one removes its head, even though he returns it, it is considered as if it were born.

hebrew_text: חותך מעובר שבמעיה מותר באכילה מן הטחול ומן הכליות אסור באכילה זה הכלל דבר שגופה אסור ושאינה גופה מותר:
human_translation: severs from a fetus that is in womb consumption permitted of the spleen or of the kidneys consumption prohibited, This is the principle: An item that is body prohibited and that is not its body, permitted
llm_translation: Cuts a fetus in its mother's womb - permitted for consumption from the spleen and from the kidneys - forbidden for consumption. This is the principle: a matter whose body is forbidden, and one whose body is not forbidden - permitted.

hebrew_text: גמ׳ אמר רב יהודה אמר רב ואבר עצמו אסור
human_translation: Rav Yehuda says Rav says: But the limb itself, prohibited,
llm_translation: Gemara: Rav Yehudah said in the name of Rav, "And a bone itself is forbidden."

hebrew_text: מאי טעמא דאמר קרא (שמות כב, ל) ובשר בשדה טרפה לא תאכלו כיון שיצא בשר חוץ למחיצתו נאסר
human_translation: What is the reason as the verse states: “And flesh, in the field, a tereifa , you shall not eat” Once flesh has gone outside of its boundary, it becomes prohibited,
llm_translation: What is the reason that the verse says (Exodus 22:30), "And flesh in the field, torn by beasts, you shall not eat"? Once the flesh has left its boundary, it becomes prohibited.

hebrew_text: תנן בהמה המקשה לילד והוציא העובר את ידו והחזירו מותר באכילה מאי לאו אאבר לא אעובר
human_translation: We learned an animal was encountering difficulty giving birth and the fetus extended its foreleg but brought it back, consumption permitted What, not referring to the limb, No, referring to fetus,
llm_translation: We learned: An animal that is difficult to give birth and it brought out the fetus, its limb, and it returned it, it is permitted for consumption. What, is it not a limb and not a fetus?

hebrew_text: אי אעובר מאי איריא החזירו אפילו לא החזירו נמי הוא הדין אף על גב דלא החזירו ואיידי דקא בעי מיתנא סיפא הוציא את ראשו אף על פי שהחזירו הרי זה כילוד תנא נמי רישא החזירו
human_translation: If referring to fetus, why specifically brought back Even not bring it back The same is true, even if did not bring back But since wants to teach the latter clause: extended its head, even though it brought it back, that like a newborn he also taught the first clause brought back
llm_translation: If he transgressed, what is the difference? He returned it, even if he did not return it, it is the same. Even though he did not return it, and since the latter clause is necessary to teach: "He removed his head," even though he returned it, this is considered as if it were born. The first clause also states: "He returned it."

hebrew_text: וסיפא מאי קמשמע לן דכיון דיצא ראשו הויא לה לידה תנינא איזהו בכור לנחלה ואינו בכור לכהנים הבא אחר נפלים אף על פי שיצא ראשו חי או בן ט' שיצא ראשו מת
human_translation: And latter clause what does it teach us? that once extended its head, that is a birth? we learned Who is a firstborn with regard to inheritance but is not a firstborn with regard to the priests? who came after miscarriage even if its head emerged alive, or nine- -old whose head emerged dead.
llm_translation: The end, what does it teach us? Since his head emerged, it is considered a birth for her. We learned: Who is a firstborn for inheritance but not a firstborn for the priests? One who comes after a miscarriage, even though his head emerged alive or a nine-month fetus, if his head emerged dead.

hebrew_text: טעמא דראשו מת הא ראשו חי הבא אחריו בכור לנחלה נמי לא הוי
human_translation: The reason that head dead. But its head alive, born after him would not be a firstborn even with regard to inheritance.
llm_translation: Reason of his head died, his head alive, the one coming after him also not be firstborn for inheritance.

hebrew_text: וכי תימא אשמעינן באדם וקא משמע לן בבהמה
human_translation: And if you would say teaches us with regard to a person, and teaches us to an animal,
llm_translation: And if you will say, "We hear the law regarding a man, and it implies to us the law regarding an animal."

hebrew_text: דאדם מבהמה לא יליף דאין פרוזדור לבהמה ובהמה מאדם לא ילפא דחשיב פרצוף פנים דידיה
human_translation: Because a person cannot be derived from of an animal, as an animal does not have a concealed opening [ prozdor ] And an animal cannot be derived from a person, as the form of face is significant
llm_translation: Man from animal not learns, for no foresight in animal, and animal from man not learns, for considered face of his own.

hebrew_text: הא נמי תנינא שליא שיצתה מקצתה אסורה באכילה כסימן ולד באשה כך סימן ולד בבהמה
human_translation: this also, we learned part of a placenta emerged consumption prohibited as an indication of a fetus in a woman, so too, an indication of a fetus in an animal.
llm_translation: This also we learned: a fetus that emerged partially is forbidden for consumption, a sign that a son will be born to a woman, similarly a sign that a son will be born to an animal.

hebrew_text: אי אמרת בשלמא החזירו דרישא דוקא תנא סיפא אטו רישא
human_translation: Granted, if you say brought back in the first clause specifically taught the latter clause due to the first clause,
llm_translation: If you say, "Granted, the first part makes sense, specifically the Mishnah; the latter part, however, does not."

hebrew_text: אלא אי אמרת לא דרישא דוקא ולא דסיפא דוקא למה ליה למתנייה כלל
human_translation: But if you say the first clause not specifically and the latter clause is not specifically why does it to teach at all?
llm_translation: Rather, if you say not the beginning specifically and not the end specifically, why did he need to teach it at all?

hebrew_text: לא לעולם אעובר וכדאמר רב נחמן בר יצחק לא נצרכה אלא למקום חתך הכא נמי לא נצרכה אלא למקום חתך
human_translation: No; actually, referring to fetus, but similar to that which Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said, necessary only with regard to the location of a cut Here too, necessary only with regard to the location of the cut,
llm_translation: Not forever I will pass, and as Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak said, it was not necessary except for the place where it was cut. Here too, it was not necessary except for the place where it was cut.

hebrew_text: ת"ש בהמה המקשה לילד הוציא עובר את ידו והחזירה ואחר כך שחט את אמו מותר באכילה שחט את אמו ואחר כך החזירה אסור באכילה
human_translation: Come hear an animal was encountering difficulty giving birth, the fetus extended its foreleg and then brought it back and afterward one slaughtered its mother, consumption permitted one slaughtered its mother, and afterward return its consumption prohibited.
llm_translation: Come and hear: An animal that is difficult to give birth, if it brought out its fetus and then returned it, and afterwards its mother was slaughtered, it is permitted for consumption. If it slaughtered its mother and then returned the fetus, it is forbidden for consumption.

hebrew_text: הוציא את ידו וחתכו ואח"כ שחט את אמו שבחוץ טמא ואסור ושבפנים טהור ומותר
human_translation: extended its foreleg and cut it and afterward one slaughtered its mother, that was outside ritually impure and prohibited, And that was inside ritually pure and permitted
llm_translation: He extended his hand and cut it, and afterwards he slaughtered his mother, outside - impure and forbidden, and inside - pure and permitted.

hebrew_text: שחט את אמו ואחר כך חתכו
human_translation: one slaughtered its mother and afterward cut off
llm_translation: He slaughtered his mother and afterwards he cut her.

hebrew_text: הבשר מגע נבלה דברי רבי מאיר
human_translation: the flesh contact with a carcass. the statement of Rabbi Meir.
llm_translation: The flesh that touches a carcass - the words of Rabbi Meir.

hebrew_text: וחכמים אומרים מגע טרפה שחוטה
human_translation: And the Rabbis say: contact with a slaughtered tereifa .
llm_translation: And the sages say: "Touching a treifah is considered as if it were slaughtered."

hebrew_text: קתני מיהא רישא הוציא עובר את ידו והחזירה ואחר כך שחט את אמו מותר באכילה מאי לאו אאבר לא אעובר
human_translation: In any event, the first clause teaches: the fetus extended its foreleg and then brought it back and afterward one slaughtered its mother, consumption permitted. What, is it not to the limb, No, is referring to the fetus.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: From the beginning, he extended his hand and then withdrew it, and afterwards he slaughtered his mother, he is permitted to eat. What, is it not a limb of a living animal that he did not transgress.

hebrew_text: אי אעובר אימא סיפא שחט את אמו ואחר כך החזירו אסור באכילה ואי עובר אמאי אסור
human_translation: If is referring to fetus, say the latter clause: one slaughtered its mother, and afterward returned its consumption prohibited. And if fetus, why prohibited
llm_translation: If he transgressed, say the latter part: if one slaughters his mother and then returns her, it is forbidden to eat. And if he did not transgress, why is it forbidden?

hebrew_text: כדאמר רב נחמן בר יצחק לא נצרכה אלא למקום חתך הכא נמי לא נצרכה אלא למקום חתך
human_translation: similar to that which Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said, necessary only with regard to the location of the cut Here too, necessary only with regard to the location of the cut,
llm_translation: As Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak said: It was only necessary for the place where it was cut. Here too, it was only necessary for the place where it was cut.

hebrew_text: איני והא כי אתא אבימי מבי חוזאי אתא ואייתי מתניתא בידיה פרסה החזיר אכול פרסות החזיר אכול מאי לאו החזיר פרסה אכול פרסה
human_translation: Is that so? But when Avimi came from Bei Ḥozai he came and brought a baraita with him: returned hoof one may eat, hooves one may eat. What, is it not brought back hoof one may eat hoof, hooves one may eat
llm_translation: I am not convinced, but when Avimi came from the house of Huzai, he came and brought a Mishnah in his hand: "The pig, its hooves are split, it is unclean; its hooves are split, it is unclean." What, is it not enough that the pig's hooves are split, that it is unclean?

hebrew_text: לא החזיר פרסה אכול עובר אי עובר מאי איריא החזיר אפילו לא החזיר נמי אמר רב נחמן בר יצחק לא נצרכה אלא למקום חתך
human_translation: No, brought back hoof one may eat fetus If fetus, why does it specifically brought back Even not bring back Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said necessary only with regard to the location of the cut
llm_translation: The text reads as follows: "He did not return the leg, the eater is transgressing. If he transgresses, what is the relevance of 'he did not return'? Even if he did not return, Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak also said: It is only necessary for the place of the cut."

hebrew_text: והא תרי קראי קא נסיב לה מאי לאו חד לאבר וחד למקום חתך לא חד למקום חתך וחד לקלוט במעי פרה
human_translation: But adduces two verses, What, is it not one to limb, and one to location of the cut, No; one to location of the cut, but one to non-cloven hooves [ kalut ] inside the womb of a cow
llm_translation: And this: two verses it is derived from. What, is it not one for the limb and one for the place it was cut? Not one for the place it was cut and one for the absorbing in the womb of the cow.

hebrew_text: ואליבא דרבי שמעון דאמר רבי שמעון קלוט בן פרה אסור ה"מ היכא דיצא לאויר העולם אבל במעי אמו שרי
human_translation: And according to of Rabbi Shimon, as Rabbi Shimon says: non-cloven hooves born from a cow forbidden, this matter where emerged into the airspace of the world, But inside its mother’s womb
llm_translation: And according to Rabbi Shimon who said, Rabbi Shimon says: "A calf born through a caesarean section is forbidden." What is the reason? Because it has emerged into the open air of the world. But while in its mother's womb, it is permitted.

hebrew_text: עולא אמר רבי יוחנן ואבר עצמו מותר
human_translation: Ulla Rabbi Yoḥanan says: And limb itself is permitted
llm_translation: Ula said, Rabbi Yochanan said, "And a limb itself is permitted."

hebrew_text: אמר ליה רב יהודה לעולא והא רב ושמואל דאמרי תרוייהו אבר עצמו אסור אמר ליה מאן יהיב לן מעפרא דרב ושמואל ומלינן עיינין אלא הכי אמר רבי יוחנן הכל היו בכלל (שמות כב, ל) בשר בשדה טרפה לא תאכלו
human_translation: Rav Yehuda said to Ulla: But Rav and Shmuel both say limb itself is prohibited; said to him: Who will give us of the dust of Rav and Shmuel and we will fill our eyes But this Rabbi Yoḥanan says: all was included “And flesh, in the field, a tereifa , you shall not eat”
llm_translation: He said to him, Rav Yehudah to Ula, "But didn't Rav and Shmuel both say that a limb of its own is forbidden?" He said to him, "Who will give us the dust of Rav and Shmuel, and we will analyze it? Rather, this is what Rabbi Yochanan said: All were included in the verse (Exodus 22:30), 'You shall not eat flesh torn in the field.'"

hebrew_text: כשפרט לך הכתוב גבי חטאת שיצתה חוץ למחיצתה וחזרה אסור חטאת הוא דפרט רחמנא בה אבל כל מילי כיון דהדור שרי
human_translation: Once verse applies for you specifically with regard to a sin offering, that went outside of its boundary and returned prohibited that the Merciful One specifically applied to a sin offering. But all items once brought back permitted,
llm_translation: When the verse specifies regarding the sin offering that it went outside its boundary and then returned, it is prohibited. It is a sin offering that the Merciful One specified with it. But all other matters, once it has returned, are permitted.

hebrew_text: מיתיבי בשר בשדה טרפה לא תאכלו מה תלמוד לומר לפי שמצינו במעשר שני ובכורים שאף על פי שיצאו חוץ למחיצתן וחזרו מותרין יכול אף זה כן תלמוד לומר טרפה
human_translation: raises an objection “And flesh, in the field, a tereifa , you shall not eat,” Why the verse state Since we find with regard to second tithe and first fruits that even though they went outside of their boundary, are brought back they are permitted, might that also this it is so, the verse states: “A tereifa .”
llm_translation: The scholars raised an objection: "Do not eat the flesh in the field of a treifah." What is the teaching to say? Because we find regarding the Second Tithe and Firstborns that even if they went out beyond their boundary and returned, they are permitted. One might have thought the same applies here as well. Therefore, the teaching states "treifah."

hebrew_text: מאי תלמודא אמר רבה כטרפה מה טרפה כיון שנטרפה שוב אין לה היתר אף בשר כיון שיצא חוץ למחיצתו שוב אין לו היתר תיובתא דעולא תיובתא
human_translation: What is the derivation Rabba said: like a tereifa . Just as a tereifa , once is mortally wounded, it can no longer regain a permitted status, so too flesh Once it has gone outside of its boundary it can no longer regain permitted The refutation of Ulla a conclusive refutation.
llm_translation: What is Talmud? Rabbah said: Like a treifah. What is a treifah? Once it is treifah, it no longer has permission. So too, meat, once it goes outside its boundary, it no longer has permission. The refutation of Ula is a refutation.

hebrew_text: אמר מר לפי שמצינו במעשר שני ובכורים היכן מצינו
human_translation: The Master said: Since we find with regard to second tithe and first fruits Where did we find
llm_translation: The Master said: "Because we find in the Second Tithe and Firstborns, where do we find?"

hebrew_text: דכתיב (דברים יב, יז) לא תוכל לאכול בשעריך מעשר דגנך וגו' בשעריך הוא דלא תיכול אבל יצאו חוץ למחיצתן וחזרו מותרין
human_translation: that it is written: “You may not eat within your gates the tithe of your grain, within your gates, you may not eat But went outside of their boundary, and were brought back, they are permitted.
llm_translation: As it is written (Deuteronomy 12:17), "You may not eat within your gates the tithe of your grain, etc." "Within your gates" is where you may not eat, but once they have gone outside their boundaries and returned, they are permitted.

llm_translation: In the West, they taught thus: Rav said, "There is childbirth for the Hebrews," and Rabbi Yochanan said, "There is no childbirth for the Hebrews."

llm_translation: What is the difference between them? There is a difference between them to teach the minority of a limb that is inside.

llm_translation: The question was asked to them regarding the words of one who says, "There is no birth for limbs," if the fetus extended its hand and then retracted it, and then extended its hand again and retracted it until it completed its majority, what is the ruling? Do we say that the majority has emerged for him, or perhaps since he retracted, he retracts again?

hebrew_text: אם תמצי לומר כיון דהדר הדר הוציא עובר את ידו וחתכה וחזר והוציא את ידו וחתכה עד שהשלימו לרובו מהו מי אמרינן הא נפיק ליה רובא או דלמא רובא בבת אחת בעינן
human_translation: If you want to say since it brought back brought back fetus extended its foreleg and severed it, and again it extended its foreleg and severed it, until constituted the majority of what is Do we say majority has left Or perhaps, we require a majority simultaneously,
llm_translation: If you want to say, since he returned, he removed his hand and it was cut, and then he returned and removed his hand until he completed the majority of it, what is the law? Do we say that the majority was removed, or perhaps we require the majority to be removed in one go?

hebrew_text: תא שמע

llm_translation: This is the principle: A matter whose essence is forbidden, and if its essence is not forbidden, it is permitted. If its essence is not to bring it, what is it not to bring? Like this.

llm_translation: Not to include a fetus in the belly of a cow, and according to Rabbi Shimon, even though Rabbi Shimon said a fetus of a cow is forbidden, these words apply only when it has emerged into the world, but while in its mother's womb, it is permitted.

Or perhaps with regard to this issue it is not considered a partition, for the partition of a fetus is its mother.

human_translation: Does first siman combine with the second siman to render pure from a carcass or not? Rava said: an a fortiori If first siman was effective to second siman to permit for consumption, will it not be effective to render it pure from a carcass?
llm_translation: Who combines the first sign with the second sign to purify it immediately from a carcass or not? Rava said: It is equal. If the first sign was effective to permit it for consumption, it will not be effective to purify it from a carcass.

llm_translation: If so, even if one cuts from the spleen and from the kidneys, why then did we learn: One who cuts from the fetus in its mother's womb is permitted to eat from the spleen and from the kidneys, he is forbidden to eat from them? Scripture said: "It is complete and not lacking."

hebrew_text: אלא מעתה השוחט את הבהמה ומצא בה דמות יונה תשתרי אלמה אמר רבי יוחנן השוחט את הבהמה ומצא בה דמות יונה אסור באכילה
human_translation: If that is so, one who slaughters an animal and finds a dove-shaped in it, it should be permitted. Why, does Rabbi Yoḥanan say: One who slaughters an animal and finds a dove-shaped in it, prohibited for consumption?
llm_translation: Rather now, one who slaughters the animal and finds in it the form of a dove, what is the law? Rabbi Yochanan said: One who slaughters the animal and finds in it the form of a dove is forbidden for consumption.

hebrew_text: בעינא פרסות וליכא
human_translation: I require hooves, does not have
