llm_translation: And what is different about this, that you should eat the heart of a cabbage? What is the reason? This one has the prohibition in its eye, and that one does not have the prohibition in its eye.

hebrew_text: ההוא בר גוזלא דנפל לכדא דכמכא שרייה רב חיננא בריה דרבא מפשרוניא אמר רבא מאן חכים למישרי כי האי גוונא אי לאו רב חיננא בריה דרבא מפשרוניא קסבר כי אמר שמואל מליח הרי הוא כרותח הני מילי היכא דאינו נאכל מחמת מלחו אבל האי כותחא הרי נאכל מחמת מלחו
human_translation: a certain young bird that fell into a jug of kamka , Rav Ḥinnana, son of Rava of Pashronya, permitted Rava said Who is wise to permit cases like this, if not Rav Ḥinnana, son of Rava of Pashronya? He maintains when Shmuel said a salted like a boiling that statement that it is not eaten due to its salt, but this kutaḥ eaten due to, its salt.
llm_translation: The son of Gozla who fell into a vat of vinegar, Rav Chinana, son of Rava from Pashronya, permitted it. Rava said, "Who is wise to permit such a thing? If not for Rav Chinana, son of Rava from Pashronya, who holds that when Shmuel said 'salty,' it is like boiling, these words apply where it is not edible due to its saltiness. But this vinegar is edible due to its saltiness."

hebrew_text: והני מילי חי אבל צלי בעי קליפה ואי אית ביה פילי כוליה אסור ואי מתבל בתבלין כוליה אסור
human_translation: And this statement raw, but roasted, it requires peeling And if it has cracks [ pilei ], it is entirely forbidden, And if it has been flavored with spices it is entirely forbidden,
llm_translation: And these matters are alive, but if roasted, it requires peeling. And if it contains a worm, it is entirely forbidden. And if it is seasoned with spices, it is entirely forbidden.

hebrew_text: אמר רב נחמן אמר שמואל ככר שחתך עליה בשר אסור לאכלה והני מילי דאסמיק והני מילי דאבריה והני מילי דאסמכיה אבל קלישתא לית לן בה
human_translation: Rav Naḥman said Shmuel says: It is prohibited to eat a loaf upon which one cut meat, And this statement if is ruddy And this statement if it passed through And this statement if is viscous. But runny, we have no with it,
llm_translation: Rav Nachman said in the name of Shmuel: A loaf upon which meat has been cut is forbidden to eat. These are the words that he reasoned, and these are the words that he spoke, and these are the words that he supported. But a thin crust we do not have concerning it.

hebrew_text: שמואל שדי ליה לכלביה רב הונא יהיב ליה לשמעיה מה נפשך אי שרי לכולי עלמא שרי אי אסור לכולי עלמא אסור שאני רב הונא דאנינא דעתיה רבא אכיל ליה וקרי ליה חמר בשר
human_translation: Shmuel would throw to his dog Rav Huna would give it to his attendant. Whichever way you If is permitted, it is permitted for everyone, if it is prohibited, then it is prohibited for everyone, Rav Huna is different, as he is of delicate constitution Rava would eat and he would call meat wine.
llm_translation: Shmuel granted it to his dog. Rav Huna gave it to Shemaya. "What is your opinion? If it is permitted to everyone, it is permitted. If it is forbidden to everyone, it is forbidden." Rav Huna said: "I am different, for I am Rav Huna, the son of Raba." He fed him and called him a donkey.

hebrew_text: אמר רב נחמן אמר שמואל אין מניחין כלי תחת בשר עד שיכלה כל מראה אדמומית שבו מנא ידעינן מר זוטרא משמיה דרב פפא אמר משתעלה תימרתו
human_translation: Rav Naḥman says Shmuel says: One may not place a vessel under meat until all the ruddiness of appearance has dissipated. How do we know Mar Zutra said in the name of Rav Pappa: As soon as its smoke rises,
llm_translation: Rav Nachman said in the name of Shmuel: One does not place a vessel beneath meat until all the redness in it has been absorbed. How do we know this? Mar Zutra in the name of Rav Papa said: "When its fat goes up."

hebrew_text: מתקיף לה רב אשי ודלמא תתאה מטא עילאה לא מטא אלא אמר רב אשי לית ליה תקנתא אלא משדא ביה תרתי גללי מלחא
human_translation: Rav Ashi objects to this: But perhaps the underside roasted, upper not roasted Rather, Rav Ashi said: has no remedy except place two lumps of salt in it,
llm_translation: Rav Ashi objects: But perhaps if it is lower it does not reach higher? Rather, Rav Ashi said: It does not have a remedy except by placing two lumps of salt in it.

hebrew_text: ומשפייה
human_translation: And tilt it
llm_translation: And Meshapya.

hebrew_text: אמר ליה רב אחא בריה דרב איקא לרב אשי ומי אמר שמואל הכי והאמר שמואל ככר שחתך עליה בשר אסור לאכלה שאני התם דאגב דוחקא דסכינא פליט
human_translation: Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ika, said to Rav Ashi: And did Shmuel say this, But didn’t Shmuel say: It is prohibited to eat a loaf upon which one cut meat? is different there, as due to the pressure of the knife expels
llm_translation: Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ika, said to Rav Ashi, "Did Shmuel really say so?" But didn't Shmuel say, 'If one cuts meat on a loaf, it is forbidden to eat it'? It is different there, because of the pressure of the knife, it is exempt.

hebrew_text: אמר רב נחמן דגים ועופות שמלחן זה עם זה אסורין היכי דמי אי בכלי שאינו מנוקב אפי' עופות ועופות נמי אסירי אי בכלי מנוקב אפי' דגים ועופות נמי שרי
human_translation: Rav Naḥman says: one salted fish and birds together, are prohibited What are the circumstances If in an unperforated vessel, even a bird and bird prohibited, if a perforated vessel, even fish birds permitted.
llm_translation: Rav Nachman said: Fish and birds that were salted together are prohibited. What is the case? If it is in an unperforated vessel, even birds with birds are also prohibited. If it is in a perforated vessel, even fish and birds are permitted.

hebrew_text: לעולם בכלי מנוקב ודגים משום דרפו קרמייהו קדמי ופלטי ועופות קמיטי בתר דניחי דגים פליטי עופות והדר בלעי מיניה
human_translation: Actually, to a perforated vessel. And fish because their skin is soft, they expel first, whereas birds hard. After fish finish birds expel and then absorb from them.
llm_translation: Always in a perforated vessel and fish, because they soften their bones in front of it, and birds harden them behind it. After the fish are placed, birds are placed, and then it swallows them.

hebrew_text: רב מרי בר רחל אימלח ליה בשר שחוטה בהדי בשר טרפה אתא לקמיה דרבא
human_translation: Meat of a slaughtered was salted for Rav Mari bar Raḥel together with meat of an animal that had a wound that would have caused it to die within twelve months [ tereifa ], He came before Rava
llm_translation: Rav Mari bar Rachel mixed meat of a slaughtered animal with the meat of a treifah animal before Rava.

hebrew_text: אמר ליה (ויקרא יא, כו) הטמאים לאסור צירן ורוטבן וקיפה שלהן
human_translation: said to him: the unclean to prohibit their juice and their gravy, and their spices
llm_translation: He said to him (Leviticus 11:26), "The impure ones prohibit their eggs and their offspring and their nest."

hebrew_text: ולימא ליה מדשמואל דאמר שמואל מליח הרי הוא כרותח וכבוש הרי הוא כמבושל
human_translation: But let say to of Shmuel, as Shmuel said: A salted like a boiling and a marinated is as a cooked
llm_translation: And let him say to him, from Shmuel who said, Shmuel said: Salty is like boiling, and pickled is like cooked.

hebrew_text: אי מדשמואל הוה אמינא הני מילי דמן אבל צירן ורוטבן לא קמשמע לן
human_translation: Had on Shmuel’s I would say This statement the blood of but not the juices and gravy of teaches us
llm_translation: If from Shmuel, I would say these matters are from Avail Tziran and Rotben, we do not accept.

hebrew_text: מיתיבי דג טהור שמלחו עם דג טמא מותר מאי לאו שהיו שניהן מלוחין לא כגון שהיה טהור מליח וטמא תפל
human_translation: raises an objection A kosher fish that one salted with a non-kosher fish is permitted. What, is it not where they were both salted No, where kosher salted and non-kosher unsalted.
llm_translation: The scholars raised an objection: a kosher fish that was salted together with a non-kosher fish is permissible. What is the reason? Is it not because both of them were salted? Not like a case where the kosher fish was salted and the non-kosher fish was not.

hebrew_text: והא מדקתני סיפא (אבל אם היה טהור מליח וטמא תפל) מכלל דרישא בששניהם מלוחין עסקינן פרושי קא מפרש טהור שמלחו עם דג טמא מותר כיצד שהיה טהור מליח וטמא תפל
human_translation: But from that the latter clause teaches: But if kosher was salted and non-kosher unsalted it may be inferred that the first clause we are dealing with where they are both salted. is explaining A kosher that one salted with a non-kosher fish is permitted. How so? if kosher was salted and non-kosher unsalted.
llm_translation: And this is difficult from the teaching of the latter part (but if it was pure salty and impure it shall be nullified). From the inference of the former part, we are dealing with both salty. He is explaining explicitly: pure that became salty with impure fish is permissible. How so? If it was pure salty and impure it shall be nullified.

hebrew_text: ה"נ מסתברא דאי סלקא דעתך רישא שניהם מלוחים השתא שניהם מלוחים שרי טהור מליח וטמא תפל מיבעיא
human_translation: So, too, it is reasonable as if it enters your mind the first clause both of them are salted, Now both of them are salted permitted, is necessary kosher salted and non-kosher unsalted?
llm_translation: So it is reasoned: if according to your opinion, initially both were salty, now both are salty, it is permitted - pure salt and impure salt, it is necessary to ask.

hebrew_text: אי משום הא לא איריא תנא סיפא לגלויי רישא דלא תימא רישא טהור מליח וטמא תפל אבל שניהם מלוחין אסור תנא סיפא טהור מליח וטמא תפל מכלל דרישא שניהן מלוחין ואפ"ה שרי
human_translation: If it is due to that there is no argument. taught the latter clause to shed light on the first clause, that you not say: The first clause kosher salted and non-kosher unsalted, but both salted, prohibited. taught the latter clause, kosher salted and non-kosher unsalted, by inference that the first clause both salted, and even so permitted.
llm_translation: If because of this, it is not fitting, a Tanna taught: the latter part is revealed from the former, so you should not say the former is pure and the latter is impure, but rather both are salty, it is forbidden. A Tanna taught: the latter is pure and the former is impure, implying that both are salty, yet it is permitted.

hebrew_text: ת"ש מסיפא דסיפא אבל אם היה טמא מליח וטהור תפל אסור טמא מליח וטהור תפל הוא דאסור הא שניהן מלוחין שרי
human_translation: Come hear from the latter clause of the latter clause, But if non-kosher was salted and kosher unsalted, prohibited. it is non-kosher salted and kosher unsalted that prohibited. But both salted, permitted,
llm_translation: Come and hear: from the latter clause of the former clause - but if it was ritually impure and salty, and ritually pure, it is forbidden. Ritually impure and salty, and ritually pure, it is forbidden - it is the latter that is forbidden, but if both are salty, it is permitted.

hebrew_text: איידי דתנא רישא טהור מליח וטמא תפל תנא נמי סיפא טמא מליח וטהור תפל
human_translation: since teaches the former clause, kosher salted and non-kosher unsalted, taught the last clause as well non-kosher salted and kosher unsalted,
llm_translation: Since the Tanna taught in the beginning that tahor is salty and tamei is insipid, the Tanna also taught in the end that tamei is salty and tahor is insipid.

hebrew_text: (סימן בישרא דמנח נפקותא)
human_translation: a mnemonic meat; that is placed departs.
llm_translation: Chapter: In the city of Beisra, a dispute arose. (

hebrew_text: אמר שמואל אין הבשר יוצא מידי דמו אלא א"כ מולחו יפה יפה ומדיחו יפה יפה אתמר רב הונא אמר מולח ומדיח במתניתא תנא מדיח ומולח ומדיח ולא פליגי הא דחלליה בי טבחא הא דלא חלליה בי טבחא רב דימי מנהרדעא מלח ליה במילחא גללניתא ומנפיץ ליה
human_translation: Shmuel says: Meat cannot be rid of its blood unless one salts it thoroughly and rinses it thoroughly It was stated: Rav Huna says: salt and rinse was taught in a baraita : rinse and salt and rinse And do not disagree. This where one washed in the slaughterhouse that where one did not wash in the slaughterhouse. Rav Dimi of Neharde’a would salt with coarse salt and shake
llm_translation: Samuel said: The meat does not release its blood unless it is well salted and well rinsed. Rav Huna said: It was taught in a Mishnah - rinsing and salting, rinsing and salting, and they do not disagree, the one that was slaughtered in the butcher's house and the one that was not slaughtered in the butcher's house. Rav Dimi from Nahardea salts it with coarse salt and rinses it.

hebrew_text: אמר רב משרשיא אין מחזיקין דם בבני מעיים תרגמא אכרכשא ומעייא והדרא דכנתא
human_translation: Rav Mesharshiyya says: One does not presume blood in the intestines, interpreted to the rectum, the intestines, and the spiral colon.
llm_translation: Rav Mesharshia said: We do not hold blood in the intestines. The translation is "Akraksha, Ma'aya, and Hadra deKnata."

hebrew_text: אמר שמואל אין מניחין בשר מליח אלא ע"ג כלי מנוקב
human_translation: Shmuel says: One may place salted meat only on a perforated vessel,
llm_translation: Said Shmuel: We do not place salted meat except on a perforated vessel.

hebrew_text: רב ששת מלח ליה גרמא גרמא תרי מאי טעמא לא משום דפריש מהאי ובלע האי חד נמי פריש מהאי גיסא ובלע האי גיסא אלא לא שנא
human_translation: Rav Sheshet would salt one bone, at a time. What is the reason not two because leaves this and that absorbs one as well, leaves this side and that side absorbs Rather, is no difference
llm_translation: Rav Sheshet salted it, a bone, a bone. What is the reason? Not because he separated this one and swallowed that one, for he also separated this sinew and swallowed that sinew. Rather, it is not different.

hebrew_text: אמר שמואל משום ר' חייא השובר מפרקתה של בהמה קודם שתצא נפשה הרי זה מכביד את הבשר וגוזל את הבריות ומבליע דם באברים
human_translation: Shmuel says in the name of Rabbi Ḥiyya: One who breaks the neck of an animal before its soul departs thereby makes the meat heavy. And he robs people, he causes blood to be absorbed in the limbs,
llm_translation: Shmuel said in the name of Rabbi Chiya: "One who breaks the neck of an animal before its soul departs, this one is causing suffering to the flesh, robbing the creatures, and swallowing blood in the limbs."

hebrew_text: איבעיא להו היכי קאמר מכביד את הבשר וגוזל את הבריות משום דמבליע דם באברים הא לדידיה שפיר דמי או דלמא לדידיה נמי אסור תיקו:
human_translation: A dilemma was raised before what is he speaking? renders the meat heavy and robs people since he causes blood to be absorbed in the limbs? for himself, well Or perhaps for himself, also prohibited. shall stand
llm_translation: The question was asked to them: How does one fulfill the prohibition of "making the flesh heavy" and "robbing creatures" because he causes blood to be absorbed in the limbs? Is it considered good for him or perhaps it is also forbidden for him? This remains unresolved.

hebrew_text: מתני׳ המעלה את העוף עם הגבינה על השלחן אינו עובר בלא תעשה:
human_translation: One who places birds with cheese on the table does not violate prohibition.
llm_translation: Mishnah: One who places the bird together with the cheese on the table does not transgress a negative commandment.

hebrew_text: גמ׳ הא אוכלו עובר בלא תעשה שמע מינה בשר עוף בחלב דאורייתא אימא המעלה את העוף עם הגבינה על השולחן אינו בא לידי לא תעשה:
human_translation: consequently eats violate prohibition. learn from meat of birds in milk by Torah law, Say One who places bird meat with cheese on the table will not come to prohibition,
llm_translation: Gemara: Here, one who eats a limb from a living animal transgresses a negative commandment. Learn from this that the prohibition of eating poultry with milk is from the Torah. I might say that one who places poultry with cheese on the table does not violate a negative commandment.

hebrew_text: מתני׳ בשר בהמה טהורה בחלב בהמה טהורה אסור לבשל ואסור בהנאה בשר בהמה טהורה בחלב בהמה טמאה בשר בהמה טמאה בחלב בהמה טהורה מותר לבשל ומותר בהנאה ר"ע אומר חיה ועוף אינם מן התורה שנאמר (שמות כג, יט) לא תבשל גדי בחלב אמו ג' פעמים פרט לחיה ולעוף ובהמה טמאה
human_translation: prohibited to cook the meat of a kosher animal in the milk of kosher animal, and benefit prohibited. permitted to cook the meat of a kosher animal in the milk of a non-kosher animal, the meat of a non-kosher animal in the milk of a kosher animal, and benefit permitted. Rabbi Akiva says: an undomesticated animal or bird not by Torah law, as it is stated: “You shall not cook a kid in its mother’s milk” three times. excludes an undomesticated animal, a bird, and a non-kosher animal.
llm_translation: Mishnah: The flesh of a kosher animal in the milk of a kosher animal - it is forbidden to cook and forbidden for benefit. The flesh of a kosher animal in the milk of a non-kosher animal - the flesh of a non-kosher animal in the milk of a kosher animal - it is permitted to cook and permitted for benefit. Rabbi Akiva says: Wild animals and birds are not included in the Torah prohibition, as it is stated (Exodus 23:19), "You shall not cook a kid in its mother's milk" - three times, excluding wild animals and birds, and non-kosher animals.

hebrew_text: רבי יוסי הגלילי אומר נאמר (דברים יד, כא) לא תאכלו כל נבלה ונאמר לא תבשל גדי בחלב אמו את שאסור משום נבלה אסור לבשל בחלב עוף שאסור משום נבלה יכול יהא אסור לבשל בחלב ת"ל בחלב אמו יצא עוף שאין לו חלב אם:
human_translation: Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says it is stated: “You shall not eat of any animal carcass” and it is stated: “You shall not cook a kid in its mother’s milk.” that prohibited due to an unslaughtered carcass prohibited to cook in milk. birds, which prohibited due to an unslaughtered carcass, might would be prohibited to cook in milk. the verse states: “In its mother’s milk,” excluding a bird, which has no mother’s milk.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yosei the Galilean says: It is stated (Deuteronomy 14:21), "You shall not eat any carcass," and it is also stated, "You shall not cook a young goat in its mother's milk." Just as it is prohibited to cook poultry in milk due to the prohibition of carcass, one might have thought it is also prohibited to cook poultry in milk. Therefore, the Torah teaches us "in its mother's milk," excluding poultry which does not have milk from its mother.

hebrew_text: גמ׳ מנא הני מילי א"ר אלעזר אמר קרא (בראשית לח, כ) וישלח יהודה את גדי העזים
human_translation: From where are these matters Rabbi Elazar said: The verse states: “And Judah sent the kid of the goats”
llm_translation: Gemara: From where do we derive these matters? Rabbi Elazar said: Scripture states (Genesis 38:20), "And Judah sent the young goat."

hebrew_text: כאן גדי עזים הא כל מקום שנאמר גדי סתם אפילו פרה ורחל במשמע
human_translation: here, a kid of the goats, consequently, anywhere “kid” is stated without specification, it means even a cow or a ewe.
llm_translation: "Here, a young goat of goats. This, wherever it is stated 'young goat' without specification, even a cow and a ewe are included."

hebrew_text: ולילף מיניה כתיב קרא אחרינא (בראשית כז, טז) ואת עורות גדיי העזים כאן גדיי העזים הא כל מקום שנאמר גדי סתם אפילו פרה ורחל במשמע
human_translation: But derive from another verse is written: “And the skins of the kids of the goats” here kids of the goats, but anywhere “kid” is stated without specification, it means even a cow or a ewe.
llm_translation: And to learn from it is written another verse (Genesis 27:16) "And the skins of the kids of the goats." Here, "the kids of the goats" - but wherever it says "kid" without specification, even a cow and a ewe are implied.

hebrew_text: ולילף מיניה הוו להו שני כתובין הבאין כאחד וכל שני כתובים הבאים כאחד אין מלמדין
human_translation: But let us derive from are two verses that come as one, and any two verses that come as one do not teach
llm_translation: And to learn from it, they had two Scriptures that came together, and any two Scriptures that come together do not teach.

hebrew_text: הניחא למ"ד אין מלמדין אלא למ"ד מלמדין מאי איכא למימר תרי מיעוטי כתיבי עזים העזים
human_translation: This works out well according to the one who says do not teach but according to the one who says teach what is there to say? Two exclusions are written, Goats, “the goats,”
llm_translation: It is preferable according to the one who says: we only teach according to the one who teaches. What can be said? Two exclusions are written: "goats" - the goats.

hebrew_text: אמר שמואל גדי לרבות את החלב גדי לרבות את המתה גדי לרבות את השליל
human_translation: Shmuel says: “kid” to include fats, “kid” to include a dead “kid” to include fetus.
llm_translation: Said Shmuel: "Gedi includes goat to include its milk, gedi to include its carcass, gedi to include its placenta."

hebrew_text: גדי להוציא את הדם גדי להוציא את השליא גדי להוציא את הטמאה
human_translation: “kid” to exclude blood. “kid” to exclude the placenta “kid” to exclude a non-kosher
llm_translation: Kid to extract the blood, kid to extract the gallbladder, kid to extract the impurity.

hebrew_text: בחלב אמו ולא בחלב זכר בחלב אמו ולא בחלב שחוטה בחלב אמו ולא בחלב טמאה
human_translation: “in its mother’s milk” not in the milk of a male “in its mother’s milk” not in the milk of slaughtered “in its mother’s milk” not in the milk of a non-kosher
llm_translation: In the milk of its mother, and not in the milk of a male; in the milk of its mother, and not in the milk of a slaughtered animal; in the milk of its mother, and not in the milk of an unclean animal.

hebrew_text: הא תלתא גדי כתיבי ואנן שיתא דרשינן קסבר שמואל איסור חל על איסור ואיסור חלב ומתה מחד קרא נפקי דם נמי לאו גדי הוא ושליא נמי פירשא בעלמא הוא פשו להו תרי חד לרבות את השליל וחד למעוטי בהמה טמאה
human_translation: “kid” is written three and we expound six Shmuel maintains a prohibition takes effect prohibition and prohibition of fat and a dead are both derived from one verse, blood also is not a kid and likewise a placenta is merely a secretion two are left; one to include a fetus, and one to exclude a non-kosher animal.
llm_translation: This is the translation of the Talmudic text you provided: "Here, three goats are written, and we learn six. Samuel holds: one prohibition takes effect upon another prohibition, and the prohibition of fat and the dead animal both derive from one verse. Blood also, is not a goat, and the tail is also generally separated. They explained to them: two - one to include the negative and one to exclude the unclean animal."

hebrew_text: וסבר שמואל איסור חל על איסור והאמר שמואל משום ר' אלעזר מנין לכהן טמא שאכל תרומה טמאה שאינו במיתה שנאמר (ויקרא כב, ט) ומתו בו כי יחללוהו פרט לזו שמחוללת ועומדת
human_translation: And does Shmuel maintain a prohibition takes effect prohibition But didn’t Shmuel say in the name of Rabbi Elazar: From where an impure priest who partakes of impure teruma , is not with death as it is stated, “And die therein if they desecrate it” to the exclusion of this which was already desecrated
llm_translation: And Shmuel holds that one prohibition takes effect upon another prohibition. And Shmuel said in the name of Rabbi Elazar, from where do we derive that an impure priest who ate impure terumah is not liable to death? As it is stated (Leviticus 22:9), "And they shall bear the iniquity of it, when they eat their holy things." This excludes one who is impure and yet survives.

hebrew_text: איבעית אימא בעלמא איסור חל על איסור ושאני התם דמיעט רחמנא ומתו בו איבעית אימא בעלמא קסבר שמואל אין איסור חל על איסור ושאני הכא דרבי רחמנא גדי
human_translation: If you wish, say in general a prohibition takes effect prohibition is different there, as the Merciful One excludes “and die therein if you wish, say in general Shmuel maintains a prohibition does not take effect prohibition and here, is different, as the Merciful One includes “kid.”
llm_translation: If you wish, say: In general, one prohibition takes effect upon another prohibition. And it is different there, for the Merciful One made it rare, and they die because of it. If you wish, say: In general, Samuel holds that one prohibition does not take effect upon another prohibition. And it is different here, for Rabbi holds that the Merciful One is a kid.

hebrew_text: ואיבעית אימא הא דידיה הא דרביה
human_translation: And if you wish, say this his that is his teacher’s,
llm_translation: And if you wish, say: this one is his, this one is his teacher's.

hebrew_text: בעא מיניה רב אחדבוי בר אמי מרב המבשל בחלב גדי שלא הניקה מהו א"ל מדאיצטריכא לשמואל למימר בחלב אמו ולא בחלב זכר זכר הוא דלא אתי לכלל אם אבל האי כיון דבא לכלל אם אסור
human_translation: Rav Aḥadvoi bar Ami raised a dilemma to Rav: one cooks in milk of a goat that has not nursed, what is said to him: From it was necessary for Shmuel to say “in its mother’s milk” And not in the milk of a male it is a male cannot attain the status of a mother. But this since will attain the status of a mother, prohibited
llm_translation: Requested text: Rav Ahadboi son of Ami asked Rav: One who cooks a kid in its mother's milk that did not suckle, what is the law? He said to him: Since Shmuel needs it to say that it is prohibited with the milk of its mother and not with the milk of a male, it is a male that does not come under the prohibition. But this one, since it comes under the prohibition, it is forbidden.

hebrew_text: אתמר המבשל חלב בחלב רבי אמי ורבי אסי חד אמר לוקה וחד אמר אינו לוקה לימא בהא קמיפלגי דמ"ד לוקה קסבר איסור חל על איסור ומאן דאמר אינו לוקה קסבר אין איסור חל על איסור
human_translation: was stated: one who cooks fat in milk, Rabbi Ami and Rabbi Asi One says is flogged and one says is not flogged. Let us say they disagree about this: That the one who says is flogged maintains a prohibition takes effect prohibition and the one who says is not flogged maintains a prohibition does not take effect prohibition
llm_translation: It was stated: One who cooks milk with milk - Rabbi Ami and Rabbi Asi, one said he is liable, and one said he is not liable. Let us say they are arguing about this: one who says he is liable holds that one prohibition can take effect upon another prohibition, and one who says he is not liable holds that one prohibition cannot take effect upon another prohibition.

hebrew_text: לא דכ"ע אין איסור חל על איסור אאכילה דכ"ע לא פליגי דלא לקי כי פליגי אבשול מ"ד לוקה חד איסורא הוא ומ"ד אינו לוקה להכי אפקה רחמנא לאכילה בלשון בישול
human_translation: No; everyone a prohibition does not take effect prohibition everyone agrees that is not flogged for eating When they disagree, with regard to cooking. The one who says is flogged one prohibition, And the one who says is not flogged for this the Merciful One expressed eating the language of cooking:
llm_translation: Not like all, no prohibition takes effect on another prohibition of eating, not like all they do not argue, for not to strike when they argue, regarding cooking, one says it is a punishable offense, and one says it is not punishable, therefore the Merciful One specified eating with the language of cooking.

hebrew_text: כיון דעל אכילה לא לקי אבישול נמי לא לקי
human_translation: since one is not flogged for eating also is not flogged for cooking
llm_translation: Since regarding eating not lashes, regarding cooking also not lashes.

hebrew_text: ואיכא דאמרי אבישול כולי עלמא לא פליגי דלקי כי פליגי אאכילה מאן דאמר אינו לוקה דהא אין איסור חל על איסור ומאן דאמר לוקה להכי אפקה רחמנא לאכילה בלשון בישול כיון דאבישול לקי אאכילה נמי לקי
human_translation: And some say With regard to cooking, everyone agrees that is flogged When they disagree, with regard to eating. The one who says he is not flogged that a prohibition does not take effect prohibition And the one who says he is flogged for this the Merciful One expressed eating the language of cooking, since one is flogged for cooking also is flogged for eating
llm_translation: And there are those who say, "Avishul, everyone agrees that when they disagree regarding eating, whoever says he is not liable, for there is no prohibition upon a prohibition. And whoever says he is liable, thus the Merciful One has expressed for eating in the language of cooking, since when cooking is present, eating is also present."

hebrew_text: ואיבעית אימא מר אמר חדא ומר אמר חדא ולא פליגי
human_translation: And if you wish, say one Sage said one and one Sage said another and they do not disagree,
llm_translation: And if you wish, say: one Master said one thing, and the other Master said one thing, and they do not argue.

hebrew_text: מיתיבי המבשל במי חלב פטור דם שבשלו בחלב פטור העצמות והגידים והקרנים והטלפים שבשלן בחלב פטור
human_translation: raises an objection One who cooks in whey, exempt blood that one cooked in milk, exempt, the bones, the tendons, the horns, and the hooves that one cooked in milk, exempt.
llm_translation: The question was raised: One who cooks in milk is exempt. The blood that was cooked in milk is exempt. The bones, sinews, horns, and hooves that were cooked in milk are exempt.

hebrew_text: הפגול והנותר והטמא שבשלן בחלב חייב
human_translation: piggul and notar , and impure that one cooked in milk, liable
llm_translation: The piggul and the notar and the tamei that were cooked in their milk are liable.

hebrew_text: האי תנא סבר איסור חל על איסור
human_translation: This tanna maintains a prohibition takes effect prohibition
llm_translation: This Tanna holds that a prohibition takes effect upon another prohibition.

hebrew_text: המבשל במי חלב פטור מסייע ליה לריש לקיש דתנן מי חלב הרי הן כחלב והמוחל הרי הוא כשמן אמר ריש לקיש לא שנו אלא להכשיר את הזרעים אבל לענין בישול בשר בחלב מי חלב אינו כחלב
human_translation: One who cooks in whey is exempt supports of Reish Lakish, as we learned whey is like milk, and secretion is like oil, Reish Lakish says: They taught only rendering seeds, susceptible But with regard to cooking meat in milk, whey is not like milk.
llm_translation: The one who cooks in water of milk exempt assists to him to Reish Lakish as we learned water of milk behold they are like milk and one who pardons behold it is like oil said Reish Lakish they did not teach except to make fit the seeds but regarding the matter of cooking meat in milk water of milk is not like milk

hebrew_text: תנו רבנן בחלב אמו אין לי אלא בחלב אמו בחלב פרה ורחל מנין
human_translation: The Sages taught “in its mother’s milk” I have only to mother milk. From where to the milk of a cow and a ewe?
llm_translation: The Sages taught: "In the milk of its mother" - I have only learned about in the milk of its mother; in the milk of a cow and a ewe, from where do we derive this law?

hebrew_text: אמרת קל וחומר ומה אמו שלא נאסרה עמו בהרבעה נאסרה עמו בבשולו פרה ורחל שנאסרו עמו בהרבעה אינו דין שנאסרו עמו בבשולו תלמוד לומר בחלב אמו
human_translation: You say an a fortiori Just as mother, which is not prohibited for mating with is prohibited for cooking with it, is it not right that a cow or a ewe, which are prohibited for mating with it, should be prohibited for cooking with it? the verse states “In its mother’s milk,”
llm_translation: You said: a fortiori, just as its mother, which was not prohibited with it in its embryonic state, is prohibited with it in its cooked state, a cow and a ewe, which were prohibited with it in its embryonic state, it is not the same that they were prohibited with it in its cooked state, as it is taught to say "with its mother's milk."

hebrew_text: והא למה לי קרא הא אתיא ליה
human_translation: But why do I a verse? It was derived
llm_translation: And this, why do I need a verse? This comes to him.

hebrew_text: אמר רב אשי משום דאיכא למימר מעיקרא דדינא פירכא מהיכא קא מייתית לה מאמו מה לאמו שכן נאסרה עמו בשחיטה תאמר בפרה שלא נאסרה עמו בשחיטה תלמוד לומר בחלב אמו
human_translation: Rav Ashi said: because one can say that refutation of the inference from the outset, From where do you derive from its mother What about its mother? in that it is prohibited for slaughter with it, Will you say about a cow, which is not prohibited for slaughter with it? the verse states: “In its mother’s milk,”
llm_translation: Rav Ashi said: Because there is to say from the outset of the law, a refutation. From where do you bring it to her from her mother? Just as her mother is forbidden to him in slaughter, you shall say in a cow that was not forbidden to him in slaughter, it is stated to teach in the fat of her mother.

hebrew_text: תניא אידך בחלב אמו אין לי אלא בחלב אמו בחלב אחותו גדולה מנין
human_translation: is taught another “in its mother’s milk” I have only to the milk of its mother, From where to the milk of its older sister,
llm_translation: It was taught in another source: "In the milk of its mother, I have only learned about in the milk of its mother, how do we know the law applies in the milk of its sister?"

hebrew_text: אמרת ק"ו ומה אמו שנכנסה עמו לדיר להתעשר נאסרה עמו בבשול אחותו שלא נכנסה עמו לדיר להתעשר אינו דין שנאסרה עמו בבשול תלמוד לומר בחלב אמו
human_translation: You say an a fortiori Just as mother, which enters the pen to be tithed with it, is prohibited for cooking with it, is it not right that its sister, which does not enter the pen to be tithed with it, should be prohibited for cooking with it? the verse states “In its mother’s milk,”
llm_translation: You said: "Is it not logical? If his mother who entered with him into the chamber to become wealthy is prohibited to him in marriage due to the prohibition of his sister who did not enter with him into the chamber to become wealthy, is it not the same that she is prohibited to him in marriage due to the prohibition of his mother's milk?"

hebrew_text: והא למה לי קרא הא אתיא ליה אמר רב אשי משום דאיכא למימר מעיקרא דדינא פירכא מהיכא קא מייתית לה מאמו מה לאמו שכן נאסרה עמו בשחיטה תאמר באחותו גדולה שלא נאסרה עמו בשחיטה תלמוד לומר בחלב אמו
human_translation: But why do I a verse? It was derived Rav Ashi said: because one can say refutation of inference from the outset. From where do you derive from its mother. What about its mother? in that it is prohibited for slaughter with it Will you say to its older sister, which is not prohibited for slaughter with it? the verse states: “In its mother’s milk,”
llm_translation: And this, why do I need a verse for it? This comes to teach us. Rav Ashi said: Because there is something to say from the beginning of the judgment, a refutation arises. From where do you bring it for her? From her mother. Just as with her mother, it is prohibited to be with him in slaughter, you shall say with his older sister who was not prohibited to be with him in slaughter. The verse states, "From the milk of his mother."

hebrew_text: אשכחן אחותו גדולה אחותו קטנה מנין אתיא מביניא
human_translation: We have found its older sister From where its younger sister, It is derived from between them,
llm_translation: We found his older sister, his younger sister, from where do they come? From the daughters.

hebrew_text: מהי תיתי תיתי מאמו מה לאמו שכן נאסרה עמו בשחיטה אחותו גדולה תוכיח מה לאחותו גדולה שלא נכנסה עמו לדיר להתעשר אמו תוכיח
human_translation: From which should it be derived? it should be derived from its mother, What about its mother? in that it is prohibited for slaughter with it Its older sister can prove What about its older sister? in that it does not enter the pen to be tithed with it, its mother can prove
llm_translation: What is the meaning of "teiti teiti" from his mother? Just as his mother is prohibited to him in terms of ritual slaughter, his older sister will prove the same. What is the meaning of his older sister? That she did not enter with him into a dwelling to become enriched. His mother will prove the same.

hebrew_text: וחזר הדין לא ראי זה כראי זה ולא ראי זה כראי זה הצד השוה שבהן שהוא בשר ואסור לבשל בחלב אף אני אביא אחותו קטנה שהוא בשר ואסור לבשל בחלב
human_translation: And the inference has reverted The aspect of this is not like the aspect of that and the aspect of that is not like the aspect of this their common element that meat and prohibited to cook in milk. I will also include its younger sister since it is meat, and prohibited to cook in milk.
llm_translation: And the law returned: not the sight of this like the sight of that, and not the sight of this like the sight of that. The equal side in them, which is flesh, and it is forbidden to cook with milk. I too will bring its younger sister, which is flesh, and it is forbidden to cook with milk.

hebrew_text: אי הכי אחותו גדולה נמי תיתי מביניא
human_translation: If so, its older sister also be derived from between them,
llm_translation: If so, his older sister should also be given from the betrothal money.

hebrew_text: אין הכי נמי אלא בחלב אמו למה לי מבעי ליה לכדתניא בחלב אמו אין לי אלא בחלב אמו
human_translation: Yes, is indeed so; Rather, why do I “in its mother’s milk?” It is necessary for that which is taught “In its mother’s milk,” I have only in its mother’s milk;
llm_translation: So too, but rather with the milk of its mother, why do I need it? It requires it, as it was taught: with the milk of its mother, I have no other source except with the milk of its mother.

hebrew_text: היא עצמה בחלבה מנין אמרת ק"ו ומה במקום שלא נאסר פרי עם פרי בשחיטה נאסר פרי עם האם בשחיטה מקום שנאסר פרי עם פרי בבשול אינו דין שנאסר פרי עם האם בבשול ת"ל בחלב אמו
human_translation: from where itself in its milk? Say an a fortiori Just as where fruit is not prohibited with fruit, slaughter, fruit is prohibited for slaughter with the mother, is it not right that where fruit is prohibited with fruit, cooking, fruit, should be prohibited for cooking with the mother? the verse states: “In its mother’s milk,”
llm_translation: It itself in its milk, from where did you say? A fortiori inference. And just as in a situation where the offspring with another offspring is not prohibited through slaughter, the offspring with the mother is prohibited through slaughter, in a situation where the offspring with another offspring is not prohibited through cooking, it is not the same that the offspring with the mother is prohibited through cooking. It is stated: "In its mother's milk."

hebrew_text: הא למה לי קרא הא אתיא לה אמר רב אחדבוי בר אמי משום דאיכא למימר סוס בן סוסיא אחי פרדה יוכיח שאסור פרי עם פרי ומותר פרי עם האם
human_translation: Why do I a verse? It was derived Rav Aḥadvoi bar Ami said: because one can say a horse born of mare the brother of a mule, proves As fruit is prohibited with fruit, but fruit is permitted with the mother.
llm_translation: This is why do I need a verse: this comes to teach. Rav Ahadboi son of Ami said: because there is to say, "A horse, son of a mare, is the brother of a mule," will prove that it is forbidden for the fruit of one species with the fruit of another species, but permitted for the fruit with its mother.

hebrew_text: התם זרע האב הוא דקא גרים
human_translation: There it is the seed of the father that effects
llm_translation: There, the seed of the father, it is that which is sown.

hebrew_text: דהא פרד בן סוסיא אחי פרדה יוכיח שמותר פרי עם פרי ואסור פרי עם האם
human_translation: as a mule born of a mare the brother of a female mule proves. As fruit is permitted with fruit, and fruit is prohibited with the mother,
llm_translation: The text reads as follows: "For Parḍ, son of Sūsiyya, the brother of Parḍa, proves that the offspring of one species is permitted with the offspring of another species, but the offspring of one species with its mother is prohibited."

hebrew_text: אלא אמר מר בריה דרבינא משום דאיכא למימר עבד בן שפחה אחי משוחררת יוכיח שאסור פרי עם פרי ומותר פרי עם האם
human_translation: Rather, Mar, son of Ravina, said: because one can say that slave born of a female slave the brother of a female freed proves As fruit is prohibited with fruit, and fruit is permitted with mother.
llm_translation: Rather, said Mar the son of Ravina in the name of, because there is to say, "A slave born of a maidservant, the brother of a freed woman, may prove that it is forbidden to mix the fruit of one species with the fruit of another species, and permitted to mix the fruit with its mother."

hebrew_text: התם גט שיחרור הוא דקא גרים דהא עבד בן משוחררת אחי שפחה יוכיח שמותר פרי עם פרי ואסור פרי עם האם
human_translation: There it is the bill of manumission that effects as slave, son of a female freed the brother of a female slave proves. As fruit is permitted with fruit, and fruit is prohibited with mother,
llm_translation: There, a bill of divorce is a document of emancipation, for he is a convert, as Ben Mishucharret did. The brother of a maidservant shall prove that it is permitted to mix the produce of the convert with the produce of the mother, but it is forbidden to mix the produce of the convert with the produce of the mother.

hebrew_text: אלא אמר רב אידי בר אבין משום דאיכא למימר כלאי זרעים יוכיחו שאסור פרי עם פרי ומותר פרי עם האם כלום נאסר פרי עם פרי אלא ע"י האם דהא חיטי ושערי בכדא ולא מיתסרו
human_translation: Rather, Rav Idi bar Avin said: because one can say diverse kinds of seeds proves As is prohibited fruit with fruit and permitted fruit with the mother, Isn’t fruit with fruit prohibited only by means of the mother, as wheat and barley in jug and they are not prohibited.
llm_translation: Rather, Rav Idi bar Avin said, on account of there being to say, "Kilayim shall prove that it is forbidden: fruit with fruit is forbidden, but fruit with the mother is permitted. Is it not the case that fruit with fruit is forbidden only through the mother, for wheat and barley in a pitcher do not become forbidden."

hebrew_text: אלא אמר רב אשי משום דאיכא למימר מה לפרי עם פרי שכן שני גופים תאמר בפרי עם האם שכן גוף אחד משום הכי איצטריך קרא
human_translation: Rather, Rav Ashi said: because one can say: What about fruit with fruit, in that two bodies you say to fruit with the mother, which one body? Due to this the verse was necessary
llm_translation: Rather, Rav Ashi said: Because there is to say, "What is the case with fruit with fruit, that there are two bodies?" You shall say, "In the case of fruit with its mother, there is one body." Therefore, a verse was necessary.

hebrew_text: אמר רב אשי מנין לבשר בחלב שאסור באכילה שנאמר (דברים יד, ג) לא תאכל כל תועבה כל שתעבתי לך הרי הוא בבל תאכל
human_translation: Rav Ashi says: From where that meat in milk is prohibited for consumption, as it is stated “You shall not eat any abominable thing” any that I have made abominable, to you, is prohibited for consumption.
llm_translation: Rav Ashi said: From where do we derive that meat cooked in milk is prohibited for consumption? As it is stated (Deuteronomy 14:3), "You shall not eat any abomination." Any abomination that I have abominated to you, behold, it is forbidden to eat.

hebrew_text: ואין לי אלא באכילה בהנאה מנין כדרבי אבהו דאמר ר' אבהו א"ר אלעזר כל מקום שנאמר לא יאכל לא תאכל לא תאכלו אחד איסור אכילה ואחד איסור הנאה במשמע עד שיפרוט לך הכתוב כדרך שפרט לך בנבלה לגר בנתינה ולעובד כוכבים במכירה
human_translation: And I have only with regard to consumption; from where with regard to benefit? in accordance with of Rabbi Abbahu, as Rabbi Abbahu says Rabbi Elazar says: Wherever it is stated, “He shall not eat,” “you,” “shall not eat,” “you,” “shall not eat,” both a prohibition eating and a prohibition benefit unless the verse specifies for you in the manner that it specified for you with regard to an animal carcass, to resident alien by giving and to gentile by sale.
llm_translation: "And I have only learned regarding eating forbidden food for pleasure, how do I know this applies according to Rabbi Abahu, for Rabbi Abahu said in the name of Rabbi Elazar: Wherever it is stated 'do not eat,' 'you shall not eat,' 'you shall not eat them,' it implies both a prohibition of eating and a prohibition of deriving benefit. This is to be understood until the verse explicitly differentiates for you, just as it differentiated for you regarding a carcass that it is forbidden for a convert to eat, for a gift to be given, and for an idolater to sell."

hebrew_text: דתניא (דברים יד, כא) לא תאכלו כל נבלה לגר אשר בשעריך תתננה ואכלה או מכור לנכרי אין לי אלא לגר בנתינה ולעובד כוכבים במכירה לגר במכירה מנין ת"ל לגר תתננה או מכור
human_translation: As it is taught “You shall not eat of any unslaughtered animal carcass; you may give it to the resident alien who is within your gates, that he may eat it; or you may sell it to a foreigner; I have only to a resident alien through giving and to a gentile through selling. From where to a resident alien through selling The verse states: “You may give it to the stranger…or you may sell it,”
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita (Deuteronomy 14:21): "You shall not eat any carcass; you may give it to the stranger within your gates, that he may eat it, or you may sell it to a foreigner." I have only learned this law regarding a stranger through giving the carcass, and regarding an idolater through selling it. How do we know this law applies to a stranger through selling it? The verse states, "to the stranger you shall give it, or sell it."

hebrew_text: לעובד כוכבים בנתינה מנין ת"ל תתננה או מכור לנכרי נמצא אחד גר ואחד עובד כוכבים בין במכירה בין בנתינה דברי ר"מ רבי יהודה אומר דברים ככתבן לגר בנתינה ולעובד כוכבים במכירה
human_translation: From where to a gentile through giving The verse states: “You may give it or you may sell it to a foreigner.” one finds both a resident alien and a gentile, both through selling or through giving. the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: matters are as they are written; to a resident alien through giving, and to a gentile through selling.
llm_translation: To a worshipper of stars, regarding giving, from where do we learn? It is written: "You shall give it" (Deuteronomy 15:14). Or if he sells it to a non-Jew, it is found that both a convert and a worshipper of stars, whether through sale or through giving, the words of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: The matters are as they are written - to a convert through giving, and to a worshipper of stars through sale.

hebrew_text: מ"ט דרבי יהודה אי ס"ד כדקאמר ר"מ לכתוב רחמנא לא תאכלו כל נבלה לגר אשר בשעריך תתננה ואכלה ומכור או למה לי ש"מ לדברים ככתבן הוא דאתא לגר בנתינה ולעובד כוכבים במכירה
human_translation: What is the reason for Rabbi Yehuda? if it enters your mind in accordance Rabbi Meir says, let the Merciful One write: You shall not eat of any animal carcass, you may give it to the resident alien who is within your gates that he may eat it and you may sell it Why do I “or” Learn from it that it comes to matters are as they are written: To a resident alien through giving and to gentile through selling.
llm_translation: Reasoning of Rabbi Yehuda: If you will say, as Rabbi Meir said, "To write 'you shall not eat any carcass to the stranger who is in your gates, you shall give it and he shall eat it, or sell it' - why do I need this?" - learn from the words as they are written, that it came for the stranger through giving, and for the idolater through selling.

hebrew_text: ור"מ אמר לך האי או להקדים נתינה דגר למכירה דעובד כוכבים ורבי יהודה להקדים נתינה דגר למכירה דעובד כוכבים לא צריך קרא סברא הוא זה אתה מצווה להחיותו וזה אי אתה מצווה להחיותו:
human_translation: And Rabbi Meir say to you this “or” to prioritize to giving to a resident alien over selling to a gentile. And Rabbi Yehuda priority of giving to a resident alien over selling to a gentile does not require a verse, it is logical reasoning: You are commanded to sustain this but you are not commanded to sustain that
llm_translation: Rabbi Meir said to you: This one, or to prioritize the giving of a ger for sale to a non-Jew. And Rabbi Yehuda to prioritize the giving of a ger for sale to a non-Jew, does not need a verse, it is a logical deduction: This one, you are commanded to sustain, and this one, you are not commanded to sustain.

hebrew_text: (סימן שבת חורש וכלאי זרעים אותו ואת בנו ושילוח הקן):
human_translation: a mnemonic Shabbat; plows; and diverse kinds of seeds; a mother and its offspring; and sending the nest.
llm_translation: Chapter Shabbat, plowing and mixing seeds, him and his son, and sending away the mother bird.

hebrew_text: אלא מעתה
human_translation: If that is so,
llm_translation: Rather now

hebrew_text: מעשה שבת ליתסרו דהא תיעבתי לך הוא
human_translation: let an action Shabbat, be prohibited as is I have made abominable to you,
llm_translation: The incident of Shabbat did not cease, for I have a loathing for you, it is.

hebrew_text: אמר קרא (שמות לא, יד) כי קדש היא לכם היא קדש ואין מעשיה קדש
human_translation: the verse states “For it is sacred to you” It, is sacred, but actions it are not sacred,
llm_translation: The verse says (Exodus 31:14), "For it is holy to you; it is holy, and its actions are not holy."

hebrew_text: חורש בשור ובחמור וחוסם פי פרה ודש בה ליתסרו דהא תיעבתי לך הוא
human_translation: one plows with an ox and with a donkey or one muzzles the mouth of a cow and threshes with it, should be prohibited as I have made abominable to you.
llm_translation: One who plows with an ox and with a donkey, and who seals the mouth of the cow while threshing, and sows with it, they are forbidden to you, for it is an abomination.

hebrew_text: השתא ומה שבת דחמירא מעשיה מותרים הני לא כל שכן
human_translation: Now Just as Shabbat, which is stringently, actions are permitted; not all the more so these
llm_translation: At present, and regarding Shabbat which is stringent, its actions are permitted, these certainly so.

hebrew_text: כלאי זרעים ליתסרו דהא תיעבתי לך הוא מדגלי רחמנא גבי כלאי הכרם (דברים כב, ט) פן תקדש פן תוקד אש מכלל דכלאי זרעים שרו
human_translation: Diverse kinds of seeds should be prohibited as is I have made abominable to you. from that the Merciful One revealed with regard to diverse kinds in a vineyard: lest be forfeited [ pen tikdash ]” Lest it be burned [ pen tukad esh ], by inference that diverse kinds of seeds are permitted.
llm_translation: "Mixtures of seeds are not prohibited, for it is an abomination to you, as the Merciful One has revealed regarding mixtures of vineyard seeds (Deuteronomy 22:9), 'Lest you consecrate, lest you burn with fire.' From this, it is inferred that mixtures of seeds are permitted."

hebrew_text: ואימא כלאי כרם אסורין בין באכילה בין בהנאה כלאי זרעים באכילה אסירי בהנאה שרו איתקוש לכלאי בהמה דכתיב (ויקרא יט, יט) בהמתך לא תרביע כלאים שדך לא תזרע כלאים מה בהמתך היוצא ממנה מותרת אף שדך היוצא ממנו מותר
human_translation: But say diverse kinds in a vineyard are prohibited both for consumption and for benefit, diverse kinds of seeds are prohibited for consumption are permitted for benefit. they are juxtaposed to diverse kinds of animals, As it is written: “You shall not let your cattle mate with a diverse kind; you shall not sow your field with two kinds of seed” just as your cattle, that comes from is permitted, so too, your field, that that comes from is permitted.
llm_translation: And say, "Kilayim of a vineyard are forbidden, whether in eating or benefiting; Kilayim of seeds are forbidden in eating but permitted in benefiting." They compared Kilayim of seeds to Kilayim of animals, as it is written (Leviticus 19:19), "Your animals you shall not breed with diverse kinds, your field you shall not sow with diverse kinds." Just as your animals that come from them are permitted, so too your field that comes from it is permitted.

hebrew_text: וכלאי בהמה גופייהו מנא לן מדאסר רחמנא כלאים לגבוה מכלל דלהדיוט שרי
human_translation: And diverse kinds of animals themselves, from where do we From that the Merciful One prohibits diverse kinds to the Most High by inference that they are permitted to ordinary
llm_translation: And how do we know that the offspring of an animal are prohibited to their mother? Because the Merciful One prohibited "kilayim" to the higher category, implying that to the lower category it is permitted.

hebrew_text: אותו ואת בנו ליתסר מדאסר רחמנא מחוסר זמן לגבוה מכלל דלהדיוט שרי
human_translation: A mother and its offspring should be prohibited From that the Merciful One prohibits whose time has not yet to the Most High by inference that permitted to ordinary
llm_translation: That one and his son are not subject to the prohibition that the Merciful One prohibits due to a lack of time for him, as it is permitted from the general rule that for an ordinary person it is permissible.

hebrew_text: שילוח הקן ליתסר לא אמרה תורה שלח לתקלה
human_translation: sending the nest, should be prohibited The Torah did not say: Send to a mishap.
llm_translation: The sending away of the nest is not prohibited, as the Torah stated, "Send away for the purpose of good."

hebrew_text: אמר ריש לקיש מנין לבשר בחלב שאסור ת"ל (שמות יב, ט) אל תאכלו ממנו נא ובשל מבושל שאין תלמוד לומר מבושל מה תלמוד לומר מבושל לומר לך יש לך בשול אחר שהוא כזה ואי זה זה בשר בחלב
human_translation: Reish Lakish says: From where that meat in milk is prohibited The verse states “You shall not eat it partially roasted, nor boiled in any way” As no the verse to state: in any way,” What the verse states: in any way?” to tell you there is another cooking, which is like this one. And which is this? This is meat in milk.
llm_translation: Said Reish Lakish: From where do we derive that meat cooked in milk is prohibited? It is stated (Exodus 23:19), "Do not cook a kid in its mother's milk." And cooked means cooked, as there is no need for the Talmud to state "cooked." What does the Talmud teach by stating "cooked"? It teaches you that there is another type of cooking similar to this, and what is that? It is meat cooked in milk.

hebrew_text: א"ל רבי יוחנן
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan said to
llm_translation: He said to him, Rabbi Yochanan

hebrew_text: כעורה זו ששנה רבי לא תאכלנו בבשר בחלב הכתוב מדבר
human_translation: Is that that Rabbi taught ugly, “You shall not eat it; the verse is speaking of meat in milk,
llm_translation: Like a blind person, this is what Rabbi changed: "Do not eat it with meat in milk," the Scripture speaks.

hebrew_text: אתה אומר בבשר בחלב הכתוב מדבר או אינו אלא באחד מכל האיסורין שבתורה אמרת צא ולמד מי"ג מדות שהתורה נדרשת בהן דבר הלמד מענינו במה הכתוב מדבר בשני מינין אף כאן בשני מינין
human_translation: Do you say the verse is speaking of meat in milk? Or it is only to one of the prohibitions in the Torah? You say: Go out and learn from the thirteen hermeneutical principles, A matter that is derived from its context. To what are the verses referring? to two types: Here too, to two types
llm_translation: You say, "In meat cooked in milk, does the verse speak, or is it only in one of all the prohibitions in the Torah?" You said, "Go out and learn the thirteen principles through which the Torah is expounded. A matter that is learned from its context, in what is the verse speaking? In two types. So too here, in two types."

hebrew_text: אי מההיא הוה אמינא הני מילי באכילה אבל בהנאה לא קמ"ל
human_translation: if from that I would say this statement to eating but not to benefit teaches us
llm_translation: If it were that, I would say these matters regarding eating, but regarding benefit, it teaches us.

hebrew_text: ורבי בהנאה מנא ליה נפקא ליה מהכא נאמר כאן (דברים יד, ב) כי עם קדוש אתה לה' ונאמר להלן (דברים כג, יח) ולא יהיה קדש בבני ישראל מה להלן בהנאה אף כאן בהנאה
human_translation: And Rabbi from where for benefit? He derives it from here, it is stated here: “For you are a sacred [ kadosh ] people unto the Lord And it is stated below: “Neither shall there be a sodomite [ kadesh ] of the sons of Israel” just as below, benefit, so too here, with regard to benefit.
llm_translation: Rabbi Behanah derived it for him, he derived it for him from here it is stated here (Deuteronomy 14:2) "For you are a holy people to the Lord," and it is stated there (Deuteronomy 23:19) "And there shall be no harlot of the daughters of Israel." Just as there, regarding benefit, so too here regarding benefit.

hebrew_text: דבי רבי אליעזר תנא (דברים יד, כא) לא תאכלו כל נבלה [וגו'] אמרה תורה כשתמכרנה לא תבשלנה ותמכרנה
human_translation: The school of Rabbi Eliezer taught: “You shall not eat of any animal carcass; The Torah stated when you sell you shall not cook it and sell it,
llm_translation: The school of Rabbi Eliezer taught: (Deuteronomy 14:21) "You shall not eat any carcass etc." The Torah said: When you sell it, do not cook it, and sell it.

hebrew_text: דבי רבי ישמעאל תנא (שמות כג, יט) לא תבשל גדי בחלב אמו ג' פעמים אחד לאיסור אכילה ואחד לאיסור הנאה ואחד לאיסור בשול
human_translation: The school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: three times: “You shall not cook a kid in its mother’s milk” One to the prohibition eating and one to the prohibition benefit and one to the prohibition cooking
llm_translation: The school of Rabbi Yishmael taught (Exodus 23:19) "You shall not cook a young goat in its mother's milk" three times: once for prohibition of eating, once for prohibition of benefit, and once for prohibition of cooking.

hebrew_text: תניא איסי בן יהודה אומר מנין לבשר בחלב שאסור נאמר כאן (דברים יד, ב) כי עם קדוש אתה ונאמר להלן (שמות כב, ל) ואנשי קדש תהיון לי ובשר בשדה טרפה לא תאכלו מה להלן אסור אף כאן אסור
human_translation: It is taught Isi ben Yehuda says: From where that it is prohibited meat in milk? It is stated here: “For you are a sacred people And it is stated below: “And you shall be sacred men unto Me; therefore you shall not eat any flesh that is torn of animals in the field [ tereifa ]; Just as below it is prohibited so too here it is prohibited
llm_translation: It was taught: Issi ben Judah says, from where do we derive that it is forbidden to cook meat with milk? It is stated here (Deuteronomy 14:2), "For you are a holy people," and it is stated there (Exodus 22:30), "And you shall be holy men to Me." Just as it is forbidden there, so too it is forbidden here.

hebrew_text: ואין לי אלא באכילה בהנאה מנין אמרת ק"ו ומה ערלה שלא נעבדה בה עבירה אסורה בהנאה בשר בחלב שנעבדה בו עבירה אינו דין שאסור בהנאה
human_translation: And I have only for consumption. From where for benefit You say an a fortiori Just as the fruit of a tree during the first three years after its planting [ orla ], as no sin has been committed in it is prohibited for benefit, is it not right that meat in milk, with regard to which a sin has been committed, should be prohibited for benefit?
llm_translation: "And I have only learned regarding prohibition of deriving benefit from forbidden items through eating, how do you know? And just as uncircumcision, which has not been used for a transgression, is forbidden for benefit, so too meat cooked with milk, which has been used for a transgression, is not necessarily forbidden for benefit."

hebrew_text: מה לערלה שכן לא היתה לה שעת הכושר
human_translation: What about orla ? in that it never had a time when it was fit.
llm_translation: What for uncircumcision so too not was for it time of fitness.

hebrew_text: חמץ בפסח יוכיח שהיתה לו שעת הכושר ואסור בהנאה מה לחמץ בפסח שכן ענוש כרת
human_translation: Let leavened bread on Passover prove as it had a time when it was fit, and it is prohibited for benefit. What about leavened bread on Passover? in that it is punishable by karet ,
llm_translation: Chametz on Passover will prove that it was fit for use and is forbidden for benefit. What is the comparison of chametz on Passover? For it is punishable by karet.

hebrew_text: כלאי הכרם יוכיחו שאין ענוש כרת ואסור בהנאה
human_translation: Let diverse kinds in a vineyard prove as is not punishable by karet , and it is prohibited to benefit
llm_translation: Boundaries of the vineyard will prove that there is no punishment of excision and it is forbidden to derive benefit.

hebrew_text: למה לי גז"ש לייתי כולה בק"ו מערלה ומה ערלה שלא נעבדה בה עבירה אסורה בין באכילה בין בהנאה בשר בחלב שנעבדה בו עבירה אינו דין שאסור בין באכילה בין בהנאה
human_translation: Why do I verbal analogy Let all of it, be derived a fortiori from orla : Just as orla , as no sin has been committed in prohibited both for consumption and for benefit; is it not right that meat in milk, with regard to which a sin has been committed, prohibited both for consumption and for benefit?
llm_translation: "Why do I need the verse 'Gazishe' to bring the entire 'Ku' from 'Ma'arla'? And what is 'Ma'arla' that has not been used for a forbidden act, whether in eating or benefiting, flesh with milk, that has been used for a forbidden act, it is not the same, that it is forbidden, whether in eating or benefiting."

hebrew_text: משום דאיכא למימר חורש בשור ובחמור וחוסם פי פרה ודש בה יוכיח שנעבדה בהם עבירה ושרו
human_translation: because one could say: who plows with an ox and with a donkey, and who muzzles the mouth of a cow and threshes with it prove As a sin has been committed through them, and permitted.
llm_translation: Because there is to say, plows with an ox and with a donkey, and seals the mouth of a cow, and threshes with it, he shall prove that a transgression was done with them, and they shall be stoned.

hebrew_text: למה לי למימר כלאי הכרם יוכיחו לימא ערלה תוכיח וליהדר דינא וליתי במה הצד

llm_translation: "Why do I need to say 'Kilayim should prove'? Let it say 'Orlah should prove,' and then the law will be established, and it will come with 'Bamah Hatzad.'"

llm_translation: Rav Ashi said: Because there is to say, "A carcass shall rebuke that it is forbidden for consumption and permitted for benefit."

hebrew_text: אמר ליה רב מרדכי לרב אשי הכי אמרינן משמיה דריש לקיש כל מה הצד מגופו פרכינן מעלמא לא פרכינן

llm_translation: Rav Mordechai said to Rav Ashi: Thus we say in the name of Rabbi Levi: Everything for which we expound, we expound; anything else, no. If you say "from one thing to another" we expound; anything else, we do not expound.
