hebrew_text: בחולין אבל לא במוקדשים: אמאי לא דאמר קרא (דברים כב, ז) שלח תשלח את האם במי שאתה מצווה לשלחו יצא זה שאי אתה מצווה לשלחו אלא להביאו לידי גזבר
human_translation: to non-sacred but not to sacrificial Why not As the verse states: “You shall send the mother” to that you are commanded to send excludes this which you are not commanded to send rather to bring it to the custody of treasurer.
llm_translation: In Hullin, one may mourn but not in Me'ukdashim. Why not? For it is stated in the verse (Deuteronomy 22:7), "You shall surely let the mother go, but the young you may take for yourself." This teaches that one may only send away the mother when one is commanded to do so. This excludes a case where one is not commanded to send her away, but rather to bring her to the tax collector.

hebrew_text: אמר רבינא הלכך עוף טהור שהרג את הנפש פטור משלוח מ"ט דאמר קרא שלח תשלח את האם במי שאתה מצווה לשלחו יצא זה שאי אתה מצווה לשלחו אלא להביאו לב"ד היכי דמי אי דגמר דיניה
human_translation: Ravina says: Therefore, a kosher bird that killed a person is exempt from sending What is the reason as the verse states: “You shall send the mother.” to that you are commanded to send excludes this that you are not commanded to send rather to bring it to court. What are the circumstances If where its verdict was issued,
llm_translation: Ravina said: Therefore, a clean bird that killed a person is exempt from sending away. What is the reason? As the verse says, "You shall surely send away the mother" - with the one you are commanded to send it away, this one has fulfilled the obligation. If you are not commanded to send it away, but rather to bring it to the court, what is the comparison? If its judgment is complete...

hebrew_text: בר קטלא הוא אלא דלא גמר דיניה ובעי לאתוייה לבי דינא וקיומי ביה (דברים יג, ו) ובערת הרע מקרבך
human_translation: It is subject killed Rather, where its verdict was not issued, and required to bring it to the court to fulfill through it “And you shall eradicate the evil from your midst”
llm_translation: Bar Kattla he is but that not completed his judgment and he requires to bring him to the court and establish in it (Deuteronomy 13:6) "And you shall exterminate the evil from your midst."

hebrew_text: הני מוקדשין היכי דמי אילימא דהוה ליה קן בתוך ביתו ואקדשיה מי מיחייב (דברים כב, ו) כי יקרא קן צפור פרט למזומן
human_translation: What are the circumstances of these sacrificial If we say that had a nest in his house and consecrated it, is one obligated “If a bird’s nest happens excludes available
llm_translation: These consecrated items, what is the case? If you say that he had a nest in his house and consecrated it, is he liable? (Deuteronomy 22:6) "When a bird's nest chance upon you" - excluding one that is designated.

hebrew_text: אלא דחזא קן בעלמא ואקדשיה ומי קדוש (ויקרא כז, יד) איש כי יקדיש את ביתו קדש אמר רחמנא מה ביתו ברשותו אף כל ברשותו
human_translation: Rather, where merely saw a nest and he consecrated it. But Is consecrated the Merciful One states: “When a man shall sanctify his house to be holy” just as his house in his possession so too, any in his possession
llm_translation: Rather, he saw a nest in general and sanctified it, and who is holy (Leviticus 27:14) "If a man consecrates his house as holy." The Merciful One said: Just as his house is within his possession, so too is everything within his possession.

hebrew_text: אלא דאגבהינהו לאפרוחים ואקדשינהו והדר הדרינהו האי אפילו בחולין נמי לא מיחייב דתנא נטל את הבנים והחזירן לקן ואח"כ חזרה האם עליהן פטור מלשלח
human_translation: Rather, where lifted chicks, and consecrated them, and then returned them this even with regard to non-sacred is not obligated as is taught took the offspring and returned them to the nest, and thereafter, the mother returned upon them, exempt from sending
llm_translation: Rather, regarding the chicks, I sanctified them, and then I returned them. This, even with regard to non-consecrated animals, is also not obligatory, as it was taught: If one took the chicks and returned them to the nest, and afterwards the mother returned to them, he is exempt from sending her away.

hebrew_text: אלא דאגבהה לאם ואקדשה והדרה מעיקרא איחייב ליה בשילוח מקמי דאקדשה דתניא ר' יוחנן בן יוסף אומר הקדיש חיה ואח"כ שחטה פטור מלכסות שחטה ואח"כ הקדישה חייב לכסות שכבר נתחייב בכסוי קודם שיבא לידי הקדש
human_translation: Rather, where lifted the mother, and consecrated her, and returned her he was initially obligated in sending before he consecrated her. as it is taught Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Yosef says: consecrated an undomesticated animal and then slaughtered it, exempt from covering slaughtered it and then consecrated it, obligated to cover as he was already obligated in covering before it came into the possession of the Temple
llm_translation: Rather, with regard to a mother animal, if one consecrated it and then returned to its original state, he is obligated in sending it away before consecrating it, as it was taught: Rabbi Yochanan ben Yosef says, "If one consecrated a live animal and then slaughtered it, he is exempt from covering the blood. But if he slaughtered it and then consecrated it, he is obligated to cover the blood, as he was already obligated in covering before it came to the state of consecration."

hebrew_text: רב אמר במקדיש פירות שובכו ומרדו ושמואל אמר במקדיש תרנגולתו לבדק הבית
human_translation: Rav says: to consecrates the fruit, of his dovecote and they rebelled And Shmuel says: to consecrates his chicken for Temple maintenance,
llm_translation: Rav said: "In one who sanctifies his fruits, they return and rebel." And Shmuel said: "In one who sanctifies his hen for the inspection of the house."

hebrew_text: בשלמא שמואל לא אמר כרב דקא מוקים לה בקדשי בדק הבית אלא רב מאי טעמא לא אמר כשמואל
human_translation: Granted, Shmuel did not state in accordance with Rav, since he interprets it to consecrated for Temple maintenance, But what is the reason Rav did not state in accordance with Shmuel?
llm_translation: In Shmuel's opinion, it makes sense that he did not say like Rav, who establishes it with the consecrated items of the Temple treasury. Rather, Rav, what is the reason he did not say like Shmuel.

hebrew_text: אמר לך רב דוקא קפטרי משילוח כגון פירות שובכו דקדשי מזבח נינהו דכיון דקדשי קדושת הגוף לא פקעה קדושתייהו מינייהו אבל במקדיש תרנגולתו לבדק הבית דלאו קדשי מזבח דקדושת דמים בעלמא הוא כיון דמרדה פקעה קדושתייהו וחייבת בשילוח
human_translation: Rav said to you: I specifically exempted from sending where fruit of his dovecote, as they are consecrated for altar. Since they are consecrated inherent sanctity, their sanctity is not abrogated from them But in consecrates his chicken for Temple maintenance, where not consecrated for altar but merely sanctity value, once it rebels its sanctity is abrogated, and it is obligated in, sending
llm_translation: Rav Duka said to you: specifically, Kaphteri from the sending, such as fruits that have become unfit for the altar, they are considered consecrated items of the altar, since they are consecrated with sanctity of the body, their sanctity is not annulled from them. But when one consecrates his rooster for the inspection of the Temple, which is not consecrated items of the altar, just the sanctity of blood in general, once it becomes unfit, their sanctity is annulled, and one is obligated to send it away.

hebrew_text: ושמואל אמר כל היכא דאיתיה בבי גזא דרחמנא איתא דכתיב (תהלים כד, א) לה' הארץ ומלואה וכן אמר ר' יוחנן במקדיש תרנגולתו לבדק הבית ומרדה אמר ליה רבי שמעון בן לקיש וכיון שמרדה פקעה ליה קדושתה אמר ליה בבי גזא דרחמנא איתא דכתיב לה' הארץ ומלואה
human_translation: And Shmuel said: wherever it is, it is in the treasury [ bei gazza ] of the Merciful One, as it is written: “The earth is the Lord’s, and its fullness thereof” And so Rabbi Yoḥanan says to consecrated his chicken for Temple maintenance, and rebelled. Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said to him: But once it rebels, its sanctity is abrogated. said to him: it is in the treasury of the Merciful One, as it is written: “The earth is the Lord’s, and its fullness thereof.”
llm_translation: And Samuel said, wherever it comes into the house of Gazda, the Merciful One's is there, as it is written (Psalms 24:1) "The earth is the Lord's, and all it contains." And so Rabbi Yochanan said, when one sanctifies his rooster for checking the house, and it rebelled, Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said to him, once it rebelled, its sanctity is annulled. He said to him, in the house of Gazda, the Merciful One's is there, as it is written "The earth is the Lord's, and all it contains."

hebrew_text: ורמי דר' יוחנן אדר' יוחנן ורמי דר' שמעון בן לקיש אדר"ש בן לקיש
human_translation: And raises a contradiction of Rabbi Yoḥanan and that of Rabbi Yoḥanan and raises a contradiction of Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish and that of Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish
llm_translation: And it was raised by Rabbi Yochanan from Rabbi Yochanan, and it was raised by Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish from Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish.

hebrew_text: דאיתמר מנה זה לבדק הבית ונגנבו או נאבדו רבי יוחנן אמר חייב באחריותן עד שיבואו לידי גזבר וריש לקיש אמר כל היכא דאיתיה בבי גזא דרחמנא איתיה דכתיב לה' הארץ ומלואה קשיא דריש לקיש אדריש לקיש קשיא דר' יוחנן אדר' יוחנן
human_translation: As was stated: these one hundred dinars for Temple maintenance, and they were stolen or lost, Rabbi Yoḥanan says: He bears responsibility for them until they come into the possession of the treasurer [ gizbar ]. And Reish Lakish says: wherever it is, it is in the treasury of the Merciful One, as it is written: “The earth is the Lord’s, and its fullness.” of Reish Lakish a difficulty for of Reish Lakish, of Rabbi Yoḥanan a difficulty for of Rabbi Yoḥanan.
llm_translation: It was stated: If one designated a certain sum for the inspection of the house, and it was stolen or lost, Rabbi Yochanan said: he is liable for it until it reaches the treasurer. Resh Lakish said: wherever the property of the Merciful One is, there it is, as it is written, "The earth and all that fills it belong to the Lord." The difficulty of Resh Lakish is a difficulty, and the difficulty of Rabbi Yochanan is a difficulty.

hebrew_text: דריש לקיש אדריש לקיש לא קשיא הא מקמי דשמעיה מר' יוחנן רביה הא לבתר דשמעיה מר' יוחנן רביה

llm_translation: Resh Lakish: I will expound. I will expound. It is not difficult. Here, before the teaching of Rabbi Yochanan, his teacher. There, after the teaching of Rabbi Yochanan, his teacher.

hebrew_text: אלא דר' יוחנן אדר' יוחנן קשיא דר' יוחנן אדר' יוחנן נמי לא קשיא הא דאמר עלי הא דאמר הרי זו
human_translation: But of Rabbi Yoḥanan a difficulty of Rabbi Yoḥanan. of Rabbi Yoḥanan of Rabbi Yoḥanan also not difficult. This where said: upon me That where said: This is
llm_translation: Rather, it is of Rabbi Yochanan that of Rabbi Yochanan it is difficult. It is of Rabbi Yochanan that of Rabbi Yochanan it is not difficult. This one who said, "Upon me," this one who said, "Behold, this is it."

hebrew_text: מכלל דר"ש בן לקיש אע"ג דאמר עלי לא מחייב
human_translation: by inference that Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish, does not bear even though said: upon me.
llm_translation: From the principle that Reish Lakish expounded, even though he said "upon me it is not obligatory."

hebrew_text: והתניא איזהו נדר ואיזו היא נדבה נדר האומר הרי עלי עולה נדבה האומר הרי זו עולה ומה בין נדר לנדבה נדר מתה או נגנבה או שאבדה חייב באחריותה נדבה מתה או נגנבה או שאבדה אינו חייב באחריותה
human_translation: But isn’t it taught Which is a vow and which is a gift A vow one says: It is upon me a burnt offering. A gift one says: This a burnt offering. And what is between a vow and a gift a vow it died or was stolen or lost, bears responsibility for it. a gift it died or was stolen or lost, does not bear responsibility for it.
llm_translation: And it was taught in a Baraita: What is a vow, and what is a freewill offering? A vow is one who says, "Behold, upon me is an olah offering." A freewill offering is one who says, "Behold, this is an olah offering." And what is the difference between a vow and a freewill offering? For a vow, if it dies, is stolen, or is lost, he is liable for its replacement. For a freewill offering, if it dies, is stolen, or is lost, he is not liable for its replacement.

hebrew_text: אמר לך ריש לקיש הני מילי קדשי מזבח דמחוסר הקרבה אבל קדשי בדק הבית דלאו מחוסר הקרבה אע"ג דאמר עלי לא מחייב
human_translation: Reish Lakish said to you: This statement, consecrated for the altar, since it has not yet been sacrificed. But consecrated for Temple maintenance, which is not lacking sacrifice even though said: upon me, does not bear
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan said to you: These matters pertain to the holy items of the altar that are lacking in offering. However, the holy items of the Temple treasury, even though he said "upon me it is not obligatory."

hebrew_text: והתנן האומר שור זה עולה בית זה קרבן  מת השור נפל הבית אינו חייב באחריותן שור זה עלי עולה בית זה עלי קרבן מת השור ונפל הבית חייב לשלם
human_translation: But didn’t we learn one who says: This bull a burnt offering, or: This house an offering, the bull died the house collapsed, he does not bear responsibility for them; upon me this bull a burnt offering, or: upon me this house an offering, the bull died the house collapsed, obligated to pay
llm_translation: And we learned in a Mishnah: One who says, "This ox shall be a sacrifice for this house," if the ox dies, the house collapses, he is not liable for their damages. If the ox is a sacrifice for this house, and the house is a sacrifice for that, if the ox dies and the house collapses, he is obligated to pay.

hebrew_text: ה"מ היכא דמת השור ונפל הבית חייב לשלם דליתנהו אבל היכא דאיתנהו כל היכא דאיתיה בבי גזא דרחמנא איתיה דכתיב לה' הארץ ומלואה
human_translation: this statement, where the bull died or the house collapsed. he is obligated to pay, since they no exist. But where they exist, Wherever it is, it is in the treasury of the Merciful One, as it is written: “The earth is the Lord’s, and its fullness thereof.”
llm_translation: These are the words: Where the ox dies and the house collapses, one is liable to pay, for they were not given. But where they were given, in any place that the decree of the Merciful One comes, it comes, as it is written, "The earth and all that fills it belong to the Lord."

hebrew_text: אמר רב המנונא הכל מודים בערכין אע"ג דאמר עלי לא מיחייב מאי טעמא דלא מיתמר ליה בלא עלי
human_translation: Rav Hamnuna says: Everyone concedes with regard to valuations even if one said: upon me does not bear What is the reason because it cannot be stated by him without Upon me.
llm_translation: Rav Hamnuna said: Everyone agrees regarding evaluations, even though he said "Alai is not obligated." What is the reason? Because it is not explicitly stated without "Alai."

hebrew_text: היכי לימא לימא ערכי אמאן לימא ערך פלוני אמאן
human_translation: how shall he say Shall he say My own valuation, upon whom shall he say The valuation of so-and-so? upon whom
llm_translation: How should one say? "Say, 'Appraise, so-and-so.'" Say, "Appraise, Ploni."

hebrew_text: מתקיף לה רבא לימא הריני בערכי הריני בערך פלוני ועוד תניא רבי נתן אומר (ויקרא כז, כג) ונתן את הערכך ביום ההוא קדש לה' מה תלמוד לומר לפי שמצינו בהקדשות ומעשרות שמתחללין על מעות שבחולין נגנבו או שאבדו אינן חייבין באחריותן
human_translation: Rava objects to this: Let him say: I am with my own valuation, I am with the valuation of so-and-so. Additionally, it is taught Rabbi Natan says and he shall give your valuation on that day, as a consecrated thing to the Lord” Why the verse state: because we have found with regard to consecrated and tithes that they can be desacralized onto non-sacred money, was stolen or lost, do not bear responsibility for it.
llm_translation: Rava objects: Let him say, "I hereby pledge to give my value," "I hereby pledge to give the value of so-and-so," and furthermore, it was taught in a Baraita: Rabbi Nathan says, "And he shall give your valuation on that day, holy to the Lord" (Leviticus 27:23). What does the Torah come to teach us? Because we find regarding consecrated items and tithes that if they are redeemed with secular money and the money is stolen or lost, the owners are not liable.

hebrew_text: יכול אף זה כן ת"ל ונתן את הערכך וגו' חולין עד שיבאו לידי גזבר
human_translation: might this too, so, the verse states: “And he shall give your valuation non-sacred until it enters the possession of treasurer,
llm_translation: It is possible that this too, as it is stated: "And he shall set your valuation, etc." (Leviticus 27:12). Hullin, until they come into the hands of the treasurer.

hebrew_text: אלא אי איתמר הכי איתמר אמר רב המנונא הכל מודים בערכין דאע"ג דלא אמר עלי מיחייב דכתיב (ויקרא כז, כג) ונתן את הערכך חולין הן בידך עד שיבאו לידי גזבר:
human_translation: Rather, if was stated, this was stated: Rav Hamnuna says everyone concedes with regard to valuations that even if did not say: upon me, bears as it is written: “And he shall give your valuation,” non-sacred until it enters the possession of treasurer.
llm_translation: Rather, if it was stated thus, it was stated thus. Rav Hamnuna said: Everyone agrees regarding appraisals, that even though he did not say "upon me you are obligated," as it is written (Leviticus 27:23), "And he shall give your appraisal," they are secular in your possession until they come into the hands of the treasurer.

hebrew_text: חומר בכסוי וכו': תנו רבנן (דברים כב, ו) כי יקרא קן צפור לפניך מה ת"ל
human_translation: stringent in the covering the Sages taught “If a bird’s nest happens before you What the verse states
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Chomer b'kisui etc." Tanu Rabbanan (Devarim 22:6) "Ki yikra ken tzippor lifneicha, mah talmud lach."

hebrew_text: לפי שנאמר (דברים כב, ז) שלח תשלח את האם ואת הבנים תקח לך יכול יחזור בהרים וגבעות כדי שימצא קן ת"ל כי יקרא במאורע לפניך
human_translation: Since it is stated: “You shall send [ shalle’aḥ teshallaḥ ] the mother, but the young you may take for yourself,” might search in the mountains and hills in order to find a nest the verse states: “If happens,” when it confronts you;
llm_translation: According to what is stated (Deuteronomy 22:7), "You shall surely send away the mother, and the young ones you may take for yourself," one might think that one should return to the mountains and hills in order to find a nest. The Torah teaches us, "When a bird's nest chances before you" (Deuteronomy 22:6).

hebrew_text: קן מ"מ צפור טהורה ולא טמאה לפניך ברשות היחיד בדרך ברשות הרבים באילנות מנין ת"ל בכל עץ בבורות שיחין ומערות מנין ת"ל או על הארץ
human_translation: “nest” in any case, “bird’s” kosher and not non-kosher “before you” on private property, “on the way” in a public thoroughfare. From where in trees? The verse states: “In any tree.” in pits, ditches, and caves, from where The verse states: “Or on the ground,”
llm_translation: A nest of a clean bird and not an unclean one before you, in a private domain, on the road, in a public domain, in trees - whence do we learn? It is stated: "On every tree," in pits, bushes, and caves - whence do we learn? It is stated: "Or on the ground."

hebrew_text: וכי מאחר שסופנו לרבות כל דבר לפניך בדרך למה לי לומר לך מה דרך שאין קנו בידך אף כל שאין קנו בידך מכאן אמרו יוני שובך ויוני עלייה שקננו בטפיחין ובבירות ואווזין ותרנגולין שקננו בפרדס חייב בשילוח אבל קננו בתוך הבית וכן יוני הרדסיאות פטור משילוח
human_translation: And since, in the end, we will include everything, why do I “Before you on the way”? to say to you: Just as way which nest is not in your possession so too, all when its nest is not in your possession. From here stated: pigeons of a dovecote or pigeons of an attic that nested in wall niches or in buildings, and geese or chickens that nested in an orchard, one is obligated in sending But nested inside the house, and likewise domesticated pigeons, one is exempt from sending
llm_translation: And when we have finished including everything before you, why do I need to tell you the way that is not in your hand, just as everything that is not in your hand? From here they said: A dove that returns and a dove that ascends, which were acquired with clapping hands and pits and geese and chickens, which were acquired in a field, one is obligated in sending away. But if they were acquired inside the house, and similarly, a dove of the orchards, one is exempt from sending away.

hebrew_text: אמר מר מה דרך שאין קנו בידך אף כל שאין קנו בידך הא למה לי מכי יקרא נפקא כי יקרא פרט למזומן ועוד לפניך למה לי
human_translation: The Master said: Just as way which nest is not in your possession, so too, all when its nest is not in your possession. Why do I this It derived from: “If happens,” “If happens” excludes available. And furthermore, why do I “before you”
llm_translation: The Master said: "What is the way that you do not acquire with your hand? Just as everything that you do not acquire with your hand, why do I need it? From when it is read, it emerges: 'When he reads' - excluding a designated item. And furthermore, why do I need it before you?"

hebrew_text: אלא לפניך לאתויי שהיו לפניך ומרדו בדרך כדרב יהודה אמר רב דאמר רב יהודה אמר רב מצא קן בים חייב בשילוח שנאמר (ישעיהו מג, טז) כה אמר ה' הנותן בים דרך וגו'
human_translation: Rather, “before you” to include where were before you, and rebelled “On the way” that which Rav Yehuda Rav said, as Rav Yehuda said Rav said: found a nest in the sea, is obligated in sending as it is stated: “So said the Lord, who makes a way in the sea,
llm_translation: Instead, before you, to bring that they were before you and rebelled on the way as Rav Yehudah said Rav said Yehudah said Rav found a nest in the sea liable in sending away as it is said (Isaiah 43:16) "Thus said the Lord, who makes a way in the sea, etc."

hebrew_text: אלא מעתה מצא קן בשמים דכתיב (משלי ל, יט) דרך נשר בשמים הכי נמי דמיחייב בשילוח הקן דרך נשר איקרי דרך סתמא לא איקרי
human_translation: If that is so, one found a nest in the sky, which it is written: “The way of an eagle in the sky” also be obligated in sending the nest. is called “the way of an eagle,” it is not called: A way, an unspecified
llm_translation: Rather now, found a nest in the sky, as it is written (Proverbs 30:19) "The way of an eagle in the sky," so too, obligated in sending away the nest, the way of an eagle is called the way of a hidden one, it is not called the way of a public one.

hebrew_text: אמרי ליה פפונאי לרב מתנה מצא קן בראשו של אדם מהו אמר (שמואל ב טו, לב) ואדמה על ראשו משה מן התורה מנין (בראשית ו, ג) בשגם הוא בשר
human_translation: The of Pappunya said to Rav Mattana: found a nest on the head of a person, what is said “And earth upon his head” From where in the Torah Moses [ Moshe ] “For that he also [ beshaggam ] is flesh;
llm_translation: They said to Rav Matna: "If one finds a nest on a person's head, what is the law?" He said: "And dust shall be on his head" (2 Samuel 15:32) - this is from the Torah. How do we know? "For you are dust" (Genesis 3:19) - he is also flesh.

hebrew_text: המן מן התורה מנין (בראשית ג, יא) המן העץ
human_translation: From where in the Torah Haman? “Have you eaten of [ hamin ] the tree,
llm_translation: The man from the Torah, where is it derived? (Genesis 3:11) "The man from the tree."

hebrew_text: אסתר מן התורה מנין (דברים לא, יח) ואנכי הסתר אסתיר מרדכי מן התורה מנין דכתיב (שמות ל, כג) מר דרור ומתרגמינן מירא דכיא:
human_translation: From where in the Torah Esther? And I will hide [ haster astir ] From where in the Torah Mordecai? As it is written flowing myrrh [ mor deror ]” and we translate Mira dakhya ,
llm_translation: Esther from the Torah, where is it derived? (Deuteronomy 31:18) "But I will surely hide (אסתר) My face." Mordecai from the Torah, where is it derived? As it is written (Exodus 30:23), "Pure myrrh (מר דרור)," and we translate it as "myrrh of freedom."

hebrew_text: ואיזהו שאינו מזומן וכו': ר' חייא ור' שמעון חד תני הדרסיאות וחד תני הרדסיאות מאן דתני הרדסיאות על שם הורדוס ומאן דתני הדרסיאות על שם מקומן
human_translation: And which that are not available? Rabbi Ḥiyya and Rabbi Shimon One teaches hadrisei’ot , and one teaches hardisei’ot . one who teaches hardisei’ot , on account of Herod, and one who teaches hadrisei’ot , on account of their location.
llm_translation: "And who is not considered prepared, etc.: Rabbi Chiya and Rabbi Shimon, one taught 'Hadarsiyyot' and one taught 'Hardasiyyot.' Who taught 'Hardasiyyot' in reference to Herod, and who taught 'Hadarsiyyot' in reference to their place."

hebrew_text: אמר רב כהנא לדידי חזיין וקיימן שיתסר דרי בפתי מילא והוה קרא קירי קירי הוה חד מינייהו דלא הוה קרי קירי קירי אמרה לה חברתה סומא אמרי קירי קירי אמרה סומא אמרי קירי בירי אתיוה ושחטוה
human_translation: Rav Kahana said: I myself saw and they standing sixteen rows, a mil wide, and they were calling My master, my master. There was one of them who was not calling My master, my master. Another said to it: Blind say: My master, my master, said Blind say: My master, my slave, They brought and slaughtered it
llm_translation: Rav Kahana said: According to my observation, they would see and stand six rows of fine flour, and it would be called "kiriy kiriy." There was one type among them that was not called "kiriy kiriy." Her blind friend said, "They say 'kiriy kiriy.'" She said, "The blind say 'kiriy biri.'" They brought it and slaughtered it.

hebrew_text: א"ר אשי אמר לי [ר'] חנינא מילין מילין ס"ד אלא אימא במילין:
human_translation: Rav Ashi said: Rabbi Ḥanina said to me: words, enter your mind words Rather, say through words
llm_translation: Rabbi Ashi said to me, Rabbi Chanina said: "Words, words, thought." Rather say, "with words."

hebrew_text: עוף טמא פטור מלשלח: מנה"מ א"ר יצחק דאמר קרא כי יקרא קן צפור לפניך עוף משמע לן בין טהור בין טמא צפור טהור אשכחן דאיקרי צפור טמא לא אשכחן דאיקרי צפור
human_translation: a non-kosher bird, exempt from sending From where is this matter Rabbi Yitzḥak said: As the verse states: “If a bird’s [ tzippor ] nest happens before you” of indicates to us whether kosher or non-kosher. tzippor , we have found a kosher is called a tzippor , we have not found a non-kosher is called a tzippor .
llm_translation: Talmudic text: An impure bird is exempt from being sent away. From where do we derive this? Rabbi Yitzchak said: As the verse states, "When a bird's nest chances before you" (Deuteronomy 22:6), the term "bird" implies to us that whether pure or impure, a bird is found. We find a pure bird that is called a bird, but we do not find an impure bird that is called a bird.

hebrew_text: תא שמע (דברים ד, יז) תבנית כל צפור כנף מאי לאו צפור בין טהור בין טמא כנף חגבים לא צפור טהור כנף טמא וחגבים
human_translation: Come hear “The likeness of any winged bird [ tzippor ]” What, is it not “ tzippor ” whether kosher or non-kosher, “winged” grasshoppers No, “ tzippor ” a kosher “winged” non-kosher and grasshoppers.
llm_translation: Come and hear: (Deuteronomy 4:17) "The likeness of any winged bird." What is meant by "bird"? Whether pure or impure, the wing of a locust is not considered a pure bird's wing, but rather an impure bird's wing, and locusts.

hebrew_text: ת"ש (תהלים קמח, י) החיה וכל בהמה רמש וצפור כנף מאי לאו צפור בין טהור בין טמא וכנף חגבים לא צפור טהור כנף טמא וחגבים
human_translation: Come hear “The undomesticated animal and all domesticated animals, creeping things and winged birds [ tzippor ]” What, is it not “ tzippor ” whether kosher or non-kosher, and “winged” grasshoppers? No, “ tzippor ” a kosher “winged” non-kosher and grasshoppers.
llm_translation: Come and hear: "He gives life to all living creatures, the breath of all mankind." What is meant by "bird"? Whether pure or impure. And "winged insects" are not considered birds, neither pure nor impure, but winged insects.

hebrew_text: תא שמע (בראשית ז, יד) כל צפור כל כנף מאי לאו כדמקשינן לא כדמשנינן
human_translation: Come hear “Every bird [ tzippor ] of every type of wing” What, is it not difficulty that we posed No, as we resolved
llm_translation: Come and hear: (Genesis 7:14) "every bird, every wing" - What is the meaning of "every wing"? Not as we have learned.

hebrew_text: תא שמע (יחזקאל לט, א) ואתה בן אדם אמור לצפור כל כנף מאי לאו כדאקשינן לא כדשנינן
human_translation: Come hear “And you, son of man, Speak to the birds [ tzippor ] of every type of wing, What, is it not difficulty that we posed No, as we resolved
llm_translation: Come and hear (Ezekiel 39:1), "And you, son of man, prophesy against the birds of every feather." What is the reason? Not as we asked, not as we learned.

hebrew_text: ת"ש
human_translation: Come hear
llm_translation: Come and hear:

hebrew_text: (דניאל ד, ט) ובענפוהי ידורן צפרי שמיא צפרי שמיא איקרו צפרי סתמא לא איקרו
human_translation: “And in its branches will dwell the birds [ tzipparei ] of the heaven” are called: Birds [ tzipparei ] of the heaven, they are not called: Tzipparei , an unspecified
llm_translation: (Daniel 4:9) "And in its branches dwelt the birds of the heaven, the birds of the heaven they called."

hebrew_text: ת"ש (דברים יד, יא) כל צפור טהורה מכלל דאיכא טמאה לא מכלל דאיכא אסורה
human_translation: Come hear “Every kosher bird [ tzippor ] by inference, that there is a non-kosher No, by inference that there is prohibited
llm_translation: Come and hear: (Deuteronomy 14:11) "Every clean bird," implying that there is impurity, not implying that there is prohibition.

hebrew_text: מאי היא אי טרפה בהדיא כתיב ואי בשחוטה דמצורע מסיפא דקרא נפקא (דברים יד, יב) וזה אשר לא תאכלו מהם לרבות שחוטת מצורע
human_translation: What is If with a wound that will cause it to die within twelve months [ tereifa ], is written explicitly And if to the slaughtered of a leper, is derived from the latter clause of the verse “But these are they of which you shall not eat” to include the slaughtered of the leper.
llm_translation: What is it? If it is a Tereifah, it is explicitly written. And if it is a Shchutah of a Metzora, it is derived from the latter part of the verse (Deuteronomy 14:12), "And this that you shall not eat of them," to include the slaughter of a Metzora.

hebrew_text: לעולם בשחוטה דמצורע ולעבור עליו בעשה ובלא תעשה ולוקמה בטרפה ולעבור עליו בעשה ולא תעשה דבר הלמד מענינו ובענינא דשחוטה כתיב
human_translation: Actually, to the slaughtered of a leper, and transgresses positive mitzva prohibition on account of it. But interpret to a tereifa , transgresses a positive mitzva and a prohibition on account of it? a matter derived from its context, is written in the context of a slaughtered
llm_translation: Always in a slaughtered animal of a metzora, and to transgress upon it with a positive commandment and a negative commandment, and if it is torn and to transgress upon it with a positive commandment and a negative commandment, this is a matter that is learned from its context, and in the context of a slaughtered animal it is written.

hebrew_text: ת"ש (ויקרא יד, ד) שתי צפרים חיות מאי חיות לאו שחיות בפיך מכלל דאיכא לאו שחיות בפיך לא מאי חיות שחיין ראשי אברים שלהן
human_translation: Come hear two living birds [ tzipporim ] what “living”? not that they are living in your mouth, by inference, that there are that are not living in your mouth, No, what “living”? that their extremities are living,
llm_translation: Come and hear: "Two living birds" (Leviticus 14:4). What is meant by "living"? Are they not living in your mouth? From the inference that there is, are they not living in your mouth? No. What is meant by "living"? They have their heads and limbs intact.

hebrew_text: ת"ש מסיפא טהורות מכלל דאיכא טמאות לא מכלל דאיכא טרפות
human_translation: Come hear from the latter clause kosher.” by inference that there are non-kosher No, by inference that there are tereifot .
llm_translation: Come and hear: From the first clause it is derived that there are pure animals from the general category of animals, but it is not derived that there are impure animals from the general category of animals, and it is not derived that there are animals that are tereifah.

hebrew_text: טרפות מחיות נפקא הניחא למאן דאמר טרפה חיה אלא למ"ד טרפה אינה חיה מאי איכא למימר ועוד בין למ"ד טרפה חיה בין למ"ד אינה חיה מדתנא דבי ר' ישמעאל נפקא
human_translation: tereifot is derived from “living” this works out well according to the one who says a tereifa can live But according to the one who says a tereifa cannot live, what is there to say? And furthermore, whether according to the one who says a tereifa can live or according to the one who says a tereifa cannot live, is derived from that which the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Treifot mechiyot nafka hanicha leman de'amar treifah chayah ela leman de'amar treifah einah chayah mai eika le'meimar ve'od bein leman de'amar treifah chayah bein leman de'amar einah chayah midetana de'bei Rabbi Yishmael nafka. English translation: Treifot (non-kosher animals) that are alive - it emerges, it is preferable according to the one who says a treifah (non-kosher animal) is alive, but according to the one who says a treifah is not alive, what can be said? And furthermore, whether according to the one who says a treifah is alive or according to the one who says it is not alive, as it was taught in the school of Rabbi Yishmael, it emerges.

hebrew_text: דתנא דבי רבי ישמעאל נאמר מכשיר ומכפר בפנים ונאמר מכשיר ומכפר בחוץ
human_translation: As the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: stated enable and atone, inside And stated enable and atone, outside
llm_translation: As taught in the school of Rabbi Yishmael: It is stated "makhshir" and "mekhaper" regarding the inside, and it is stated "makhshir" and "mekhaper" regarding the outside.

hebrew_text: מה מכשיר ומכפר האמור בפנים עשה בו מכשיר כמכפר אף מכשיר ומכפר האמור בחוץ עשה בו מכשיר כמכפר
human_translation: Just as enable or atone stated inside made enables like atones, so too, enable or atone stated outside made enables like atones.
llm_translation: What is valid and atones as stated regarding the inside, make it valid like atoning; likewise, what is valid and atones as stated regarding the outside, make it valid like atoning.

hebrew_text: אלא אמר רב נחמן בר יצחק למעוטי צפורי עיר הנדחת למאי אי לשילוח לא אמרה תורה שלח לתקלה אלא לשחיטה
human_translation: Rather, Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: to exclude birds from an idolatrous city. For what If to sending Torah did not say send to a stumbling block. Rather, to slaughter.
llm_translation: Rather, Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak said: To exclude the bird of a city of refuge, for what purpose? If not for sending away, the Torah did not say "send away for misfortune," but for slaughter.

hebrew_text: רבא אמר למעוטי שלא לזווג לה אחרת קודם שלוחיה למאי אי לשחיטה הא בעיא שילוח אלא לשילוח
human_translation: Rava said: to exclude not pair with another before its sent For what If to slaughter requires sent Rather, to sending
llm_translation: Rava said: To exclude that one should not pair her with another before sending her, for what? If for slaughter, it requires sending, rather for sending.

hebrew_text: רב פפא אמר לצפורים שהחליפו (בצפורי) עבודה זרה דכתיב (דברים ז, כו) והיית חרם כמוהו כל מה שאתה מהייה הימנו כמוהו למאי אי לשילוח לא אמרה תורה שלח לתקלה אלא לשחיטה
human_translation: Rav Pappa said: to birds that were exchanged for birds of idol worship, as it is written and become [ vahayita ] accursed like it” anything that you generate [ mehayye ] from it, like it. For what If to sent the Torah did not say: Send to a mishap. Rather, to slaughter.
llm_translation: Rav Papa said to the birds that exchanged idol worship, as it is written (Deuteronomy 7:26), "And you shall be a ban like it; you shall utterly detest it, and you shall utterly abhor it; for it is a ban." For what purpose? If for sending away, the Torah did not say "send away for negligence," but for slaughter.

hebrew_text: רבינא אמר הכא במאי עסקינן בעוף שהרג את הנפש היכי דמי אי דגמר דינא בר קטלא הוא אלא קודם גמר דינא ולמאי אי לשילוח בעי לאתויי לבי דינא וקיומי (דברים יג, ו) ובערת הרע מקרבך אלא לשחיטה:
human_translation: Ravina said: Here we are dealing with a bird that killed a person What are the circumstances If where its verdict was issued, it is subject killed, Rather, before its verdict was issued. And for what If to sending required to bring it to the court to fulfill “And you shall eradicate the evil from your midst” Rather, to slaughter.
llm_translation: Ravina said: Here, what are we dealing with? In the case of a bird that killed a person, what is the ruling? If it is determined to be a killer bird, then it is before the determination of its status as a killer bird. And for what purpose? If it is for sending away to exile, it should be brought to the court and the verse "and you shall purge the evil from your midst" (Deuteronomy 13:6) applies. Rather, it is for slaughter.

hebrew_text: עוף טמא רובץ על ביצי עוף טהור: בשלמא עוף טמא רובץ על ביצי טהור בעינן צפור וליכא אלא עוף טהור רובץ על ביצי עוף טמא הא צפור הוא
human_translation: a non-kosher bird is resting upon the eggs of a kosher bird, Granted, a non-kosher bird is resting upon the eggs of a kosher we require “ tzippor ” and is not But a kosher bird is resting upon the eggs of a non-kosher bird, it is a tzippor ,
llm_translation: Impure bird crouches on eggs of pure bird: Granted, impure bird crouches on eggs of pure bird, we require a bird, and there is none except a pure bird crouching on eggs of an impure bird, this is a bird.

hebrew_text: כדאמר רב כהנא (דברים כב, ז) תקח לך ולא לכלביך הכא נמי תקח לך ולא לכלביך
human_translation: that which Rav Kahana said you may take for yourself” but not for your dog. Here too, you may take for yourself, but not for your dog
llm_translation: As Rav Kahana said (Deuteronomy 22:7), "You shall take for yourself, and not for your dogs." Here too, "You shall take for yourself, and not for your dogs."

hebrew_text: והיכא איתמר דרב כהנא אהא דתניא אם טרפה חייב בשילוח אפרוחים טרפות פטור משילוח מנא הני מילי אמר רב כהנא דאמר קרא תקח לך ולא לכלביך
human_translation: And where was of Rav Kahana stated? with regard to that which is taught mother a tereifa , obligated to send fledglings tereifot , exempt from sending From where is this matter Rav Kahana said: As the verse states: “You may take for yourself,” but not for your dog
llm_translation: And where was it stated that Rav Kahana said: Here is what was taught in a Baraita: If an animal is a טְרֵפָה (trefah), one is obligated in sending away the mother bird, but if the mother bird is a טְרֵפָה (trefah), one is exempt from sending it away. From where do we derive these matters? Rav Kahana said: Because the verse states, "You shall take for yourself, but for your dog you shall throw it."

hebrew_text: ולהקיש אם טרפה לאפרוחים מה אפרוחים טרפות פטור משילוח אף אם טרפה נמי פטור מלשלח
human_translation: But compare a tereifa mother to fledglings Just as tereifa fledglings exempt from sending so too, a tereifa mother also exempt from sending
llm_translation: And to compare: if an animal is a treifah for chicks, just as treifah chicks are exempt from sending away the mother bird, so too if it is treifah, the mother bird is also exempt from sending away.

hebrew_text: אם כן צפור למעוטי עוף טמא ל"ל
human_translation: If so, why do I “ tzippor ” to exclude a non-kosher bird?
llm_translation: If so, "bird" to exclude "unclean bird" for itself.

hebrew_text: והתניא אם אפרוחין טרפה חייב בשילוח אמר אביי הכי קאמר אפרוח שאמן טרפה חייב בשילוח
human_translation: But isn’t it taught a mother of fledglings, tereifa , obligated to send Abaye said this is saying: a fledgling whose mother is a tereifa , obligated to send
llm_translation: And it was taught in a Baraita: If chicks are a treifah, one is obligated in sending away. Abaye said: This is what it means - chicks that were raised as a treifah, one is obligated in sending away.

hebrew_text: בעי רב הושעיא הושיט ידו לקן ושחט מיעוט סימנים מהו
human_translation: Rav Hoshaya raises a dilemma: stretched his hand into a nest and slaughtered, a minority of two organs that must be severed in ritual slaughter [ simanim ], what is
llm_translation: Rav Hoshaya inquired: "If one extends his hand to a nest and slaughters with minimal signs, what is the ruling?"

hebrew_text: מי אמרינן כיון דאילו שביק להו מטרפי בעינן לך ולא לכלביך או דלמא כיון דבידו למגמר שחיטה תקח לך קרינא ביה וחייב בשילוח תיקו
human_translation: Do we say: Since if those are left they will tereifot , we require “for yourself,” and not for your dog? Or perhaps, since it is in his power to complete the slaughter, we call “Take for yourself,” and one is obligated to send shall stand
llm_translation: We say, since he left them, we require for you and not for your dog, or perhaps, since it is in his power to complete the slaughter, we read in it for you and you are liable for sending away. Well said.

hebrew_text: בעי ר' ירמיה מטלית מהו שתחוץ כנפים מהו שיחוצו
human_translation: Rabbi Yirmeya raises a dilemma: a rag what is it interpose wings what is they interpose
llm_translation: Rabbi Yirmiyah inquired: "Regarding a talit, what is the ruling if its corners touch? What is the ruling if they overlap?"

hebrew_text: ביצים מוזרות מהו שני סדרי ביצים זו על גב זו מהו זכר על גבי ביצים ונקבה על גבי זכר מהו תיקו
human_translation: unfertilized [ muzarot ] eggs what is two sets of eggs one on top of the other, what is what is a male on top of eggs and a female on top of male? shall stand
llm_translation: Eggs strange, what is the law regarding two orders of eggs, one upon the other? What if a male egg upon top of eggs, and a female egg upon top of a male egg? What is the resolution?

hebrew_text: בעי ר' זירא יונה על ביצי תסיל מהו תסיל על ביצי יונה מהו
human_translation: Rabbi Zeira raises a dilemma: a pigeon upon the eggs of a tasil , what is a tasil upon the eggs of a pigeon, what is
llm_translation: Requested translation: Rabbi Zeira inquired: "If a dove is placed on top of eggs of a hen, what is the status of the eggs? And if eggs of a dove are placed on top of a hen, what is the status?"

hebrew_text: אמר אביי ת"ש עוף טמא רובץ על ביצי עוף טהור וטהור רובץ על ביצי עוף טמא פטור משילוח הא טהור וטהור חייב דלמא בקורא:
human_translation: Abaye said: Come hear a non-kosher bird is resting upon the eggs of a kosher bird, or a kosher is resting upon the eggs of a non-kosher bird, exempt from sending that a kosher and kosher obligated Perhaps to pheasant,
llm_translation: Abbaye said: Come and hear: An impure bird crouches on the eggs of a pure bird, and a pure bird crouches on the eggs of an impure bird - he is exempt from sending away the mother bird. But if the impure one crouches on the eggs of the pure one, he is obligated to send away the mother bird, perhaps due to the verse in Deuteronomy 22:6.

hebrew_text: קורא זכר רבי אליעזר מחייב וחכמים פוטרין: אמר רבי אבהו מאי טעמא דרבי אליעזר אתיא דגירה דגירה כתיב הכא (ירמיהו יז, יא) קורא דגר ולא ילד וכתיב התם (ישעיהו לד, טו) ובקעה ודגרה בצלה
human_translation: a male pheasant Rabbi Eliezer deems obligated and the Rabbis deem exempt Rabbi Abbahu said: What is the reasoning of Rabbi Eliezer? brooding brooding comes It is written here: “As the pheasant that broods over young that he has not brought forth” and it is written elsewhere and hatch, and brood under her shadow”
llm_translation: The reader of the male, Rabbi Eliezer obligates, and the sages exempt. Rabbi Abahu said: What is the reason for Rabbi Eliezer? It is because "gerah gerah" is written here (Jeremiah 17:11) "He who gains riches, but not through justice." And it is written there (Isaiah 34:15) "The arrow snake will make her nest and lay eggs."

hebrew_text: אמר ר"א מחלוקת בקורא זכר אבל בקורא נקבה דברי הכל חייב פשיטא קורא זכר תנן מהו דתימא רבנן אפילו קורא נקבה פטרי והא דקתני זכר להודיעך כחו דרבי אליעזר קמשמע לן
human_translation: Rabbi Elazar says: dispute with regard to a male pheasant, but to a female pheasant all agree obligated obvious, we learned A male pheasant? Lest you say the Rabbis deem exempt even a female pheasant, and that which teaches a male to convey to you the far-reaching nature of Rabbi Eliezer, teaches us
llm_translation: Said Rabbi Eliezer: Dispute regarding one who reads as male, but regarding one who reads as female, the words of all are obligated. Obviously! A male reader - we learned: What, will you say, the Rabbis even exempt a female reader? But that which it teaches "male" is to inform you of the strength of Rabbi Eliezer. This teaches us.

hebrew_text: ואמר רבי אלעזר מחלוקת בקורא זכר אבל בזכר דעלמא דברי הכל פטור פשיטא קורא זכר תנן מהו דתימא רבי אליעזר אפי' זכר דעלמא מחייב והאי דקתני קורא זכר להודיעך כחן דרבנן קמ"ל
human_translation: And Rabbi Elazar says: dispute with regard to a male pheasant, but to male in general, all agree exempt obvious, we learned A male pheasant? Lest you say Rabbi Eliezer deems obligated even male in general, and that which teaches: A male to convey to you the far-reaching nature of the Rabbis, teaches us
llm_translation: And Rabbi Elazar said: There is a dispute regarding one who reads the Torah portion mentioning a male animal, but regarding a male human in general, everyone agrees he is exempt. Obviously! One who reads about a male animal, we learned in a Mishnah, what is the case? Lest you say Rabbi Eliezer obligates even for a male human, but this Mishnah that teaches about a male animal is to inform you that the Rabbis exempt one from liability.

hebrew_text: תניא נמי הכי זכר דעלמא פטור קורא זכר ר"א מחייב וחכמים פוטרין:
human_translation: This is also taught a male in general, exempt a male pheasant, Rabbi Eliezer deems obligated and the Rabbis deem exempt
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: Similarly, regarding the mention of the world, one who reads "male" is exempt. Rabbi Eliezer deems one who reads "male" liable, while the Sages exempt.

hebrew_text: מתני׳ היתה מעופפת בזמן שכנפיה נוגעות בקן חייב לשלח אין כנפיה נוגעות בקן פטור מלשלח אין שם אלא אפרוח אחד או ביצה אחת חייב לשלח שנאמר קן קן מכל מקום
human_translation: was hovering when its wings are touching in the nest, obligated to send are not touching in the nest, exempt from sending there is only one fledgling or one egg, obligated to send as it is stated: nest nest in any case.
llm_translation: Mishnah: If it was fluttering, when its wings touch the nest, one is obligated to send it away. If its wings do not touch the nest, one is exempt from sending it away. There is only one chick or one egg there, one is obligated to send it away, as it is stated: "You shall surely send away the mother bird."

hebrew_text: היו שם אפרוחים מפריחים או ביצים מוזרות פטור מלשלח שנאמר (דברים כב, ו) והאם רובצת על האפרוחים או על הביצים מה אפרוחים בני קיימא אף ביצים בני קיימא יצאו מוזרות ומה הביצים צריכין לאמן אף האפרוחין צריכין לאמן יצאו מפריחין:
human_translation: there were fledglings flying, or unfertilized eggs exempt from sending as it is stated “And the mother is resting upon the fledglings or upon the eggs.” Just as the fledglings are living, so too, the eggs be living excludes unfertilized And just as the eggs need their mothers so too, the fledglings need their mothers. excludes flying.
llm_translation: There were there chicks hatching or strange eggs, exempt from sending as it is stated (Deuteronomy 22:6) "The mother bird sitting on the chicks or on the eggs" just as chicks are offspring so too eggs are offspring, they came out strange. And just as eggs require nurturing, so too chicks require nurturing, they came out hatching.

hebrew_text: גמ׳ תנו רבנן רובצת ולא מעופפת יכול אפי' כנפיה נוגעות בקן ת"ל רובצת מאי תלמודא מדלא כתיב יושבת
human_translation: the Sages taught resting and not hovering. might even its wings are touching the nest. the verse states: “Resting,” What is the derivation, from that sitting is not written
llm_translation: Gemara: The Rabbis taught: "It is crouching and not flying." One might have thought that even if its wings touch the nest, it is considered flying. Therefore, the verse teaches "crouching." What is the reason? Because it is not written "sitting."

hebrew_text: אמר רב יהודה אמר רב היתה יושבת בין שני רובדי אילן רואים כל שאם תשמט נופלת עליהם חייב לשלח ואם לאו פטור
human_translation: Rav Yehuda says Rav says: was sitting between two tree branches, looks any where if would slip fall upon obligated to send And if not exempt
llm_translation: Rav Yehudah said in the name of Rav: If a woman was sitting between two tree trunks, and one can see through, if she removes her garment and it falls on them, she is obligated to send it back to her. But if not, she is exempt.

hebrew_text: מיתיבי היתה יושבת ביניהן פטור מלשלח על גביהן חייב לשלח היתה מעופפת אפי' כנפיה נוגעות בקן פטור מלשלח
human_translation: raises an objection was sitting among exempt from sending above them, obligated to send was hovering, even its wings are touching the nest, exempt from sending
llm_translation: The scholars raised an objection: If she was sitting between them, he is exempt from sending away the mother bird on their account; he is obligated to send away the mother bird if she was hovering, even if her wings are touching the nest, he is exempt from sending away.

hebrew_text: מאי לאו על גביהן דומיא דביניהן מה ביניהן דנגעה בהו אף על גביהן דנגעה בהו אבל רובדי אילן פטור
human_translation: What, is it not above them similar to between them? Just as between them where she is touching them, so too, above them where she is touching them. but tree branches exempt
llm_translation: What is the case of "not similar to their produce"? Just as in their produce, if it was touched, it becomes impure, so too regarding themselves, if they were touched, they become impure. However, tree branches are exempt.

hebrew_text: לא על גביהן דומיא דביניהן מה ביניהן דלא נגעה עלייהו אף על גביהן דלא נגעה עלייהו והיינו רובדי אילן
human_translation: No; above them similar to between them Just as between them where she is not touching them above, so too, above them where she is not touching them above. And that is tree branches.
llm_translation: Not on their backs similar to between them what between them that not touched upon them also on their backs that not touched upon them and that is the majority of a tree.

hebrew_text: ה"נ מסתברא דאי סלקא דעתך רובדי אילן פטור אדתני היתה מעופפת אפי' כנפיה נוגעות בקן פטור מלשלח ליתני רובדי אילן וכ"ש מעופפת
human_translation: This, too, stands to reason, As, if enter your mind exempt tree branches, Rather than teaching was hovering, even its wings are touching the nest, exempt from sending let teach tree branches, and all the more so is hovering.
llm_translation: So it is logical that if it were to enter your mind that the majority of a tree is exempt, as we have learned: if it was flying, even if its wings touch a nest, it is exempt from sending away. Let it teach that the majority of a tree is exempt, and all the more so if it was flying.

llm_translation: Fluttering - it is necessary for him that even its wings touch the nest, exempt from sending.

human_translation: What, is it not above them similar to between them Just as between them where she is not touching them above so too, above them where she is not touching them above? And that is tree branches.

human_translation: No, above them similar to between them Just as between them where she is touching them, so too, above them where she is touching them. but tree branches exempt If that is so, rather than teaching the last clause: was hovering, even its wings are touching the nest, exempt
llm_translation: Not on their account similar to between them what between them if touched them also on their account if touched them but those who trample a tree exempt if so established conclusion was fluttering even its wings touching a nest exempt
